('29', 0, 3, 6, 206) Devdas 1, Pyarelal 2, Mahadev 3 and Manzar Ali are with me.
('29', 0, 3, 7, 266) I shall return in a couple of days.

('29', 1, 0, 1, 1184) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 1, 1, 2, 1224) 3. RELIEF WORK IN MALABAR 1
('29', 1, 2, 3, 1252) I have to confess that the response to this appeal has been more prompt than I had expected.
('29', 1, 2, 4, 1345) It has been proved not once but many times that, by God’s grace, compassion does exist in the hearts of the people.
('29', 1, 2, 5, 1461) Many funds have been launched for this work.
('29', 1, 2, 6, 1506) People may pay their contribution to Whichever fund they choose; I would only urge that pay, they must.
('29', 1, 2, 7, 1610) Malabar’s misery is unimaginable.
('29', 1, 2, 8, 1644) If a man expecting death survives, he dances with joy.
('29', 1, 2, 9, 1699) He forgets hunger, thrist, heat or cold in the excitement of having survived.
('29', 1, 2, 10, 1777) Our brothers and sisters in Malabar are in this predicament.
('29', 1, 2, 11, 1838) Those who are dead are gone.
('29', 1, 2, 12, 1867) The survivors are simply happy because they are alive.
('29', 1, 2, 13, 1922) As days pass, their misery will increase, not diminish.
('29', 1, 2, 14, 1978) We are humble creatures before God.
('29', 1, 2, 15, 2014) We have the power to crush an ant and that makes us arrogant; Whereas God has a thousand times more power to crush us like ants and He does exercise that power on occasion.
('29', 1, 2, 16, 2187) This action of His is, however, not “violence”, because He is omniscient and an ocean of compassion.
('29', 1, 2, 17, 2288) Since we cannot pierce His mystery, we call Him the creator, preserver and destroyer of the world.
('29', 1, 2, 18, 2387) He, in fact, neither creates nor preserves nor destroys.
('29', 1, 2, 19, 2444) We know not what law governs our birth, life and death.
('29', 1, 2, 20, 2500) Whatever it is, as long as we desire to live, it is our natural and inescapable duty to help others to live.
('29', 1, 2, 21, 2609) Readers will be glad to know that some brothers and sisters are missing a meal every day, some have given up milk or other things and they are contributing to the Fund.
('29', 1, 2, 22, 2778) What is thus saved.
('29', 1, 2, 23, 2798) Even children have joined this work spontaneously.
('29', 1, 2, 24, 2849) A handsome amount is likely to be collected in this way.
('29', 1, 2, 25, 2906) A small girl had stolen three pice which too she paid to the Fund.
('29', 1, 2, 26, 2973) A sister has donated her four bracelets and a chain of pure gold.
('29', 1, 2, 27, 3039) Another sister has given her heavy necklace.
('29', 1, 2, 28, 3084) A child has parted with his gold trinket and a sister With her silver anklets.
('29', 1, 2, 29, 3163) One person has given two toe rings.
('29', 1, 2, 30, 3199) An Antyaja 2 girl has offered voluntarily the ornaments worn on her feet.
('29', 1, 2, 31, 3273) A young man has handed over his gold cufflinks.
('29', 1, 2, 32, 3321) Rs. 6994 13 3 have been collected in cash up to date.
('29', 1, 2, 33, 3375) (Pleasesee
('29', 1, 3, 34, 3386) 1 A similar appeal in regard to flood relief was made in Young India; vide “Notes (subtopic Help to Malabar)”, 14 8 1924. 2 Literally “the last born”, the castes traditionally regarded as untouchables.
('29', 2, 0, 1, 3588) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 3
('29', 2, 1, 2, 3634) the last page 1).
('29', 2, 1, 3, 3652) The following amounts were deposited with the Bombay branch: A gentleman—Rs. 5; Dahyalal Harivallabh Joshi—Rs. I0; Vishveshwar Manilal—Rs. 101; a gentleman—Re.1. I trust that the collection will continue at the same rate at which it has started.
('29', 2, 2, 4, 3898) CLOTHES
('29', 2, 3, 5, 3906) Clothes are coming in large numbers.
('29', 2, 3, 6, 3943) It is difficult to estimate their value.
('29', 2, 3, 7, 3984) These clothes are most welcome on this occasion.
('29', 2, 3, 8, 4033) When there is a cloud burst, it is not possible to think of swadeshi and paradeshi 2. Therefore I intend to accept any clothes that may be offered.
('29', 2, 3, 9, 4181) I do not have the nerve to say that I will not clothe a naked man in foreign garments.
('29', 2, 3, 10, 4268) If India had been overflowing with khadi by now, I would, indeed, have said this.
('29', 2, 3, 11, 4350) As long as I have not acquired this power, how can we, who are ourselves loaded with garments, be fastidious while clothing the naked?
('29', 2, 3, 12, 4485) I have lost sight of the distinction between co operation and non co operation on this occasion of distress relief.
('29', 2, 3, 13, 4601) I am prepared to serve under Government officials in the work of feeding the hungry; and I advise the non co operators to do the same.
('29', 2, 3, 14, 4736) It does not mean that we should also attend meetings convened by the Government.
('29', 2, 3, 15, 4817) We are not interested in these things.
('29', 2, 3, 16, 4856) We should only perform the soldier’s job.
('29', 2, 3, 17, 4898) If we collect funds, we should modestly extend relief without coming in the way of the Government to quarters where the Government has not reached or does not wish to reach.
('29', 2, 3, 18, 5072) If the Government wills, it can extend abundant help.
('29', 2, 3, 19, 5126) The entire work is so enormous that there is enough scope for private enterprise and private charity.
('29', 2, 3, 20, 5228) Private enterprise alone will not be able to meet the challenge; but whatever is left undone by Government aid can be undertaken by private relief alone.
('29', 2, 3, 21, 5382) I am considering in consultation with Vallabhbhai 3 how best to utilize the funds.
('29', 2, 3, 22, 5465) Much depends upon the amount of money collected.
('29', 2, 3, 23, 5514) If anyone’s contribution is not acknowledged in Navajivan, he should write to me.
('29', 2, 3, 24, 5596) The intention to acknowledge all amounts is still there.
('29', 2, 3, 25, 5653) In case of very small amounts, I intend to publish only the
('29', 2, 4, 26, 5713) 1 Of Navajivan, 17 8 1924
('29', 2, 5, 27, 5739) 2 Foreign 3 Vallabhbhai Patel (1875 1950); Congress leader of Gujarat; first Deputy Prime Minister of India
('29', 3, 0, 1, 5847) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 3, 1, 2, 5887) totals.
('29', 3, 1, 3, 5895) Those who wish to remain anonymous, may kindly let me know their wish.
('29', 3, 1, 4, 5966) If the donors of clothes remember the following instructions, it will be convenient to accept and forward the gifts: 1. Used clothes may be washed before they are offered.
('29', 3, 1, 5, 6138) 2. Torn garments may first be stitched.
('29', 3, 1, 6, 6178) 3. All clothes may be properly folded, bundled and labelled with the name of the donor and the number of garments.
('29', 3, 1, 7, 6293) We are not giving away these clothes to beggars.
('29', 3, 1, 8, 6342) These, people, like ourselves, belong to clean and tidy middle class families.
('29', 3, 1, 9, 6421) I do hope that the same love, care and courtesy will be shown to them, as we do while giving something to our own brother or sister.
('29', 3, 1, 10, 6554) Indeed we should show consideration and care while we give even to a beggar.
('29', 3, 1, 11, 6631) It does not take much time to wash unclean clothes, stitch torn garments or to fold them all properly.
('29', 3, 1, 12, 6734) It merely tests one’s fellow feeling.
('29', 3, 2, 13, 6772) STUDENT OF MAHAVIDYALAYA
('29', 3, 3, 14, 6797) Readers are aware that students of the Mahavidyalaya have offered yarn; but, like the pupils of Shraddhanandji 1 during the South African campaign, they have also donated manual work.
('29', 3, 3, 15, 6981) About 75 students put in Work as labourers at the college building which is being constructed for them and they paid to this fund the wages they earned.
('29', 3, 3, 16, 7134) I congratulate the students and hope that they will often undertake such manual labour which is the true way of utilizing the education acquired by them.
('29', 3, 4, 17, 7288) WHERE TO GIVE?
('29', 3, 5, 18, 7303) At Ahmedabad, the donations can be forwarded to the offices of the Provincial Committee and the Navajivan or to the Ashram.
('29', 3, 5, 19, 7427) In Bombay, arrangements may be made with the Provincial Committee or the donations may be forwarded to the branch office of the Navajivan on Princess Street.
('29', 3, 5, 20, 7585) Wherever money, yarn or clothes are forwarded, I Would advise the donors to take a regular receipt.

('29', 3, 6, 22, 7701) Navajivan, 17 8 1924
('29', 3, 7, 23, 7722) 1 1856 1926; nationalist leader of Arya Samaj who was known as Mahatma Munshiram; founder of the Gurukul at Kangri near Hardwar

('29', 4, 1, 2, 7896) 4. TEACHERS AND TRAINING IN SPINNING
('29', 4, 2, 3, 7933) Bhai Harishankar Trivedi has written the following thought provoking letter on this subject: 1
('29', 4, 3, 4, 8028) There is not the least doubt in my mind that students Would certainly learn to spin if teachers take an interest in and masterspinning and its related arts.
('29', 4, 3, 5, 8185) Experience shows that students’ interest in a subject is sustained not by the subject matter but by the teacher.
('29', 4, 3, 6, 8298) My own experience has been that one teacher used to bore me to sleep while teaching chemistry, whereas another teacher kept me wide awake and interested in the same subject.
('29', 4, 3, 7, 8472) The former, who talked and talked without clarifying the topic, was not liked while, as the other teacher elucidated the theme, one wished that his period should never end.
('29', 4, 3, 8, 8645) The topic was the same as well as the students.
('29', 4, 3, 9, 8693) Instruction by one, however, was absorbing and by the other insipid.
('29', 4, 3, 10, 8762) The spinning wheel holds a jar of nectar.
('29', 4, 3, 11, 8804) In the Dakshinamurti Bhavan, it appears, there are teachers who can reveal this.
('29', 4, 3, 12, 8885) [From Gujarati]
('29', 4, 4, 13, 8901) Navajivan, 17 8 1924
('29', 4, 5, 14, 8922) 5. MY NOTES
('29', 4, 6, 15, 8934) MAULANA SHAUKAT ALI IN KATHIAWAR
('29', 4, 7, 16, 8967) Maulana Shaukat Ali 2 wired from Delhi that he, along with his companions, will start on a tour of Kathiawar and reach Rajkot on the 18th.
('29', 4, 7, 17, 9106) the Khilafat Committees and other societies or associations who wish to invite him should write to him in time to the Rajkot address to enable him to fix engagements.
('29', 4, 7, 18, 9273) I am confident that Maulana Shaukat Ali and his companions will be welcomed by Hindus as well as Muslims everywhere during their tour of Kathiawar.
('29', 4, 8, 19, 9421) UTILITY OF “TAKLI” 3
('29', 4, 9, 20, 9442) This 4 is only one Of many experiences.
('29', 4, 9, 21, 9482) This is just the beginning for takli.
('29', 4, 9, 22, 9520) It has already been reported that the takli can spin
('29', 4, 10, 23, 9573) 1 Not translated here 2 Along with his brother, Mahomed Ali took a leading part in the Khilafat Movement.

('29', 5, 1, 2, 9796) up to 70 yards of yarn in an hour.
('29', 5, 1, 3, 9831) The spinning wheel can of course spin much more.
('29', 5, 1, 4, 9880) But it is not proper to compare the takli with the wheel.
('29', 5, 1, 5, 9938) A takli can be plied if you are unoccupied even for five minutes.
('29', 5, 1, 6, 10004) The Congress has exempted members from spinning during travel because the spinning wheel cannot be plied in trains.
('29', 5, 1, 7, 10120) If I had been aware of the utility of the takli then, the exemption during travel would not have been made.
('29', 5, 1, 8, 10228) Onthe whole, the takli may be more useful than the wheel to one on a journey or otherwise busy, wanting to spin.
('29', 5, 1, 9, 10341) The takli is an inexpensive spinning tool which can supplement if not replace the wheel.
('29', 5, 1, 10, 10430) Moreover, if a takli is made out of a bit of tile, it would cost nothing at all.
('29', 5, 2, 11, 10511) PUNISHMENT IN NATIONAL SCHOOLS
('29', 5, 3, 12, 10542) A gentleman writes that I have got many resolutions passed in the teachers’ conference; that the teachers assented to all those resolutions half heartedly in order to humour me; that it would be lucky if even one of them were implemented; and that I forgot to pass a resolution about punishment of students in national schools.
('29', 5, 4, 13, 10870) I hope the resolutions in the teachers’ conference were adopted not merely to humour me but with the idea of implementing them.
('29', 5, 4, 14, 10998) I have no doubts like those expressed by this brother.
('29', 5, 4, 15, 11053) I have presumed that national schools shun physical punishments.
('29', 5, 4, 16, 11118) If this were not so, some teachers would have raised a discussion.
('29', 5, 4, 17, 11185) The other possibility is that punishment is too common to surprise anyone.
('29', 5, 4, 18, 11260) I am not prepared to imagine this possibility.
('29', 5, 4, 19, 11307) I hope that the correspondent will have noticed only a few instances.
('29', 5, 4, 20, 11377) Those teachers who punish their students are not teachers but jailors.
('29', 5, 4, 21, 11448) The function of the teacher is to stimulate and attract the student and thus to help his advancement.
('29', 5, 4, 22, 11550) I take it that faith in the power of the rod in training a child has been discarded by now.
('29', 5, 4, 23, 11642) Thousands of teachers all over the world have seen that a child can be brought up better by patience than by punishment; the latter in fact only shows the teacher’s ignorance.
('29', 5, 4, 24, 11818) It is the job of the teacher to make every subject interesting.
('29', 5, 4, 25, 11882) A good teacher can make even a dry subject like Arithmetic interesting.
('29', 5, 5, 26, 11954) WERE THEY DEMONS?
('29', 5, 6, 27, 11972) A gentleman has condemned Ramachandra, Yudhishthira 1 and
('29', 5, 7, 28, 12030) 1 Eldest of the five Pandava brothers in the Mahabhrata
('29', 6, 0, 1, 12086) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 7
('29', 6, 1, 2, 12132) Nala 1 and wants me to defend them.
('29', 6, 1, 3, 12168) “Ramachandra made Sita go through the ordeal of fire and yet later abandoned her; Yudhishthira indulged in gambling and forfeited the right even to protect Draupadi; Nala cast aspersions on his wife and forsook her half naked in a dense forest.
('29', 6, 1, 4, 12413) Should we call these three persons men or demons.?”
('29', 6, 2, 5, 12465) This charge can only be answered by the poets or the virtuous heroines themselves.
('29', 6, 2, 6, 12548) I judged as a layman and to me all the three men appear worthy of reverence.
('29', 6, 2, 7, 12625) Rama’s story is extraordinary; but let us, for a moment, put the legendary Rama in line with the other two.
('29', 6, 2, 8, 12733) If the three women had not been the wives of such heroes, history would not have remembered them as virtuous heroines.
('29', 6, 2, 9, 12852) Damayanti never left chanting the name of Nala, Sita could not think of anyone in the world except Rama, and Draupadi, although indignant with Yudhishthira, would never move away from him.
('29', 6, 2, 10, 13041) If we could enter the innermost hearts of these three men when they wronged their virtuous wives, we would be consumed by the fire of anguish seething there.
('29', 6, 2, 11, 13199) Bhavabhuti 2 has given us a moving account of the misery experienced by Rama.
('29', 6, 2, 12, 13277) The five brothers, who tended Draupadi like a fresh flower, used to listen patiently to her angry words.
('29', 6, 2, 13, 13382) Nala was not himself when he did what he did.
('29', 6, 2, 14, 13428) Even the gods watched from the heavens Nala’s devotion to his wife when he sped away with Rituparna 3. For me at any rate the testimony of these three noble wives is enough evidence.
('29', 6, 2, 15, 13611) It is, however, true that the poets have depicted these three wives as more virtuous than their husbands.
('29', 6, 2, 16, 13717) Rama, Nala, Dharmaraj 4 would become insignificant without Sita, Damayanti, Draupadi.
('29', 6, 2, 17, 13803) The men are impulsive, their conscience is wayward and their devotion too is not undeviating; whereas the devotion of these heroines was steady like the lustre of a gem.
('29', 6, 2, 18, 13973) The patience of women far surpasses that of men.
('29', 6, 2, 19, 14022) Since forbearance is a mark of strength, these virtuous women were not weak but strong.
('29', 6, 2, 20, 14110) What is man’s courage before woman’s?
('29', 6, 2, 21, 14148) This weakness, however, is endemic to man as such, not particularly to Nala and the rest.
('29', 6, 2, 22, 14238) The poets have depicted these women as embodiments of endurance.
('29', 6, 2, 23, 14303) I do regard them as the pinnacle of virtue; but I cannot
('29', 6, 3, 24, 14360) 1 King of Nishadha and husband of Damayanti in the Mahabharata
('29', 6, 4, 25, 14423) 2 Eighth century Sanskrit poet and playwright 3 King of Ayodhya, whom Nala served as a trainer of horses and as an accomplished cook 4 Yudhishthira
('29', 7, 0, 1, 14571) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 7, 1, 2, 14611) look upon their noble husbands as demons.
('29', 7, 1, 3, 14653) Would not the fame of these women be sullied if we look on their husbands as demons?
('29', 7, 1, 4, 14738) A demonic spirit cannot stay by the side of a virtuous woman.
('29', 7, 1, 5, 14800) The husbands may well be considered inferior to their noble wives.
('29', 7, 1, 6, 14867) But the men and women belong to the same category—both are worthy of reverence.
('29', 7, 1, 7, 14947) I think it is equally wrong to regard everything old as despicable or as venerable.
('29', 7, 1, 8, 15031) We should not give up the ideal of woman’s duty while espousing the cause of her rights.
('29', 7, 1, 9, 15120) I see no need for criticizing our ancient heroes in order to champion women’s rights.
('29', 7, 2, 10, 15206) CONTEMPT FOR “ANTYAJAS”
('29', 7, 3, 11, 15230) Contempt for Antyajas is in evidence more in Kathiawar than in the rest of Gujarat.
('29', 7, 3, 12, 15314) Antyaja brothers hailing from Kathiawar bring such news and others confirm it.
('29', 7, 3, 13, 15393) A gentleman write that even now the Antyajas have to suffer the same humiliation in railway trains as before.
('29', 7, 3, 14, 15503) They are not allowed to be seated.
('29', 7, 3, 15, 15538) If they sit down, the other passengers keep at a distance, insult and abuse them.
('29', 7, 3, 16, 15620) Such contempt is taken as a part of religion since many who perpetrate it flaunt a tilak 1
('29', 7, 4, 17, 15711) on their fore heads.
('29', 7, 4, 18, 15732) This contempt is not due to any uncleanness because the Antyaja brother can help himself and enjoy respect if he resorts to a small white lie.
('29', 7, 4, 19, 15875) He has only to give out his caste as Thakore or Rathod.
('29', 7, 4, 20, 15931) Only those who speak the truth have to suffer indignities.
('29', 7, 4, 21, 15990) The Antyaja brothers who would not resort to untruth for the sake of momentary comfort are entitled to high praise.
('29', 7, 4, 22, 16106) They thus prove that they are more virtuous than their revilers.
('29', 7, 4, 23, 16171) If the railway officials are sympathetic, they can protect the poor Antyajas.
('29', 7, 4, 24, 16249) Not all the passengers have this contempt for the Antyajas.
('29', 7, 4, 25, 16309) Those who do not despise them should come forward as their protectors.
('29', 7, 4, 26, 16380) The Antyajas should gain the confidence that the presence of a person with a khadi cap is a sure guarantee of their protection.

('29', 8, 2, 5, 17144) DISTRESSING
('29', 8, 3, 6, 17156) A perusal of the following description 1 of Dholka tahsil will distress the reader.
('29', 8, 3, 7, 17240) To sell out all cotton and all food grains because they fetch a good price, is only buying trouble.
('29', 8, 3, 8, 17340) A man cannot keep the money raised in this way and he is left in the end with the dust with which he had started.
('29', 8, 3, 9, 17454) A man should retain at least his own requirements of cotton and food grains.
('29', 8, 4, 10, 17531) LACK OF FELLOW FEELING
('29', 8, 5, 11, 17554) Another picture of the same tahsil is given below 2
('29', 8, 6, 12, 17606) The whole tragedy lies in walking away.
('29', 8, 6, 13, 17646) We have not progressed beyond the family circle; that is why we cannot see our own good in what is good for our town.
('29', 8, 6, 14, 17764) We were not very much concerned with the distress of Malabar.
('29', 8, 6, 15, 17826) Mere preaching is the least effective in creating family ties among citizens.
('29', 8, 6, 16, 17904) The effort may well start with preaching; but that is not enough.
('29', 8, 6, 17, 17970) A tree does not take shape merely by our sowing a seed.
('29', 8, 6, 18, 18026) It needs water and nurture and when it is just a sapling, it needs a fence.
('29', 8, 6, 19, 18102) Without this, the whole effort may go waste.
('29', 8, 6, 20, 18147) So with preaching too.
('29', 8, 6, 21, 18170) We shall succeed only if we strive to strike root in one town and, through it, spread enlightenment to all other towns.
('29', 8, 6, 22, 18290) If our objective is merely to collect funds, then it would be another matter.
('29', 8, 6, 23, 18368) If, however, we wish to penetrate the hearts of people or to collect yarn from them, that can be achieved only by staying in the village.
('29', 8, 6, 24, 18506) We shall progress faster if, instead of complaining against the people, we look critically at the shortcomings in our own work.
('29', 8, 7, 25, 18634) FOREIGN V. SWADESHI SUGAR
('29', 8, 8, 26, 18660) A gentleman writes that I have not discussed in detail “which sugar may be considered pure and which foreign”.
('29', 8, 8, 27, 18771) It is not certain

('29', 9, 1, 6, 19359) Its nutrient value is very small.
('29', 9, 1, 7, 19393) Whatever sugar is necessary is available in sweet fruits.
('29', 9, 1, 8, 19451) Chewing sugarcane is the best way of taking in sugar.
('29', 9, 1, 9, 19505) When the season for sugarcane is at an end, one should use jaggery.
('29', 9, 1, 10, 19573) Nevertheless, if one cannot do without sugar, one should try to get swadeshi sugar and should risk the possibility of shopkeepers making spurious mixtures.
('29', 9, 2, 11, 19729) KHADI WORK IN KATHIAWAR
('29', 9, 3, 12, 19753) I have recently read the distressing report published by Mr. Amhurst in Vishwa Bharati about conditions in Kathiawar.
('29', 9, 3, 13, 19871) Therein he says that there is progressive erosion of land and consequent danger of famine in Kathiawar on account of the destruction of forests.
('29', 9, 3, 14, 20016) Since the area under pasture lands is decreasing, the once famous cattle are decaying.
('29', 9, 3, 15, 20103) The opening of factories in cities drains away the population from villages, and ultimately, the extinction of villages leads to the ruin of cities also.
('29', 9, 3, 16, 20257) These Changes will sap the artistic qualities of Kathiawar.
('29', 9, 3, 17, 20317) This is almost a prophecy.
('29', 9, 3, 18, 20344) It applies to India as much as to Kathiawar.
('29', 9, 3, 19, 20389) The latter being a very small peninsula, it can even now be protected; that is why Mr. Amhurst could grasp the past and the future during the present transition.
('29', 9, 3, 20, 20551) I have often stated that modern industrialism can prosper only in those countries which import raw materials from outside, or in other words, an industrial country can only prosper at the expense of another country.
('29', 9, 3, 21, 20767) India does not feed on any other country.
('29', 9, 3, 22, 20809) She herself is the prey of other countries, namely, England, etc.
('29', 9, 3, 23, 20875) If our cities too start preying like these coun tries, then the poor villager will have to suffer double exploitation.
('29', 9, 3, 24, 20994) Kathiawar can save itself to some extent from this awful situation.
('29', 9, 3, 25, 21062) Trees should be planted and grown in every compound, the area under pasture should be increased and the craze for mills and ginning factories should be reduced.
('29', 9, 3, 26, 21223) It does not need much mathematics to see that too many mills and ginning factories in a very small region are an unbearable burden on the people.
('29', 9, 3, 27, 21369) If the princes and their ministers think calmly and unselfishly, they will realize that their sustenance depends upon the welfare of the villagers which requires the fulfilment of two conditions.
('29', 9, 3, 28, 21565) Their farms should be prosperous and they should have some employment for their idle
('29', 10, 0, 1, 21650) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 11
('29', 10, 1, 2, 21697) This industry, being based entirely on cotton, is operated in the villagers’ cottage.
('29', 10, 1, 3, 21783) The spinning wheel is its centre.
('29', 10, 1, 4, 21817) One who sustains the wheel, sustains the people.
('29', 10, 1, 5, 21866) The spread of foreign or mill made cloth should not be tolerated in Kathiawar.
('29', 10, 2, 6, 21945) KHADI ASSOCIATION AT AMRELI
('29', 10, 3, 7, 21973) I wish as well as hope that Kathiawar will participate in the current efforts to popularize spinning.
('29', 10, 3, 8, 22075) I therefore welcome the journal issued by the Khadi Association at Amreli; whoever wants to learn the processes or whoever wants to pay his contribution to the Congress in yarn, will find in the journal information regarding many facilities available to him.
('29', 10, 3, 9, 22334) Training is also available to those who want to learn the processes.
('29', 10, 3, 10, 22403) I hope many brothers and sisters from Kathiawar will benefit from these facilities.
('29', 10, 3, 11, 22487) It is necessary to remember that the object of the Congress resolution was to make the middle classes spin religiously.
('29', 10, 3, 12, 22607) If this effort succeeds, the cult of spinning will be revived and the hungry stomachs of the poor will be filled.
('29', 10, 3, 13, 22721) Before the spinning wheel finds a place in every home, faith in its power has to be inspired.
('29', 10, 3, 14, 22815) This can be done if the middle classes accept the spinning wheel as a sacrament; popularization of khadi is as imperative as the spread of the spinning wheel.
('29', 10, 3, 15, 22974) The day when khadi sells as easily as ghee, we may presume that there will be no more starvation deaths in India.
('29', 10, 3, 16, 23088) I wish that Kathiawar will play its full part in this divine sacrifice.
('29', 10, 3, 17, 23160) The wonderful thing about this sacrifice is that one who performs it reaps his fruit immediately.
('29', 10, 3, 18, 23258) If 2.6 million Kathiawaris put in labour worth one rupee on an average, they can save 2.6 million rupees every year.
('29', 10, 3, 19, 23375) I would advise the workers of the Khadi Association not to be the least disheartened about their work.
('29', 10, 3, 20, 23478) Doubt and despondency seem to be taking root in the land these days.
('29', 10, 3, 21, 23547) At the slightest sign of determination, the clouds of despondency will disperse.

('29', 11, 1, 2, 23706) 6. FOR GANDHIJI OR FOR THE COUNTRY
('29', 11, 2, 3, 23741) A friend says that currently it has become a vogue insistently to ask the students, in the name of Gandhiji, to take up spinning.

('29', 12, 4, 5, 25572) TO THE TRAFFIC SUPERINTENDENT AJMER
('29', 12, 5, 6, 25608) SIR, I travelled 2nd class on Saturday last the I6th instant from Ahmedabad to Delhi.
('29', 12, 5, 7, 25694) I had three third class attendants with me, of whom one, by permission of the Deputy Station Master, Ahmedabad, and under medical certificate, remained with me in the compartment.
('29', 12, 5, 8, 25874) Two years ago before I was imprisoned I used to travel similarly on your as well as other Indian lines.
('29', 12, 5, 9, 25978) Objection was once raised by a G.I.P. 1 Ticket Examiner.
('29', 12, 5, 10, 26035) Till then I did not carry a medical certificate, as my delicate health I showed on my person.
('29', 12, 5, 11, 26129) But on the G.I.P. Traffic Superintendent drawing my attention to the rule under which attendants with lower class tickets were allowed to travel with higher class invalid, I began to carry a medical certificate.
('29', 12, 5, 12, 26341) This time too, therefore, I produced to the Station authorities at Ahmedabad a medical certificate, copy of which is enclosed herewith.
('29', 12, 6, 13, 26477) On alighting at Delhi Station on the 17th instant, the Ticket Collector, having been advised that an attendant with a third class ticket had travelled with me demanded excess fare and penalty.
('29', 12, 6, 14, 26670) One of my attendants explained to the Deputy Superintendent the circumstances under which he travelled second class with me, offered to produce the medical certificate and to read him the rule (copy of which he had taken from the Coaching Tariff, Part I, para 69) permitting passengers to carry an attendant with a lower class ticket.
('29', 12, 6, 15, 27005) I am told he would not even look at these, and the Station Superintendent, who was sought to be approached through the Deputy Superintendent, would not even see my attendant.
('29', 12, 6, 16, 27180) I regard these acts as highly impolite.
('29', 12, 6, 17, 27220) The attendant in order to avoid any dispute paid Rs. 23 under protest.
('29', 12, 6, 18, 27291) I enclose receipt therefor, and now beg to apply

('29', 13, 7, 8, 27623) DELHI, August 18, 1924 1
('29', 13, 8, 9, 27648) RAMDAS, I have been constantly thinking of you on the way and here.
('29', 13, 8, 10, 27716) I have been pondering how your mind may be set at rest.
('29', 13, 8, 11, 27772) But no one can bring peace to another.
('29', 13, 8, 12, 27811) One can only help to a certain degree.
('29', 13, 8, 13, 27850) For the rest, one can find satisfaction only within oneself.
('29', 13, 8, 14, 27911) 2 Further, “The mind alone is the cause of bondage or freedom for man” and “the mind is its own place.
('29', 13, 8, 15, 28014) It can make a hell of heaven and a heaven of hell.” 3
('29', 13, 9, 16, 28068) Thus have sung various seers and it is true.
('29', 13, 9, 17, 28113) You too must find solace by following this rule.
('29', 13, 9, 18, 28162) You will.
('29', 13, 9, 19, 28172) Be patient in the meantime, “Make merry today, who knows of the morrow” sang Mirabai when confronted by sorrows.
('29', 13, 9, 20, 28285) An atheist would take it in its gross meaning and would be tempted to indulge in physical pleasures.
('29', 13, 9, 21, 28386) A devotee like Mira would find merriment only in devotion to God, in the path of service and in innocent joy.
('29', 13, 9, 22, 28496) If there is God, worrying about Time is His concern.
('29', 13, 9, 23, 28549) Why should we worry about it?
('29', 13, 9, 24, 28579) Let us do what we have got to do with devotion to God.
('29', 13, 9, 25, 28634) I shall reach there by the metre gauge train by Saturday afternoon if not earlier.
('29', 13, 9, 26, 28717) Be happy in the meantime.
('29', 13, 10, 27, 28743) Blessings from
('29', 13, 12, 28, 28758) 1 From the postmark 2Bhagavad Gita, II, 55

('29', 13, 13, 30, 28904) Can make a heav’n of hell, a hell of heav’n.”

('29', 15, 2, 24, 32226) THE ALI BROTHERS’ QUOTA
('29', 15, 3, 25, 32250) The Big Brother made a mighty effort but succeeded in sending only one tola of indifferently spun yarn.
('29', 15, 3, 26, 32354) If there was no fear of the reader accusing me of partiality towards the Brothers, I would say that this is not a bad record for one who is constitutionally ill fitted for continuous spinning and who is always on the move.

('29', 15, 4, 31, 32849) The history of my spinning is this.
('29', 15, 4, 32, 32885) Never had I spun a yard of yarn in all my life, but after Ahmedabad I was determined to commence it the moment I settled down at Delhi.
('29', 15, 4, 33, 33021) Continuous travelling was followed by illness, but on the 2nd August I sat down at long last to spin.

('29', 15, 4, 35, 33218) But some of it was spun by my wife who acted as my tutor and afterwards also by Arif Hasvi who also taught me a little.
('29', 15, 4, 36, 33338) On the 4th I spun the third skein but

('29', 17, 4, 19, 37338) NATAL INDIANS
('29', 17, 5, 20, 37352) It is a pathetic cable from the Natal Indians protesting against the passing of the ordinance disenfranchising Natal Indians from voting at municipal elections.
('29', 17, 5, 21, 37513) This fight commenced in 1894. It was finally decided in favour of the Indian settlers.
('29', 17, 5, 22, 37600) The then Natal Government admitted that it would be most unjust to deprive the Indian tax payer of the municipal franchise.
('29', 17, 5, 23, 37724) The Indian settler submitted to the virtual deprivation of the political franchise.
('29', 17, 5, 24, 37808) But no past promises or undertakings bind governments when they wish to change policies or principles.
('29', 17, 5, 25, 37911) We have seen this illustrated often enough in the history of Indians in South Africa.
('29', 17, 5, 26, 37997) Almost every assurance given to them has been violated on due occasion.
('29', 17, 5, 27, 38069) Our bewildered countrymen make a pathetic appeal to the nation for help.
('29', 17, 5, 28, 38142) Little do they know that we are powerless to give them real assistance.
('29', 17, 5, 29, 38214) Sympathy they have.
('29', 17, 5, 30, 38234) Newspaper articles they will have, but I fear that beyond that they are likely to get very little.
('29', 17, 5, 31, 38333) If the Government of
('29', 18, 0, 1, 38354) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 19
('29', 18, 1, 2, 38401) India move, for very shame, to protect them against impending spoliation, it can do so with effect.
('29', 18, 1, 3, 38501) I say “impending”, for the ordinance requires the sanction of the Governor General of the Union of South Africa.
('29', 18, 1, 4, 38614) He has once refused to sanction such an ordinance.
('29', 18, 1, 5, 38665) If he exercises his prerogative, he can save the Indians the insult that the ordinance implies.
('29', 18, 1, 6, 38761) Every letter received by me from South Africa during Mrs. Naidu’s 1 stay there showed the high hopes our people built on the brilliant mission of Mrs. Naidu.
('29', 18, 1, 7, 38919) But the South African Europeans can be courteous and yet carry out their determination, though it may be, as this is, totally unjust.
('29', 18, 1, 8, 39053) They have learnt under General Smuts 2 the art of being sweetly unjust.
('29', 18, 1, 9, 39125) The ultimate remedy lies with our countrymen themselves.
('29', 18, 2, 10, 39182) KENYA DECISION
('29', 18, 3, 11, 39197) The Colonial Secretary’s announcement about the Kenya Indians is an artful performance.
('29', 18, 3, 12, 39285) It reads perfectly innocent.
('29', 18, 3, 13, 39314) But it has practically taken away everything that our countrymen of Kenya were fighting for.

('29', 19, 1, 2, 40873) 12. BOLSHEVISM OR DISCIPLINE?
('29', 19, 2, 3, 40903) Two American friends have written to me a passionately worded letter saying that in the name of religion I am probably introducing in India Bolshevism which knows no God or morality and is frankly atheistic.
('29', 19, 2, 4, 41111) They say that the alliance between Mussulmans and myself is an unholy alliance and a menace to the world, for, they argue, Mussalmans are today aiming at supremacy in the East with the help of Bolshevic Russia.
('29', 19, 2, 5, 41322) I have heard this charge hurled against me before now, but I have hitherto taken no notice of it.
('29', 19, 2, 6, 41420) But it seems to me it is time for me to consider it when it is brought by responsible foreign friends in all good faith.
('29', 19, 2, 7, 41541) In the first placeI must confess that I do not know the meaning of Bolshevism.
('29', 19, 2, 8, 41620) I know that there are two opposite parties, one painting it in the blackest colours, the other hailing it as deliverance for the down trodden masses all the world over.
('29', 19, 2, 9, 41789) I do not know what to believe.
('29', 19, 2, 10, 41820) All I can say is that my movement is not atheistic.
('29', 19, 2, 11, 41872) It is not a denial of God.
('29', 19, 2, 12, 41899) It has been undertaken in His name and is being continued with constant prayer.
('29', 19, 2, 13, 41979) It is undoubtedly a mass movement but it seeks to touch the masses through their hearts, their better nature.
('29', 19, 2, 14, 42089) It is a process of discipline and hence it is that it has filled even some of the best of my co workers with despair.
('29', 19, 2, 15, 42207) I am proud of the alliance between the Mussalmans and myself.
('29', 19, 2, 16, 42269) Islam is not a denial of God.
('29', 19, 2, 17, 42299) It is a passionate avowal of one supreme deity.
('29', 19, 2, 18, 42347) Not even its worst detractors have accused Islam of atheism.
('29', 19, 2, 19, 42408) If therefore Bolshevism is atheism, there can be no common ground between it and Islam.
('29', 19, 2, 20, 42496) They must in that case come to death grip.
('29', 19, 2, 21, 42539) It will be an embrace of opponents, not of friends.
('29', 19, 2, 22, 42591) I have retained the American letter phraseology.
('29', 19, 2, 23, 42640) But let me inform my American readers and others that I am under no delusion.
('29', 19, 2, 24, 42718) My pretension is very humble.
('29', 19, 2, 25, 42748) The alliance there is between the Ali Brothers and myself, i.e., between a few valued Mussualman friends and myself.
('29', 19, 2, 26, 42865) I would love to call it an alliance between Mussalmans and Hindus—not myself.
('29', 19, 2, 27, 42943) But that seems to have been a day dream.
('29', 19, 2, 28, 42984) In truth therefore one may say, there is an alliance between some Mussalmans including the Ali

('29', 21, 1, 2, 45538) 13. WASTE OF ENERGY?
('29', 21, 2, 3, 45559) A friend has invited my attention to an article in the Welfare of May last which is an examination by Mr. M. N. Roy 1 of Acharya Ray’s 2 address at the opening of the khaddar exhibition at Cocanada.
('29', 21, 2, 4, 45758) The copy has been lying among my papers for fully two months.
('29', 21, 2, 5, 45820) I am sorry that I have not been able to read the article before now.
('29', 21, 2, 6, 45889) Having read it I feel that Mr. Roy’s refutation of Dr. Ray’s contentions has been often refuted in these pages.
('29', 21, 2, 7, 46001) But as readers have short memories, it is perhaps as well for me to re state the arguments in a connected form.
('29', 21, 2, 8, 46113) Dr. Ray’s critic considers that all the effort made on behalf of the charkha is “a waste of energy”.
('29', 21, 2, 9, 46214) The central point in Dr. Ray’s argument is that the charkha has a message specially for the peasant in that it enables him to utilize his idle hours.
('29', 21, 2, 10, 46364) The critic contends that the peasant has not any idle hours to utilize.
('29', 21, 2, 11, 46436) What leisure he has, he needs.
('29', 21, 2, 12, 46467) If he is idle for four months, it is because he has over worked himself for eight months and that if he is made to work the four months at the wheel, his efficiency for eight months’ work will deteriorate from year to year.
('29', 21, 2, 13, 46691) In other words, according to the critic, the nation has no leisure for the charkha.
('29', 21, 2, 14, 46775) It appears to me that the critic has little if any experience of the peasantry of India.
('29', 21, 2, 15, 46864) Nor has he been able to picture to himself the way the charkha would work, and indeed is working today.
('29', 21, 2, 16, 46968) The peasantry does not need to slave at the charkha.
('29', 21, 2, 17, 47021) It affords a pleasant variety and recreation after hard toil.
('29', 21, 2, 18, 47083) As a permanent institution, it is presented to the women of India.
('29', 21, 2, 19, 47150) They will spin during odd moments.
('29', 21, 2, 20, 47185) If the majority of the toilers were to give on an average half an hour per day they would spin enough yarn for themselves and to spare for the rest.
('29', 21, 2, 21, 47334) Such worker would add to his or her income at least Rs. 1 11 0 per year—not a bad addition to the income of a starving person.
('29', 21, 2, 22, 47461) It is admitted that there are enough handlooms and weavers today in India to weave all the cloth we may require.
('29', 21, 2, 23, 47574) The only question is therefore that of hand spinning.
('29', 21, 2, 24, 47628) If the peasantry would take to it, the problem could be solved without any great outlay of capital, of India becoming self supporting for her cloth.
('29', 21, 2, 25, 47777) This would mean at least sixty million

('29', 22, 1, 2, 47972) rupees circulating among the millions of spinners and thousands of carders and weavers of India working in their own cottages and to that extent raising the earning capacity of the peasantry.
('29', 22, 1, 3, 48164) It is the experience all the world over that peasants need a subsidiary occupation to supplement their earnings or occupy their leisure hours.
('29', 22, 1, 4, 48307) It must not be forgotten that not very long ago India’s women spun during spare hours all the yarn it required.

('29', 23, 1, 3, 50531) The difficulties in the way are want of faith among the middle classes which alone can supply the required number of workers.

('29', 23, 1, 15, 52022) If one man or woman spins for a few pice, when he or she has no other occupation, it is so much gain; if one man or woman spins as a sacrifice, it is also so much gain.
('29', 23, 1, 16, 52191) If there is one activity in which it is all gain and no loss, it is hand spinning.

('29', 24, 1, 2, 52344) 14. UNDER CONSCIENCE’S COVER
('29', 24, 2, 3, 52373) A correspondent says in effect : Do you know what you have done by continually harping on conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 4, 52475) I find youngsters and grown up people talking utter nonsense under cover of conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 5, 52563) What is more, youngsters have become impudent and grown up people unscrupulous; can you not prevent this mischief?
('29', 24, 2, 6, 52678) If you cannot, please withdraw the word from use and stop the drivel that is being said in the name of that sacred but much abused word.
('29', 24, 2, 7, 52815) Pray tell us who has a conscience?
('29', 24, 2, 8, 52850) Do all have it?
('29', 24, 2, 9, 52866) Do cats have a conscience when they hunt to death poor mice?
('29', 24, 2, 10, 52927) I have not given the correspondent’s question in his own words.
('29', 24, 2, 11, 52991) I have endeavoured to paraphrase it.
('29', 24, 2, 12, 53028) In doing so I hope I have done no injustice to him.
('29', 24, 2, 13, 53080) I must confess that the charge is not without substance.
('29', 24, 2, 14, 53137) But he has presented only the dark side.
('29', 24, 2, 15, 53178) Every virtue has been known to be abused by the wicked.
('29', 24, 2, 16, 53234) But we do not on that account do away with virtue.
('29', 24, 2, 17, 53285) We can but erect safeguards against abuse.
('29', 24, 2, 18, 53328) When people cease to think for themselves and have everything regulated for them, it becomes necessary at times to assert the right of individuals to act in defiance of public opinion or law which is another name for public opinion.
('29', 24, 2, 19, 53561) When individuals so act, they claim to have acted in obedience to their conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 20, 53645) I entirely agree with the correspondent that youngsters as a rule must not pretend to have conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 21, 53748) It is a quality or state acquired by laborious training.
('29', 24, 2, 22, 53805) Wilfulness is not conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 23, 53835) A child has no conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 24, 53862) The correspondent’s cat does not go for the mouse in obedience to the call of conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 25, 53952) It does so in obedience to its nature.
('29', 24, 2, 26, 53991) Conscience is the ripe fruit of strictest discipline.
('29', 24, 2, 27, 54045) Irresponsible youngsters therefore who have never obeyed anything or anybody save their animal instinct have no conscience, nor therefore have all grown up people.
('29', 24, 2, 28, 54209) The savages for instance have to all intents and purposes no conscience.
('29', 24, 2, 29, 54282) Conscience can reside only in a delicately tuned breast.
('29', 24, 2, 30, 54339) There is no such thing therefore as mass conscience as distinguished from the consciences of individuals.
('29', 24, 2, 31, 54445) It is safe therefore to say that when a man makes everything a matter of conscience, he is a stranger to it.
('29', 24, 2, 32, 54554) It is a truthful saying that “conscience makes cowards of us all”.
('29', 24, 2, 33, 54621) A conscientious man hesitates
('29', 25, 0, 1, 54651) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 25, 1, 2, 54692) to assert himself, he is always humble, never boisterous, always compromising, always ready to listen, ever willing, even anxious to admit mistakes.
('29', 25, 1, 3, 54841) The correspondent is needlessly agitated.
('29', 25, 1, 4, 54883) What does it matter that fifty thousand people say they act or refrain for conscience’s s ake?
('29', 25, 1, 5, 54978) The world has no difficulty in distinguishing between conscience and an arrogant or ignorant assumption of it.
('29', 25, 1, 6, 55089) Such men would have acted in similar circumstances exactly as they would under cover of conscience.
('29', 25, 1, 7, 55189) The introduction of conscience into our public life is welcome even if it has taught a few of us to stand up for human dignity and rights in the face of the heaviest odds.
('29', 25, 1, 8, 55361) These acts will live for ever, whereas those done under shams are like soap bubbles enjoying a momentary existence.

('29', 28, 1, 2, 60969) 17. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('29', 28, 2, 3, 60995) Sravana Krishna 7 [August 21, 1924 1]
('29', 28, 3, 4, 61033) DEAR SHRI GHANSHYAMDAS 2, God has provided me with conscience keepers.
('29', 28, 3, 5, 61104) You, I think, are one of them.
('29', 28, 3, 6, 61135) Some of my own children, some ladies and a few grown ups like Jamnalalji 3 and yourself want to make me a perfect man.
('29', 28, 3, 7, 61254) Regarding you thus, how could I be offended by your letter?
('29', 28, 3, 8, 61314) In fact, I want you always to caution me in this manner.
('29', 28, 3, 9, 61371) You complain against three things: One, my absolving the Swaraj Party of the charge of corruption; two, my giving a testimonial to Suhrawardy; and, three, my trying to get Sarojini Devi elected as [Congress] President.
('29', 28, 3, 10, 61590) In the first place, it is one’s duty to say only that which, after a pains taking inquiry, one has come to regard as the truth, even if the world considers it to be an error.
('29', 28, 3, 11, 61765) In no other way can one become fearless.
('29', 28, 3, 12, 61806) I cannot consider anything dearer to me than moksha 4. Yet even that moksha I would renounce if it were to conflict with truth and non violence.
('29', 28, 3, 13, 61951) In all these three things I only followed truth.
('29', 28, 3, 14, 62000) When I said that, I had in mind what you had told me at Juhu.
('29', 28, 3, 15, 62062) In the absence of any definite proof, it becomes my duty to treat the Swaraj Party as free from the guilt imputed to it.
('29', 28, 3, 16, 62183) If there is any evidence that you can furnish I shall certainly examine it.
('29', 28, 3, 17, 62259) I shall even make it public if you will allow me to do so; if not I shall know and keep it to myself and remain silent.
('29', 28, 3, 18, 62379) As for Suhrawardy, I only testified to his sagacity and I am having practical experience of it even now.
('29', 28, 3, 19, 62484) About Sarojini Devi your fears are, I think, uncalled for.
('29', 28, 3, 20, 62543) I hold strongly that she has served India well and is still doing so.
('29', 28, 3, 21, 62613) While I have done nothing so far for her presidentship, I do believe that if the others who have so far occupied that office were fit for it, she too is fit.
('29', 28, 3, 22, 62771) Everybody is charmed with her enthusiasm.
('29', 28, 3, 23, 62813) I can bear witness to her courage.
('29', 28, 3, 24, 62848) I have noticed nothing blame worthy in her character.

('29', 30, 4, 6, 65026) he said that negotiations were still going on between Hindus and Mussalmans for a compromise and the situation was as hopeful as ever.

('29', 32, 1, 2, 67632) 23. SPEECH AT LABOURERS’ MEETING, AHMEDABAD
('29', 32, 2, 3, 67676) August 23, 1924
('29', 32, 3, 4, 67692) About 5,000 labourers assembled on the river bed outside Shahpur Gate, Ahmedabad City, on August 23 to present a purse of Rs. 3,000 to M. K. Gandhi.
('29', 32, 3, 5, 67841) The Secretary of the Union, Gulzarilal Nanda, described the help that the Mahatma had so often given to the labourers of Ahmedabad.
('29', 32, 4, 6, 67973) Gandhi asked the labourers if they had any complaints to make to him.
('29', 32, 4, 7, 68043) Various questions regarding the internal economy of the Union were brought up.
('29', 32, 4, 8, 68122) Gandhi urged them to be self reliant and to control their own institutions.
('29', 32, 4, 9, 68198) They were the masters of the Union.
('29', 32, 4, 10, 68234) They should appoint such officials as would serve their ends honestly, be they Hindus or Mohammedans.
('29', 32, 4, 11, 68336) He also urged them to use khaddar.
('29', 32, 5, 12, 68371) Bombay Secret Abstracts, 1924, p.

('29', 35, 2, 4, 73526) 25. MY NOTES
('29', 35, 3, 5, 73539) BARREN PARLIAMENT
('29', 35, 4, 6, 73557) A journalist has made these remarks: 1
('29', 35, 5, 7, 73596) Parliament is indeed barren.
('29', 35, 5, 8, 73625) I do not imagine that its nature can change in India.
('29', 35, 5, 9, 73679) I live, however, in the hope that our Parliament will only remain barren and not give birth to a wicked son.
('29', 35, 5, 10, 73788) I cannot abandon practical considerations.
('29', 35, 5, 11, 73831) The ideal is one only, namely, Ramarajya.
('29', 35, 5, 12, 73873) But where can we find Rama?
('29', 35, 5, 13, 73901) The journalist says, “whom the people approve.” People means Parliament and, in our view, whomsoever the Parliament approves is a virtuous man or woman.
('29', 35, 5, 14, 74054) I am suggesting many ways to ensure that the voice of Parliament is really the voice of the people and not that of hired voters.
('29', 35, 5, 15, 74183) With this end in view I am searching for a device which will enable us to listen to the voice of the entire people.
('29', 35, 5, 16, 74299) All systems are bound to be defective.
('29', 35, 5, 17, 74338) We are looking for a system which will yield maximum benefit to India.
('29', 35, 5, 18, 74409) Good men can transform a bad system into a good one—like the wise housewife who transforms dust into grains.
('29', 35, 5, 19, 74518) Wicked men can misuse the best of systems and make it defective, like a foolish housewife who allows bright food grains to decay into dust.
('29', 35, 5, 20, 74658) I am therefore on the look out for good men in India and employing devices to sort out such men.
('29', 35, 5, 21, 74755) But what can a man do?
('29', 35, 5, 22, 74778) He can only make an honest effort.
('29', 35, 5, 23, 74813) The fruit lies in the hands of God.
('29', 35, 5, 24, 74849) The efforts of many, and not one, are required for securing the desired fruit.
('29', 35, 5, 25, 74928) Many other factors determine the fruit.
('29', 35, 5, 26, 74968) Therefore “one step is enough” for us.
('29', 35, 6, 27, 75007) INNER VOICE

('29', 35, 8, 29, 75047) All this criticism is true; but these errors are unavoidable.

('29', 36, 2, 26, 76940) 26. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI

('29', 36, 4, 28, 77000) MY DEAR RAJAGOPALACHARI 1, Mahadev has shown me your letter to him.

('29', 40, 10, 16, 83079) The following rendering of Mr. Gandhi’s speech in reply to the address of the
('29', 40, 11, 17, 83157) Ahmedabad Municipality is given here as being of general interest: Whilst I thank you for the beautiful address you have presented to me, I am painfully conscious of the fact that as a citizen of Ahmedabad I am utterly undeserving of it.
('29', 40, 11, 18, 83395) In saying so I am not using the language of false or undue modesty.
('29', 40, 11, 19, 83463) A citizen to deserve an address from the Municipality of his city shouldhave special citizen service to his credit.
('29', 40, 11, 20, 83579) And I have none.
('29', 40, 11, 21, 83596) I do not think it was at all necessary for you to vote this address for the services you have had in mind.
('29', 40, 11, 22, 83703) But I know that I owe the address to the fact of many of you
('29', 40, 12, 23, 83764) 1 Vide “Letter to G. D. Birla”, 22 8 1924.
('29', 40, 13, 24, 83807) 2 At the Municipal Hall; Vallabhbhai Patel read out the address.

('29', 41, 0, 1, 83907) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 41, 1, 2, 83948) being my co workers in another field and to the proverbial generosity of the nation to which you and I are proud to belong.
('29', 41, 2, 3, 84072) When in response to the invitation of some friends I fixed my abode in this city some years ago I thought I should contribute my share in the service of this city, and be worthy of calling myself its citizen.
('29', 41, 2, 4, 84281) I had not then the privilege of knowing many of you, but I shared my dreams and visions with Dr. Hariprasad whom I often met.
('29', 41, 2, 5, 84407) I used to tell him of the citizen service I had done in South Africa— service which I am thankful was true service inasmuch as it was silent and of which most of you know nothing—and I concerted measures for improving the sanitation and health of the city.
('29', 41, 2, 6, 84664) We had intended to form a committee of servants who would visit every nook and corner of the city in order to give the citizens object lessons in cleaning closets and streets and in general conservancy by doing the work ourselves.
('29', 41, 2, 7, 84895) We had also intended to plan and suggest measures for the expansion of the city by opening suburbs and inviting citizens to go and settle there rather than live in congested areas.
('29', 41, 2, 8, 85076) Such things we know could not be satisfactorily done by fresh taxation.
('29', 41, 2, 9, 85148) We therefore thought of going with the beggar’s bowl to the rich citizens and ask them to donate land in the heart of the city for opening little gardens for the children to play in.
('29', 41, 2, 10, 85331) We had intended too to think out schemes so as to afford the fullest facility for the education of every child of Ahmedabad.
('29', 41, 2, 11, 85456) It was also our intention to ensure a supply of pure and cheap milk by municipalizing all the city dairies.
('29', 41, 2, 12, 85564) Mr. Jivanlal Desai 1 even suggested that I should enter the Municipality myself and endeavour to carry out the plans above adumbrated.
('29', 41, 2, 13, 85699) But the fates willed it otherwise.
('29', 41, 2, 14, 85734) A huge hurricane blew over the country in the shape of the Rowlatt Bills taking us all within its sweep.
('29', 41, 2, 15, 85839) It took some lives both innocent and guilty.
('29', 41, 2, 16, 85884) I had to do penance for my Himalayan miscalculation.
('29', 41, 2, 17, 85937) 2 The hurricane still persists though in another shape.
('29', 41, 2, 18, 85993) We are all trying, however inadequately, to stop it.
('29', 41, 2, 19, 86046) And I at least feel I have not the leisure to Work out my schemes.
('29', 41, 2, 20, 86113) But why should Ipretend that I would have succeeded in carrying them out, had I entered the Municipality?
('29', 41, 2, 21, 86219) Why may I assume that none of your previous presidents or none of you thought or are thinkings the same
('29', 41, 3, 22, 86323) 1 Barrister; public worker of Ahmedabad; helped Gandhiji in establishing the Satyagraha Ashram in 1915 2 On April 14, 1919, Gandhiji decided to undergo a fast for three days; vide “Speech at Mass Meeting, Ahmedabad”, April 14, 1919.
('29', 42, 0, 1, 86556) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 43
('29', 42, 1, 2, 86603) things as I?
('29', 42, 1, 3, 86616) How dare I say that no efforts have been made in this direction?
('29', 42, 1, 4, 86681) I may only say that my heart weeps to see the misery, the squalour, and the dirt in the streets of Ahmedabad as I pass through them.
('29', 42, 1, 5, 86814) How can starvation and dirt be allowed to exist in a city of such riches and rich traditions?
('29', 42, 1, 6, 86908) But I may not pretend that I should have been able to remove all this, had I entered the Municipality.
('29', 42, 1, 7, 87011) Possibly humilation would have been in store for me in that field as it has been in others.

('29', 42, 1, 9, 87165) As it is, however, even today I stand in the humiliating position of having no citizen service to my credit, and yet stealing an address I do not deserve.
('29', 42, 1, 10, 87320) I pray that the Almighty may have consideration for my good intention and forgive my failings.

('29', 43, 7, 12, 88250) 33. NOTES
('29', 43, 8, 13, 88260) LORDS LYTTON’S EXPLANATION
('29', 43, 9, 14, 88287) Lord Lytton’s letter to the Poet in my opinion aggravates the insult, His Excellency seeks to explain away.
('29', 43, 9, 15, 88395) I hardly think that the fine grammatical distinction made by him in any way mends matters.
('29', 43, 9, 16, 88486) No one, I am sure, thought that His Excellency had the women of India in general in his mind when he uttered the indiscreet words.
('29', 43, 9, 17, 88617) The complaint is that he uttered the charge at all.
('29', 43, 9, 18, 88669) When a responsible person makes any charge, there is always a double presumption.
('29', 43, 9, 19, 88751) The one is that he has entirely satisfied himself about it and that he can prove it to the world.
('29', 43, 9, 20, 88849) The other is that the evil which is the subject matter of the charge is fairly general.
('29', 43, 9, 21, 88937) Apart from the police testimony, is His Excellency in a position to prove the charge to the satisfaction of the public, say to the satisfaction of the Poet?
('29', 43, 9, 22, 89094) Does he not know that the police are thoroughly distrusted by the public?
('29', 43, 9, 23, 89168) Does he not know that they are, so far as the public is concerned, as a rule in the defendant’s box?
('29', 43, 9, 24, 89269) Again assuming that the charge is true of some women and some men, is he in a position to prove that the evil is so general as to call for a public condemnation.
('29', 43, 9, 25, 89431) Will a responsible Indian be justified in saying that some English civilians are guilty, say, of
('29', 43, 10, 26, 89528) 1 The postmark bears the date August 28, 1924, in which year Shravan Vad 12 corresponded to August 27.
('29', 44, 0, 1, 89631) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 45
('29', 44, 1, 2, 89678) corruption and immorality, because to his knowledge a few rare cases have been so found?
('29', 44, 1, 3, 89767) Will he not be indignantly called upon to name the parties and take them to a court of law and also to apologize to the civilians for turning what was a charge against particular individuals into a charge against a body?
('29', 44, 1, 4, 89988) Will he be permitted to take shelter under the adjective, “some”?
('29', 44, 1, 5, 90054) If Lord Lytton never intended to say more than that Indians contain among them degraded specimens of humanity as every other nation, where was the occasion for his complaint in a serious speech when he knew that every word of his speech would be scanned here and have due weight abroad.
('29', 44, 1, 6, 90341) I cannot therefore help respectfully suggesting that if he did not mean to cast any aspersion on Indian womanhood and Indian manhood, he should unreservedly withdraw and apologize for the charge.
('29', 44, 1, 7, 90537) He will thereby add to his dignity and even prestige.
('29', 44, 1, 8, 90591) If on the other hand he has proofs of the kind I have suggested, he should bravely sustain the charge and place the proofs before the public.
('29', 44, 1, 9, 90733) A lame explanation is no explanation.
('29', 44, 1, 10, 90771) It adds injury to insult.
('29', 44, 2, 11, 90797) A BADGE OF SUBSERVIENCE
('29', 44, 3, 12, 90821) Every Indian publicist knows that when a duty was placed on cotton goods imported, an excise cotton duty was placed on Indian production solely in the interest of Lancashire and it still remains in spite of protests and in spite even of promise that it would be reconsidered.
('29', 44, 3, 13, 91097) This duty is a continuing reminder to us of the subordination of India’s interest to England’s.
('29', 44, 3, 14, 91193) Some friends who only know my strong, indeed passionate, preference for hand spun to the exclusion of mill spun cannot understand my advocacy of preference for Indian mill spun.
('29', 44, 3, 15, 91371) A little reflection must however show the consistency between the two policies.
('29', 44, 3, 16, 91451) Foreign cloth must be totally banished from the Indian market, if India is to become an economically free nation, if her peasantry is to be freed from chronic pauperism, if that peasantry is to find honourable employment during times of famine and such other visitations.
('29', 44, 3, 17, 91723) Protection of her staple industry is her birthright.
('29', 44, 3, 18, 91776) I would therefore protect the Indian mills against foreign competition even though for the time being it may result in mulcting the poor people.
('29', 44, 3, 19, 91921) Such mulcting can take place only if the mill owners be so unpatriotic as to raise prices owing to the monopoly they may secure.
('29', 44, 3, 20, 92050) I have therefore no hesitation in advocating the repeal of cotton excise duties and imposition of a prohibitive import duty.
('29', 45, 0, 1, 92175) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 45, 1, 2, 92216) Similarly and consistently I would protect hand spun khaddar against the home mills.
('29', 45, 1, 3, 92301) And I know that if only foreign competition is avoided, khaddar will be protected without difficulty.
('29', 45, 1, 4, 92403) Foreign cloth will be banished when public opinion becomes effectively powerful.
('29', 45, 1, 5, 92484) The same power will insure the protection of khaddar against mills.
('29', 45, 1, 6, 92552) But my strong belief is that khaddar will come to its own without any unseemly war with the mills.
('29', 45, 1, 7, 92651) But, whilst khaddar has only a limited number of votaries, they, the votaries, must necessarily preach khaddar in preference to and to the exclusion of yarn and cloth manufactured even in our mills.
('29', 45, 1, 8, 92850) To give the option is to kill khaddar.
('29', 45, 2, 9, 92889) MILL KHADI
('29', 45, 3, 10, 92900) But says the impatient patriot, “Surely you can have no corner for the mills in your heart when the mill owners do not hesitate even to palm off fraudulent imitations of khadi on the gullible public.” I know this imitation khadi.
('29', 45, 3, 11, 93130) I have purposely kept the precious samples in front of me in order to warn me of my duty not to be angry against the mill owners in question in spite of their unpatriotic conduct.
('29', 45, 3, 12, 93310) I know that they could have conducted their trade without entering into competition with khadi.
('29', 45, 3, 13, 93406) They could at least have refrained from miscalling their coarse cloth “khadi” when they well knew that “khadi” was a word used to signify hand spun cotton cloth.
('29', 45, 3, 14, 93568) But two Wrongs cannot make one right.
('29', 45, 3, 15, 93606) My satyagrahi spirit tells me that I may not retaliate.
('29', 45, 3, 16, 93662) I may not imitate their unpatriotic conduct.
('29', 45, 3, 17, 93707) I know that, if lovers of khadi remain true to their faith, hand spun khadi will thrive against all odds.
('29', 45, 3, 18, 93813) Non co operators must, therefore, irrespective of what some mills are wittingly or unwittingly doing to injure khadi, continue to advocate not only the repeal of cotton excise duty but advocate also full protection of that great industry.
('29', 45, 4, 19, 94052) INDIANS OVERSEAS
('29', 45, 5, 20, 94069) I offer no apology for printing several contributions at a time from Mr. Andrews.
('29', 45, 5, 21, 94151) They have all been received during the week.
('29', 45, 5, 22, 94196) They give an indication of his burning love for India and his impati ence of every wrong.
('29', 45, 5, 23, 94286) These contributions give at a glance an idea of the uphill work that lies in front of us in connection with these coun trymen of ours scattered in various parts of the world.
('29', 45, 5, 24, 94461) The Natal ordi nance that was forcing up its career even whilst Mrs. Naidu was in South Africa shows that we have to follow up her valuable work.
('29', 45, 5, 25, 94607) The betrayal both of the Africans and the Indians in Kenya makes the
('29', 46, 0, 1, 94676) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 47
('29', 46, 1, 2, 94723) wrong almost too prodigious for poor India to deal with.
('29', 46, 1, 3, 94780) The hideous immorality of the system under which our countrymen emigrate to Burma shows the necessity of eternal vigilance.
('29', 46, 1, 4, 94904) In the palmy days of my third class travelling, I was an eyewitness of what was then possible in the deck passenger traffic between Calcutta and Burma.
('29', 46, 1, 5, 95056) I then des cribed the conditions of deck passengers as inhuman.
('29', 46, 1, 6, 95120) I understood then that it was much worse between Madras and Rangoon.
('29', 46, 1, 7, 95189) The cause was the insatiable greed of the steamship company that permitted the filth and the degradation that went on with its knowledge and conniva nce.
('29', 46, 1, 8, 95343) It is difficult to distribute the blame, whether the Government that permits the company to conduct its service in utter neglect of the health and moral well being of deck passengers or the company that perpetrates the wrong or the passengers who for the sake of earning a living abroad are content to wallow in dirt both physical and moral are the greatest sinners.
('29', 46, 1, 9, 95710) Mr. Andrews says in a private letter that he hopes to see before long a decided improvement in the condition of the deck passenger traffic.
('29', 46, 1, 10, 95850) Let us hope that this good Englishman’s hope will be fulfilled.
('29', 46, 2, 11, 95914) PLEASE NOTE
('29', 46, 3, 12, 95926) The secretary, A.I.K.B., sends the following for the benefit of all concerned:
('29', 46, 4, 13, 96005) 1. Most of the members who sent in their yarn have not given their register numbers.
('29', 46, 4, 14, 96090) This may probably be due to the fact that the Provincial Khadi Boards have not been able to intimate each member of his register number.
('29', 46, 5, 15, 96227) 2. Added to the above is the difficulty of finding out the members’ names in registers where no alphabetical index is provided.
('29', 46, 5, 16, 96355) Few provinces have carried out the instruction in the matter of the index asked for.
('29', 46, 5, 17, 96440) Where members give no register numbers, the absence of an alphabetical index makes it well nigh impossible to proceed with the sorting.
('29', 46, 6, 18, 96576) 3. Members and non members have directly sent their yarn to this office contrary to instructions.
('29', 46, 6, 19, 96674) They should be told in future to send their contributions to the provinces whether members or non members.
('29', 46, 7, 20, 96781) 4. The length of the yarn in most cases is unmeasured.
('29', 46, 7, 21, 96836) The provincial secretary before despatching the parcel should see that every yarn contribution is properly labelled and described.

('29', 47, 3, 5, 97352) 34. GULBARGA GONE MAD
('29', 47, 4, 6, 97374) I hinted last week 1 that there was evidently an organization to the back of the mania for desecrating Hindu temples.
('29', 47, 4, 7, 97492) Gulbarga is the latest instance in point.

('29', 69, 7, 15, 144243) 50. SPEECH AT NATIONAL MEDICAL COLLEGE, BOMBAY
('29', 69, 8, 16, 144290) September 2, 1924
('29', 69, 9, 17, 144308) Mahatmaji in his short address expressed his great joy at seeing the National Medical College progressing so satisfactorily.
('29', 69, 9, 18, 144433) He said that when Dr. Sathaye first asked his advice about starting the institution he was rather diffident, as the task was so huge and beset with many difficulties.
('29', 69, 9, 19, 144600) But now he was pleased to see for himself that his fears were unfounded and that the institution had achieved such amarvellous success.
('29', 69, 9, 20, 144736) He expected that the leading men in the Medical profession would continue to give their support, and he also hoped that the rich men of Bombay would remove the housing difficulty of the College and also give money to support it.
('29', 69, 9, 21, 144965) In the end, he exhorted the students to wear khaddar and spin for half an hour as a national duty.
('29', 69, 9, 22, 145064) The Bombay Chronicle, 3 9 1924

('29', 71, 3, 4, 146912) SANTOK 2, What a sad occasion on which to write to you!
('29', 71, 3, 5, 146968) You must have received my telegram sent to your Rajkot address and you must all have returned to the Ashram.
('29', 71, 3, 6, 147077) Remember what you have learnt at the Ashram.
('29', 71, 3, 7, 147122) I hope you have not let a single tear flow from your eyes.
('29', 71, 3, 8, 147181) The world feel’s the grief of bereavement, but you should curb it, and realize the meaning of death.
('29', 71, 3, 9, 147282) He who has understood the second chapter of the Gita will not grieve over what is inevitable.
('29', 71, 3, 10, 147376) It is on such occasions that we should be guided by the teachings of the scriptures.
('29', 71, 3, 11, 147461) My relations with Shivlalbhai were intimate.
('29', 71, 3, 12, 147506) I respected him as my elder and on many matters I consulted him alone.
('29', 71, 3, 13, 147577) Our relations subsisted till the end.
('29', 71, 3, 14, 147615) They did not always find outward expression as the occasions for consultation were rare, but whenever we met we could read each other’s feelings in our eyes.
('29', 71, 3, 15, 147773) I have always known him as an honest banker.

('29', 71, 3, 21, 148090) This is not true.
('29', 71, 3, 22, 148108) She ought to write to me and tell me freely whatever she has on her mind.

('29', 72, 1, 2, 148596) 54. NEVER TO BE FORGOTTEN
('29', 72, 2, 3, 148622) Whilst I was listening to praises of me at the Excelsior Theatre in Bombay on Sunday last, 1 I felt that Mr. Bharucha had staged a play for the benefit of the distressed people in the South.
('29', 72, 2, 4, 148813) But an incident changed it into a serious business for me.
('29', 72, 2, 5, 148872) Mr. Bharucha had endeavoured to bring on the platform people belonging to different political parties.
('29', 72, 2, 6, 148975) He had therefore put up Mr. Jamnadas Dwarakadas as one of the speakers.
('29', 72, 2, 7, 149047) Mr. Jamnadas spoke of me as Gandhiji instead of ‘Mahatma’.
('29', 72, 2, 8, 149106) Two or three in the audience who could not brook the insult of my being called ‘Gandhiji’ required the speaker to call me ‘Mahatma’.
('29', 72, 2, 9, 149239) Mr. Jamnadas bravely but courteously persisted in calling me Gandhiji though, he said, he loved me no less than any in the audience.
('29', 72, 2, 10, 149372) He protested that his manner of addressing me was more pleasing to me.
('29', 72, 2, 11, 149443) The interruptions, however, continued almost to the end.
('29', 72, 2, 12, 149500) It was nevertheless most creditable to the meeting that the cry against Mr. Jamnadas was not taken up by the audience.
('29', 72, 2, 13, 149619) Mr. Jamnadas was able to finish his speech without difficulty.
('29', 72, 2, 14, 149682) All the same the interruption jarred on me.
('29', 72, 2, 15, 149726) I saw that those admirers of me dishonoured and misinterpreted their idol where as Mr. Jamnadas honoured and interpreted me properly by courteously but firmly reiterating his dissent from some of my political views and by refusing to call me ‘Mahatma’ at the dictation of any person.
('29', 72, 2, 16, 150010) I therefore asked the friends who had been so discourteous to publicly apologize.
('29', 72, 2, 17, 150092) I drew their attention to the fact that the rules of public meetings demanded a respectful behaviour even towards opponents.
('29', 72, 2, 18, 150217) The code of courtesy was still more exacting for non violent non co operators.
('29', 72, 2, 19, 150296) The non violence of non co operators obliged them to respect their opponents even as they respected their friends.
('29', 72, 2, 20, 150411) Moreover, the audience must respect the sentiments of those in whose honour they might meet.
('29', 72, 2, 21, 150504) The interrupters should have known that I had often said that the name ‘Mahatma’ stank in my nostrils.
('29', 72, 2, 22, 150607) It did, for instance, at the time of the Bombay riots of 1921. The use of the adjective was prohibited at the Ashram.
('29', 72, 2, 23, 150725) Mr. Jamnadas had therefore done what was after my heart.
('29', 72, 2, 24, 150782) After saying this I paused for the apology.
('29', 72, 2, 25, 150826) The audie nce helped me by murmuring approval and adviceto the interrupters to apologize.
('29', 72, 2, 26, 150916) And the latter bravely stood up and apologized with
('29', 72, 3, 27, 150968) 1 Vide “Speech at Excelsior Theatre, Bombay”, 31 8 1924.
('29', 73, 0, 1, 151025) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 73, 1, 2, 151066) folded hands.
('29', 73, 1, 3, 151080) It was a sight that I cannot easily forget.
('29', 73, 1, 4, 151124) In resuming my speech and in thanking the interrupters for their apology, I could not help remarking that the seed of swaraj lay more in such true and gentlemanly conduct than in any number of eloquent speeches or debates and votes in the Councils.
('29', 73, 1, 5, 151373) The penitent members of the audience had brought swaraj nearer by their frank and fearless repentance.
('29', 73, 2, 6, 151476) This prelude which was both unhappy and happy at the same time emphasized the note underlying my speech and gave it an expectedly dignified turn.
('29', 73, 3, 7, 151622) It enabled me in dealing with Malabar to pay a tardy tribute to the inexhaustible capacity for social service of Mr. Devdhar and to show that though in politics we seemed to differ as poles asunder my regard for his personal character, devotion to duty and self sacrifice remained undiminished.
('29', 73, 3, 8, 151917) I then presented the spinning wheel as a symbol of our identification with the poorest of the soil.
('29', 73, 3, 9, 152017) Mere lip profession was not enough.
('29', 73, 3, 10, 152053) Even a genuine sensation of pity was not enough.
('29', 73, 3, 11, 152102) We wanted the poor to feel that, if they toiled for us, we spin for their sakes.
('29', 73, 3, 12, 152183) The halffed millions were in a state of blank despair.
('29', 73, 3, 13, 152238) They had lost faith in themselves and in us.
('29', 73, 3, 14, 152283) They had resigned themselves to death by slow and painful starvation.
('29', 73, 3, 15, 152353) They had become so accustomed to livings on charity doles that they almost refused to work.
('29', 73, 3, 16, 152445) They had become less than animals, they were living sepulchres.
('29', 73, 3, 17, 152509) If we wanted these millions to earn a few pice by doing honest and honourable toil, the only possible instrument to present them with was the gentle and graceful spinning wheel which could be turned even by the most delicate.
('29', 73, 3, 18, 152735) The only effective way of inducing the millions to exchange a listless, inane life of beggary for that of dignified and easy labour was for us to invite them to take up the spinning wheel by turning it ourselves.
('29', 73, 3, 19, 152948) In the words of the Gita what the great ones did, the simple folk copied.
('29', 73, 4, 20, 153022) From the spinning wheel I came to the hope that was expressed by so many friends that I would show a way out of the present awful impasse in national life.
('29', 73, 4, 21, 153178) I told the audience that I was aware of my responsibility and was trying to devise a way out.
('29', 73, 4, 22, 153272) I was in correspondence with Pandit Motilalji.
('29', 73, 4, 23, 153319) But I had nothing else to suggest but satyagraha.
('29', 73, 4, 24, 153369) The people had hitherto known it in its
('29', 73, 5, 25, 153409) 1 The source has “their”.
('29', 74, 0, 1, 153435) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 75
('29', 74, 1, 2, 153482) terrible aspect of civil disobedience and non co operation.
('29', 74, 1, 3, 153542) But it had a benign aspect which was its permanent part.
('29', 74, 1, 4, 153599) Whatever shape it took, it must now be the benign aspect of satyagraha which must be presented to the public.
('29', 74, 1, 5, 153709) We had quarrelled too long and often on trivials.
('29', 74, 1, 6, 153759) We were heedlessly divided.
('29', 74, 1, 7, 153787) There was no reason why we could not find a common denominator of action.
('29', 74, 1, 8, 153861) There must be some things on which we could all unite and for the prosecution of which we could all meet under the same roof.
('29', 74, 1, 9, 153987) The spinning wheel, unity between the different communities and removal by Hindus of untouchability were the items on which perhaps all could unite.
('29', 74, 1, 10, 154136) I had already seen Mrs. Besant and ventured in a humble spirit to place my view before her.
('29', 74, 1, 11, 154228) I would likewise canvass the other leaders.
('29', 74, 1, 12, 154272) I would on no account divide the Congress and if I found a desire to quarrel, I would certainly not only take no part in any division but would take a back seat and retire from any such unseemly contest.
('29', 74, 1, 13, 154476) Any programme must therefore be a programme arrived at not by the majority of votes but by mutual informal discussion and agreement.
('29', 74, 1, 14, 154609) The vote may come in, if necessary, after agreement on all sides.
('29', 74, 1, 15, 154675) If I found that there was no programme that I could work, I should gladly retire altogether but not lead obstruction.
('29', 74, 1, 16, 154793) The most benign spirit of satyagraha was a spirit of perfect self surrender in which resistance, if any, was on matters of obvious principle which one might have practised and woven into one’s life.
('29', 74, 1, 17, 154992) I told the audience that the whole science of satyagraha if it might be so called was evolved out of prolonged experience in the domestic field.
('29', 74, 1, 18, 155137) In its terrible aspect I had to practise it in connection with my own wife, son and brother long deceased.
('29', 74, 1, 19, 155244) It had cost me their estrangement.
('29', 74, 1, 20, 155279) But it was all out of deepest love.
('29', 74, 1, 21, 155315) I believe myself to be capable of boundless love as well towards other creatures of God as towards my own dearest relatives.
('29', 74, 1, 22, 155440) Sometimes love’s anguish left deep scars on the loved ones but it left much deeper ones on the lover’s bosom.
('29', 74, 1, 23, 155550) I owed no ill will to Englishmen.
('29', 74, 1, 24, 155584) I had in them some of my best friends but there came a time when I had to say, “You shall not exploit my country.
('29', 74, 1, 25, 155698) The explotation has done incalculable harm.
('29', 74, 1, 26, 155742) Some of you are indifferent to its welfare and would squeeze it as much as you can.
('29', 74, 1, 27, 155826) Some others among you believe in your ignorance that the English rule in India is for her own good and that you are her trustees.
('29', 74, 1, 28, 155956) This thing must end and that soon.” For me to say this was to put my whole soul into doing it.
('29', 74, 1, 29, 156051) The attempt had resulted in bringing into prominence the terrible aspect of satyagraha.
('29', 74, 1, 30, 156139) It had not ended the system of
