('29', 75, 4, 20, 157723) 56. SPINNING IN BANARAS
('29', 75, 5, 21, 157747) Professor Ramdas Gour has sent an interesting report of how he introduced spinning among the children of the municipal schools of Banaras.
('29', 75, 5, 22, 157886) He bought 40 second hand wheels, cardingbows etc.
('29', 75, 5, 23, 157936) He next taught thirteen teachers the art of spinning.
('29', 75, 5, 24, 157990) The latter in their turn taught their fellow teachers.
('29', 75, 5, 25, 158045) Thus in a little over a month 175 teachers became competent spinning masters.
('29', 75, 5, 26, 158123) The professor was helped by his wife and daughter.
('29', 75, 5, 27, 158174) Thus the professor proudly says:
('29', 75, 6, 28, 158207) 1 Small soul
('29', 76, 0, 1, 158220) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 77
('29', 76, 1, 2, 158267) If each school had been supplied with an extra spinning expert it would have cost at least Rs. 10,000 a year.
('29', 76, 1, 3, 158377) This problem was solved by mygiving only four hours daily for five or six weeks in training the existing staff.
('29', 76, 1, 4, 158489) He adds:
('29', 76, 2, 5, 158498) Now there is no teacher who cannot spin or card and henceforward no man or woman is to be employed as a teacher who does not know carding and spinning.
('29', 76, 2, 6, 158650) His future plans the professor describes as follows:
('29', 76, 3, 7, 158703) As this difficulty was obviated, I approached the Board with a detailed scheme for introducing 350 spinning wheels in 26 upper primary schools to teach carding and spinning to about 700 boys at least, with provision for half a dozen pit looms for a weaving section for khadi, a weaving teacher, a supervisor, a carpenter, and sufficient cotton to give work to each student for half an hour daily.
('29', 76, 3, 8, 159100) The scheme demanded Rs. 6,000/ per annum.
('29', 76, 3, 9, 159142) The Board, however, felt very diffident and postponed the question from meeting to meeting for 2 months.
('29', 76, 3, 10, 159247) On the 26th of July last, they saw their way to grant Rs. 3,000/ only, for the year.
('29', 76, 3, 11, 159332) I have, therefore resolved to cut off the item of cotton almost entirely and to reduce several other items to a workable minimum, so that the work may be carried on [on] a smaller scale.
('29', 76, 3, 12, 159519) I am now getting only 300 spinning wheels made with 600 removable spindle holders, of the pattern I purchased at the Sabarmati Ashram.
('29', 76, 3, 13, 159654) With the little improvements I have in view (the result of a study at the Ashram), I hope to make it possible for more than a thousand boys and girls to learn and practise spinning every day and produce yarn of tolerably good quality.
('29', 76, 3, 14, 159889) I am now waiting only for the wheels to be made, and this must take its time.
('29', 76, 3, 15, 159967) In the meantime, I am appealing to the parents and guardians to allow a daily supply of cotton from their pockets.
('29', 76, 3, 16, 160082) I am to give the children the instruments and the necessary instruction and the parents to give them cotton.
('29', 76, 3, 17, 160191) The yarn will be theirs and if they so choose, they will collect their yarn and give it over to us to be woven into khadi and we will supply them khadi on reasonable weaving charges.
('29', 76, 3, 18, 160374) I am going to open also a tailoring class and will make tailoring cheaper for khadi.
('29', 76, 3, 19, 160459) The public will watch this experiment with sympathetic interest.
('29', 76, 3, 20, 160524) Let me hope that the other teachers will follow the example set by Professor Ramdas Gour.

('29', 77, 1, 2, 160677) 57. FOR FALLEN HUMANITY
('29', 77, 2, 3, 160701) It was at Barisal that I had the privilege of meeting our fallen sisters, victims of our lust, now nearly three years ago.
('29', 77, 2, 4, 160824) 1 Some of them said, “We earn from two to three rupees per day.
('29', 77, 2, 5, 160888) You must give us some occupation that would give us as much.” For a moment I sank within me but immediately came to myself and said, “No, my dear sisters, I cannot suggest anything that would give you two or three rupees per day but I must ask you to give up your calling even though you have to starve.
('29', 77, 2, 6, 161192) There is the spinning wheel however.
('29', 77, 2, 7, 161229) If you take it, it will be your salvation.”
('29', 77, 3, 8, 161273) The fallen sisters are only a small part of the fallen humanity of India.
('29', 77, 3, 9, 161347) The skin and bone of Orissa are also in a sense part of that humanity.
('29', 77, 3, 10, 161418) They are the victims of our ignorance as the first are of our lust.
('29', 77, 3, 11, 161486) In their case it is not our animal lust but the lust for wealth that reduces them to skin and bone.
('29', 77, 3, 12, 161586) They bleed so that we may become rich.
('29', 77, 4, 13, 161625) But now, thank God, we the educated middle class are hungering to identify ourselves with our fallen sisters and our starving brothers.
('29', 77, 4, 14, 161761) We desire swaraj so that they may live.
('29', 77, 4, 15, 161801) We cannot all go to the villages and help the villagers.
('29', 77, 4, 16, 161858) The fallen sister is a perpetual reminder to us to become pure.
('29', 77, 4, 17, 161922) How then can we think of and feel for them from day to day?
('29', 77, 4, 18, 161982) What may we all do for them every day?
('29', 77, 4, 19, 162021) We are so weak that we want to do as little as possible.
('29', 77, 4, 20, 162078) What is that little?
('29', 77, 4, 21, 162099) I can think of nothing else but the spinning wheel.
('29', 77, 4, 22, 162151) The work must be easy, capable of being done by all, the learned and the ignorant, the good and the bad, young and old, men and women, boys and girls, the strong and the weak, no matter to what religion they belong.
('29', 77, 4, 23, 162367) The work to be effective must be the same for all.
('29', 77, 4, 24, 162418) The spinning wheel satisfies all these conditions.
('29', 77, 4, 25, 162469) Therefore he or she who spins for half an hour every day serves the masses in the most efficient manner possible.
('29', 77, 4, 26, 162583) And he renders whole hearted conscious service to the fallen humanity of India and thus brings swaraj nearer for that service.
('29', 77, 4, 27, 162710) The spinning wheel for us is the foundation for all public corporate life.
('29', 77, 4, 28, 162785) It is impossible to build any permanent public life without it.
('29', 77, 4, 29, 162849) It is the one visible link that indissolubly binds us to the
('29', 77, 5, 30, 162910) 1 Vide “Fallen Sisters”, 11 9 1921.
('29', 78, 0, 1, 162946) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 79
('29', 78, 1, 2, 162993) lowest in the land and thus gives them a hope.
('29', 78, 1, 3, 163040) We may or must add many things to it, but let us first make sure of it, even as a wise mason makes sure of his foundation before he begins to build the super structure, and the bigger the structure the deeper and stronger the foundation.
('29', 78, 1, 4, 163278) For the result to be obtained therefore spinning should become universal in India.
('29', 78, 1, 5, 163361) But spinning will be not only the connecting link between the masses and the classes, it will be the link between the different political parties.
('29', 78, 1, 6, 163508) It will become common to all the parties.
('29', 78, 1, 7, 163550) They may disagree on all other things if they like, but they can agree on this at the least.
('29', 78, 1, 8, 163643) I ask therefore every one who loves the country, loves the poorest and the fallen, to give half an hour’s labour daily to spinning even and well twisted yarn for their sake and in the name of God.
('29', 78, 1, 9, 163840) As this must be a gift to the nation, it must be delivered to the All India Khadi Board with religious regularity.
('29', 78, 1, 10, 163955) Young India, 4 9 1924
('29', 78, 2, 11, 163977) 58. NOTES
('29', 78, 3, 12, 163987) LOWEST COMMON MEASURE
('29', 78, 4, 13, 164009) The readers of Young India will find in the summary of my speech at the Excelsior Theatre, Bombay, an idea developed for the purpose of bringing together all the various elements in the country that are at present working against one another often without knowing that they are doing so.
('29', 78, 4, 14, 164297) Everybody is asking me to bring these together.
('29', 78, 4, 15, 164345) I am therefore trying to see what can bring these elements together.
('29', 78, 4, 16, 164414) In other words what are the things in which the majority of those who have at all taken part in moulding public life can or do agree or which are indispensable for our internal growth.
('29', 78, 4, 17, 164599) Though the external may have its use constituted as I am, I have all my life thought of growth from within.
('29', 78, 4, 18, 164707) External appliances are perfectly useless if there is no internal reaction.
('29', 78, 4, 19, 164783) When a body is perfect within, it becomes impervious to external adverse influences and is independent of external help.
('29', 78, 4, 20, 164904) Moreover when the internal organs are sound they automatically attract external help.
('29', 78, 4, 21, 164990) Hence the proverb, God helps those who help themselves.
('29', 78, 4, 22, 165046) If therefore we would all work to bring about internal perfection, we need not take up any other activity at all.
('29', 78, 4, 23, 165160) But whether we do so or not, at least the Congress may restrict itself to internal development alone.

('29', 79, 1, 2, 165303) What then is this lowest common measure necessary for such growth?

('29', 86, 1, 2, 178299) 60. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES—XI 1
('29', 86, 2, 3, 178328) WHAT I READ [ I]
('29', 86, 3, 4, 178345) As a boy I had not much taste for reading anything outside my school books.
('29', 86, 3, 5, 178421) They alone gave me enough food for thought; for it was natural for me to reduce to practice what I learnt at School.
('29', 86, 3, 6, 178538) For home reading I had an intense dislike.
('29', 86, 3, 7, 178581) I used to labour through home lessons because I had to.
('29', 86, 3, 8, 178637) During my student days in England too, the same habit persisted of not reading outside the books for examinations.
('29', 86, 3, 9, 178752) When however I began life, I felt I ought to read for the sake of gaining general knowledge.
('29', 86, 3, 10, 178845) But at the earliest period of my life it became one of storm and stress.
('29', 86, 3, 11, 178918) It commenced with a fight with the then political agent of Kathiawar.
('29', 86, 3, 12, 178988) I had therefore not much time for literary pursuits.
('29', 86, 3, 13, 179041) In South Africa for one year I had fair leisure in spite of the battle for freedom that faced me.
('29', 86, 3, 14, 179139) The year 1893 I devoted to religious striving.
('29', 86, 3, 15, 179186) The reading was therefore wholly religious.
('29', 86, 3, 16, 179230) After 1894 all the time for sustained reading I got was in the jailsof South Africa.
('29', 86, 3, 17, 179315) I had developed not only a taste for reading but for completing my knowledge of Sanskrit and studying Tamil, Hindi and Urdu.
('29', 86, 3, 18, 179440) Tamil because I was in touch with so many Tamilians in South Africa and Urdu because I had dealings with so many Mussalmans.
('29', 86, 3, 19, 179565) The South African jails had whetted my appetite and I was grieved when during my last incarceration in South Africa I was prematurely discharged.
('29', 86, 3, 20, 179711) When therefore the opportunity came to me in India, I hailed it with joy.
('29', 86, 3, 21, 179785) I mapped out a rigid programme of studies at Yeravda to finish which six years were not enough.
('29', 86, 3, 22, 179881) During the first three months I had a vague hope that India would rise to the occasion, complete the boycott of foreign cloth and unlock the prison gates.
('29', 86, 3, 23, 180036) But I soon learnt that such was not to be the case.
('29', 86, 3, 24, 180088) I saw at once that it meant laborious quiet organizing which could not take the nation anything less than five years.
('29', 86, 3, 25, 180206) I had no desire whatsoever for being discharged before my time except by the peaceful constructive act of the nation even if it was not actually swaraj.
('29', 86, 3, 26, 180359) I therefore settled down to studies with the zest of a youth of twenty four instead of an old man of fifty four with a broken constitution.
('29', 86, 3, 27, 180499) I accounted for every minute of my time and

('29', 90, 1, 14, 189533) I was even prejudiced against it, believing (falsely as it has now turned out) that it was nothing but a record of bloodshed and impossible long descriptions which would send me to sleep.

('29', 90, 1, 17, 189927) I compared it, as I finished it in four months, not to a treasure chest in which you find nothing but polished gems limited as to quantity and quality but to an inexhaustible mine which the deeper one digs the more precious are the finds.

('29', 90, 1, 22, 190518) It is like a mighty river which in its progress absorbs many streams, some even muddy.

('29', 104, 11, 30, 218205) 76. MY NOTE
('29', 104, 12, 31, 218217) PROPAGATION OF KHADI
('29', 104, 13, 32, 218238) The Khadi Bhandar on Princess Street, formerly run as his own by Shri Jerajani has now been taken over by the All India Khadi Board, which proposes to expand it.
('29', 104, 13, 33, 218400) Securities required for the take over have been received.
('29', 104, 13, 34, 218458) The purpose of the takeover is to store in
('29', 104, 14, 35, 218501) 1 The addressee received this letter on September l, 1924, in which year Bhadrapad Sud 8 corresponded to September 6.
('29', 105, 0, 1, 218619) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 105, 1, 2, 218661) and sell from a central depot the surplus stocks of khadi from the country’s output lying unsold in the provinces.
('29', 105, 1, 3, 218776) This kind of assistance was formerly rendered by Gujarat, but this has since been discontinued in view of the Gujarat Provincial Committee’s decision to develop the local trade.
('29', 105, 1, 4, 218954) Every type of khadi can therefore be had from this Bhandar.
('29', 105, 1, 5, 219014) Saris worn by the women of the South can be had, as also dhotis of full width which were formerly not available in khadi.
('29', 105, 1, 6, 219136) The scheme recently launched for the organization of this Bhandar deserves all encouragement.
('29', 105, 1, 7, 219230) Anyone can become a member by paying an annual subscription of one rupee.
('29', 105, 1, 8, 219304) It is the responsibility of the Manager to issue a folder detailing the varieties and prices of the khadi and distribute it among the members.
('29', 105, 1, 9, 219447) Members are entitled to a discount of one pice in a rupee on their purchases.
('29', 105, 1, 10, 219525) Thus if during one year a member buys khadi worth 64 rupees he saves a rupee.
('29', 105, 1, 11, 219603) But it is not desirable that members should join with this narrow aim in view; one should join because one wants to encourage khadi.
('29', 105, 1, 12, 219736) A member should obtain the folder on the progress of the industry and keeping himself informed circulate the information among the public.
('29', 105, 1, 13, 219875) The fourth issue of the said pamphlet carries two instructions which are useful.
('29', 105, 1, 14, 219956) During the monsoon season clothes do not dry soon, more particularly khadi clothes.
('29', 105, 1, 15, 220040) To get over this inconvenience we should put up two clothes lines, instead of the usual single one, at a distance of [say] two feet, and spread the clothes over both, so that the ends do not cling together, and thus allow sufficient air to pass over the clothes which will now dry sooner.
('29', 105, 1, 16, 220329) The other instruction pertains to the washing of the khadi cap.
('29', 105, 1, 17, 220393) A cap loses its shape if wrung in this process, and even stitches may come off at the seams.
('29', 105, 1, 18, 220486) But if left to dry after being rubbed without wringing and then pressed between the hands after being folded twice or thrice, it will not be creased and retain its shape.
('29', 105, 1, 19, 220657) It is true in this way all the water cannot be squeezed out; however, a cap can be used for three days, during which time the washed one can dry.
('29', 105, 1, 20, 220803) If, instead of being crushed between the hands, it is compressed between clean smooth planks and the entire water is wrung out, the cap will on drying stay stiff.
('29', 105, 1, 21, 220966) Those who go in for white khadi must not wear even slightly soiled clothes.
('29', 105, 1, 22, 221042) We shall enjoy the very act of washing, once we get used to it.
('29', 105, 1, 23, 221106) One does not have to spend much time over it and one gets the additional satisfaction of doing ones own laundering.
('29', 105, 1, 24, 221222) Obviously, white clothes require frequent washing.
('29', 105, 1, 25, 221273) The poor man who prefers a black jacket cannot afford to depend on a dhobi; he must acquire the habit of doing his own washing.
('29', 105, 1, 26, 221401) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 7 9 1924

('29', 106, 2, 3, 221502) The All India Khadi Board tested the yarn collected by them and I give below 1 the results which are interesting and instructive.

('29', 106, 2, 15, 222606) This should encourage other workers.

('29', 106, 2, 18, 222845) By now thousands of expert spinners, men and women, should have become active in this region where there are many instructors and where much attention is paid to developing the craft of spinning.
('29', 106, 2, 19, 223041) This is one side.

('29', 106, 2, 21, 223138) More yarn is obtained from places where more work is put in.

('29', 106, 2, 23, 223273) Again, the paucity [or spinners] indicates that the country has not yet realized the importance of spinning and that the craft has not yet become as popular as it ought to be.
('29', 106, 2, 24, 223449) Results of the next month may throw more light.

('29', 107, 1, 2, 223630) 78. BIRTH ANNIVERSARY OF DADABHAI NAOROJI
('29', 107, 2, 3, 223672) The birth anniversary of the Grand Old Man of India, Dadabhai Naoroji, fell on 4th September; but the National Women’s Council arranged the function on the 30th August to suit my convenience since I had to be present in Poona on the 4th.
('29', 107, 2, 4, 223910) Dadabhai led the life of a rishi.
('29', 107, 2, 5, 223944) I have many sacred memories of him.
('29', 107, 2, 6, 223980) This Grand Old Man of India was, and continues to be, one of the great men who have moulded my life.
('29', 107, 2, 7, 224081) I think the memories that I recounted before the sisters are worth being reported to the readers.
('29', 107, 2, 8, 224179) I had the privilege to see Dadabhai in 1888 for the first time.
('29', 107, 2, 9, 224243) A friend of my father’s had given me a letter of introduction to him, and it is worth noting that this friend was not at all acquainted with Dadabhai.
('29', 107, 2, 10, 224394) He, however, took it for granted that anyone from the public could write to such a saintly person.
('29', 107, 2, 11, 224493) In England, I found that Dadabhai came in contact with all students.
('29', 107, 2, 12, 224562) He was their leader and attended their gatherings.
('29', 107, 2, 13, 224613) Ever since, I have seen his life flowing in the same rhythm till the end.
('29', 107, 2, 14, 224687) I was in South Africa for twenty years, and exchanged hundreds of letters with Dadabhai during the period.
('29', 107, 2, 15, 224794) I was astonished at the regularity with which his replies came.
('29', 107, 2, 16, 224858) My letters used to be typed, but I do not remember any typed reply from him.
('29', 107, 2, 17, 224935) The replies were all in his own hand, and moreover, as I came to know subsequently, he would himself make copies of his letters on a tissue paper book.
('29', 107, 2, 18, 225087) I could find that most of my letters were replied to by the return of post.
('29', 107, 2, 19, 225163) Whenever I met him I tasted nothing but love and sweetness.
('29', 107, 2, 20, 225223) Dadabhai would talk to me exactly like a father to a son, and I have heard from others that their experience was the same as mine.
('29', 107, 2, 21, 225354) The thought uppermost in his mind all the time was how India could rise and attain her freedom.
('29', 107, 2, 22, 225450) My first acquaintance with the extent of Indian poverty was through Dadabhai’s book 1; I learnt from that book itself that about three crores of men in our country are half starved.
('29', 107, 2, 23, 225632) Today this number has increased.
('29', 107, 2, 24, 225665) His simplicity was without limit.
('29', 107, 2, 25, 225699) It so happened that someone criticized him in 1908. I found it extremely intolerable and yet I was unable to prove that it was wrong.
('29', 107, 2, 26, 225833) I was troubled by many doubts.
('29', 107, 2, 27, 225864) I thought that it was sinful to entertain doubts about a great patriot like Dadabhai.
('29', 107, 2, 28, 225950) Therefore I sought an appointment and went to see him with the consent of the
('29', 107, 3, 29, 226028) 1 Poverty and Un British Rule in India
('29', 108, 0, 1, 226067) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 109
('29', 108, 1, 2, 226115) critic.
('29', 108, 1, 3, 226123) That was the first time I went to his private office.
('29', 108, 1, 4, 226177) It was made up of a very small room with only two chairs.
('29', 108, 1, 5, 226235) I entered.
('29', 108, 1, 6, 226246) He asked me to sit in a vacant chair but I went and sat near his feet.
('29', 108, 1, 7, 226317) He saw distress on my face and questioned me, asking me to speak out whatever weighed on my mind.
('29', 108, 1, 8, 226415) With great hesitation I reported to him the criticisms of his detractors and said,”I was troubled by doubts on hearing these things and, because I worship you, I consider it a sin to keep them back.” Smilingly, he asked me,”What reply do I give you?
('29', 108, 1, 9, 226665) Do you believe this thing?” His manner, his tone and the pain that was so apparent in his words, were enough for me.
('29', 108, 1, 10, 226782) I said,”I do not now want to hear anything more.
('29', 108, 1, 11, 226831) I have no trace of a doubt left in me.” Even then he told me many things relating to this matter, which it is not necessary to recapitulate here.
('29', 108, 1, 12, 226977) After this event I realized that Dadabhai was an Indian living in the simple style of a fakir.
('29', 108, 1, 13, 227072) A fakir’s style does not imply that a man should not have even a farthing; but Dadabhai had forsaken the luxuries and standards which other people of his stratum were enjoying during those days.
('29', 108, 1, 14, 227267) I myself and many others like me have learnt the lessons of regularity, single minded patriotism, simplicity, austerity and ceaseless work from this venerable man.
('29', 108, 1, 15, 227431) At a time when criticism of the Government was considered sedition and hardly anyone dared to speak the truth, Dadabhai criticized the Government in the severest terms and boldly pointed out the shortcomings of the administration.
('29', 108, 1, 16, 227662) I have absolutely no doubt that the people of India will remember Dadabhai affectionately as long as India endures as an entity in the world.

('29', 108, 4, 19, 227840) 79. BOMBAY’S BENEVOLENCE
('29', 108, 5, 20, 227865) I know Bombay has quite a few vices and a lot of filth too.

('29', 109, 1, 6, 228820) It is my belief that this is a consequence of Parsi benevolence.

('29', 109, 1, 18, 229880) The Parsis, in order to take the lead in contributing yarn, may put in manual labour and others who want to help them may come out with cash from their savings; and now whose contribution will be held higher in the Almighty’s accounts?
('29', 109, 1, 19, 230116) Certainly, this spinning is for the sake of the poor in India.
('29', 109, 1, 20, 230179) This [yarn] can be woven into khadi and sold.
('29', 109, 1, 21, 230225) But the real purpose behind this manual work is to serve as an example for the poor.
('29', 109, 1, 22, 230310) This purpose, it would appeal to cosmopolitan Bombay to fulfil.

('29', 110, 1, 2, 230458) 80. TWO OLD BOOKS
('29', 110, 2, 3, 230476) Bhai Karsandas Chitalia has presented me two very good old books which he had secured from a Parsi sister.
('29', 110, 2, 4, 230583) Both of them were litho printed in 1828, they are bound in leather and carry on the fly leaf the following superscription in golden letters:”Presented to Dinshaw Bhikaji by Major General Sir Malcom.” This Englishman was then the head of the Education Board.
('29', 110, 2, 5, 230841) The book treats of Arithmetic, Algebra, Geometry and Book keeping.
('29', 110, 2, 6, 230908) Gujarati translations from English books have been done by George Jarvis Engineer with the assistance of Jagannath Shastri Mawant.
('29', 110, 2, 7, 231039) This book is an evidence of the missionary spirit and liberality of Englishmen of the older generations.
('29', 110, 2, 8, 231144) The script of the book is Devanagari.
('29', 110, 2, 9, 231182) May be this was done with the express intention of making Devanagari the common script.
('29', 110, 2, 10, 231270) The letters are as beautiful as pearls and there are many lucid tables filled with figures.
('29', 110, 2, 11, 231362) One might say that we can read the first chapter of our educational history in these books.
('29', 110, 2, 12, 231454) The terminology used then has remained nearly the same till today, it could not be changed even slightly after all these many years.
('29', 110, 2, 13, 231587) Since they were written with the help of a Maharashtrian scholar, a few changes like pujya for shunya, jabab for jawab are noticeable.
('29', 110, 2, 14, 231722) In this age of printing presses and rotary machines, we can hardly imagine how hard the pioneers had to labour.
('29', 110, 2, 15, 231834) These books are witnesses to that hard work.
('29', 110, 2, 16, 231879) These books will be deposited in the collection of the archaeological museum.
('29', 110, 2, 17, 231957) If any brothers or sisters possess similar old books which are not in actual use, I would suggest their being deposited in the archaeological museum.
('29', 110, 3, 18, 232107) [From Gujarati]
('29', 110, 4, 19, 232123) Navajivan, 7 9 1924

('29', 111, 7, 12, 232803) 82. LETTER TO MAHOMED ALI
('29', 111, 8, 13, 232829) September 8, 1924
('29', 111, 9, 14, 232847) MY DEAR BROTHER, It is now just after five, Monday morning.
('29', 111, 9, 15, 232907) I have commenced to use ink but somehow or other the hand has not yet settled down to the ink pen yet.
('29', 111, 9, 16, 233010) And I want to talk to you without avoidable impediment.
('29', 111, 9, 17, 233066) Only yesterday I realized what you wanted.
('29', 111, 9, 18, 233109) Remember that though I have been successfully at the head of two Presses, I know next to nothing of the details.
('29', 111, 9, 19, 233222) I have not yet been to the Navajivan office.
('29', 111, 9, 20, 233267) I never knew what was brought from Delhi and what was not.
('29', 111, 9, 21, 233326) I thought I was bringing something that was mine.
('29', 111, 9, 22, 233376) Now I am sending something that is yours.
('29', 111, 9, 23, 233418) What is mine is yours—Swami 1 included.
('29', 111, 9, 24, 233458) But where he fails, or you find him wanting, you should fall back upon me.
('29', 111, 9, 25, 233533) I cannot supply his ability, but I shall find the money somehow, if money can make up for lost time.
('29', 111, 9, 26, 233634) I believe Swami when he tells me, he could not have managed to send you the machines earlier.
('29', 111, 10, 27, 233728) 1 Swami Anandananda, manager, Navajivan Press
('29', 112, 0, 1, 233774) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 113
('29', 112, 1, 2, 233822) can you not have both Comrade 1 and Hamdard 2 printed elsewhere for the time being and ask me to find the deficit?
('29', 112, 1, 3, 233937) Swami says, the Press will take time to set up in all its details.
('29', 112, 1, 4, 234004) He says, he never understood that he was to put up everything.
('29', 112, 1, 5, 234067) He thought, and I too, that he was wanted for the machines only.
('29', 112, 1, 6, 234132) He says, he was not willing to cart all the furniture here.
('29', 112, 1, 7, 234192) Neither he nor his agent had the requisite knowledge at the time.
('29', 112, 1, 8, 234258) The agent who actually took delivery knew very little of Press things.
('29', 112, 1, 9, 234329) But the point is not what A or B understood but what you need, and what I can do.
('29', 112, 1, 10, 234411) Even whilst I was in Delhi I did not understand that the sole delay was due to the delay caused on my side.
('29', 112, 1, 11, 234519) I thought that even after the machines had been set up there were many things that had to be done in Delhi by you before we could make a start.
('29', 112, 1, 12, 234663) Now please use Swami freely.
('29', 112, 1, 13, 234692) After all he is among those who are the closest to me.
('29', 112, 1, 14, 234747) If he fails, I have failed.
('29', 112, 1, 15, 234775) A man who is no judge of men is a failure even though he may have a heart of gold and may have the best of intentions in the world.
('29', 112, 1, 16, 234907) He must then cease to deal with men and things.
('29', 112, 1, 17, 234955) I have therefore always said that I must be judged by the test my closest campanions pass through.
('29', 112, 1, 18, 235054) You, Swami, Mahadev, Hayat, Ashfaq, Moazzam, Devdas, Krishnadas, Shwaib are among them.
('29', 112, 1, 19, 235142) It is not enough that I can pull on well with you; Swami, Mahadev, Devdas, etc., also ought.
('29', 112, 1, 20, 235235) If they cannot, they should disappear from my public life even as Ba has, at any rate, for the present.
('29', 112, 1, 21, 235339) They are the instruments through which I work, as Hayat, Moazzam are the ones through whom you work.
('29', 112, 1, 22, 235440) I am therefore sending Swami so that you and he can come near each other and know each other better.
('29', 112, 1, 23, 235541) For me a proper regulation of these personal relations means more for swaraj and unity than a thousand public documents.
('29', 112, 1, 24, 235662) With deepest love,
('29', 112, 3, 25, 235681) M. K. G.
('29', 112, 4, 26, 235690) TO MAHOMED ALI

('29', 113, 1, 2, 235875) 83. LETTER TO SATISH CHANDRA MUKERJEE
('29', 113, 2, 3, 235913) September 8, 1924
('29', 113, 3, 4, 235931) DEAR SATISH BABU, I was deeply touched by your wire.
('29', 113, 3, 5, 235984) I am sending you a consoling reply.
('29', 113, 3, 6, 236020) No one has displaced or wishes to displace Kristodas.
('29', 113, 3, 7, 236074) I still cannot do without him.
('29', 113, 3, 8, 236105) Last time Kristodas did not accompany me because he and I came to the conclusion that it was the best for him and the cause.
('29', 113, 3, 9, 236230) He is the wisest among the four who are rendering personal service and doing secretarial work.
('29', 113, 3, 10, 236325) Mahadev, Devdas and Pyarelal regard him as more advanced in wisdom and tapasya than they.
('29', 113, 3, 11, 236415) I wonder what led Kristodas to think that any of them could ever think of ousting Kristodas.
('29', 113, 3, 12, 236508) I do not need four with me in my travels.
('29', 113, 3, 13, 236550) One at least must remain behind to attend to affairs.
('29', 113, 3, 14, 236604) Only Mahadev or Devdas can constantly remain behind if only because neither Pyarelal nor Kristodas can attend to Navajivan and the Gujarati correspon dence.
('29', 113, 3, 15, 236761) Kristodas must therefore be a constant companion with me.
('29', 113, 3, 16, 236819) He has gone to Gulbarga because he alone was acceptable to Shwaib.
('29', 113, 3, 17, 236886) The latter would have taken Mahadevwith him, if I had insisted.
('29', 113, 3, 18, 236950) But I know him to be very sensitive.
('29', 113, 3, 19, 236987) I wanted him to go under the best of auspices.
('29', 113, 3, 20, 237034) And when he asked for Kristodas although Mahadev was suggested, I unhesitatingly agreed.
('29', 113, 3, 21, 237123) Kristodas was willing.
('29', 113, 3, 22, 237146) He and Shwaib hit it off well together.
('29', 113, 3, 23, 237186) Pray therefore do not be anxious about Kristodas.
('29', 113, 3, 24, 237236) He shall be with me not merely for your sake.
('29', 113, 3, 25, 237282) He will be with me for my sake.
('29', 113, 3, 26, 237314) I am more anxious to have him by me than you can be to put him by me.
('29', 113, 3, 27, 237384) It has been the privilege of my life to have some companions whom I have felt honoured and comforted to have by me.
('29', 113, 3, 28, 237500) Kristodas is not the least among them.
('29', 113, 3, 29, 237539) I have written this with your pen.
('29', 113, 3, 30, 237574) The first you sent me I prized very much and always kept with me.
('29', 113, 3, 31, 237640) In the jail, I lent it to Indulal.
('29', 113, 3, 32, 237675) It got spoiled.
('29', 113, 3, 33, 237691) He sent it out for repairs.
('29', 113, 3, 34, 237719) The friend whom he entrusted with the precious charge lost it.
('29', 113, 3, 35, 237782) Kristodas has therefore given me the one I am using.
('29', 113, 3, 36, 237835) I have also received two print orders.
('29', 113, 3, 37, 237874) May I thank you for all these delicate attention?
('29', 113, 3, 38, 237924) Add one more by wirings a promise, never more to worry about Kristodas.
('29', 113, 5, 39, 237996) M. K. GANDHI
('29', 113, 6, 40, 238009) From a photostat: G.N. 5597

('29', 114, 9, 20, 239117) Whatever befell Jadabharat, he suffered it calmly.
('29', 114, 9, 21, 239168) You are going not as Rudra, but as Vishnu.
('29', 114, 9, 22, 239211) The question is not what the Maulana should do, but what I, i.e., you should do.

('29', 114, 9, 24, 239424) You will assist me in this whole heartedly.
('29', 114, 9, 25, 239468) Do it believing that such action alone would become us.

('29', 117, 7, 12, 243532) 90. NOTES
('29', 117, 8, 13, 243542) THE COMING FIFTEENTH
('29', 117, 9, 14, 243563) The second month of spinning will soon be upon us.
('29', 117, 9, 15, 243614) The spinners for the first month, representatives and others, were 2,780. Legitimate excuses have been received from many places and persons.
('29', 117, 9, 16, 243756) Some did not even know that non representatives had to send yarn at all.
('29', 117, 9, 17, 243829) The second month therefore should see very considerable improvement in all the provinces.
('29', 117, 9, 18, 243919) Will all the spinners bear the following in mind?
('29', 117, 9, 19, 243969) 1. To send uniform yarn.
('29', 117, 9, 20, 243994) Whenever good cotton and good slivers are procurable, attempt should be made not to spin below 20 counts.
('29', 117, 9, 21, 244100) The same spinners have sent a variety of counts.
('29', 117, 9, 22, 244149) Let every spinner bear in mind that counts cannot be mixed for weaving purposes.
('29', 117, 9, 23, 244230) 2. Each hank should be not more than 500 yards.
('29', 117, 9, 24, 244278) Each hank should be divided into strands of 100 yards as nearly as may be and properly leased, i.e., tied with a strong string.
('29', 117, 9, 25, 244406) This is very essential for weavers who have to undo the hanks and wind the yarn on bobbins.
('29', 117, 9, 26, 244498) If the yarn is all in a tangle, it is almost impossible to unwind it.
('29', 117, 9, 27, 244568) Leases are intended to enable the bobbin winder to trace a missing thread
('29', 118, 0, 1, 244642) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 119
('29', 118, 1, 2, 244690) without difficulty.
('29', 118, 1, 3, 244710) He can do so easily if he has to search only 100 threads at a time.
('29', 118, 1, 4, 244778) 3. It will advance the durability of yarn if it is sprayed before taking it off the winder.
('29', 118, 1, 5, 244870) 4. The number of yards and weight and count should be noted on each hank of uniform yarn.
('29', 118, 1, 6, 244960) The way to find the count easily is to divide the yards by 21 and its weight in tolas.
('29', 118, 1, 7, 245047) Thus if a hank of 840
('29', 118, 2, 8, 245069) yards weighs one tola, the yarn is
('29', 118, 3, 9, 245104) 840 21x1 40 = counts.
('29', 118, 3, 10, 245126) If its weight be _ tola the yarn is
('29', 118, 4, 11, 245162) 840x2 21x1 = 80 counts.
('29', 118, 4, 12, 245186) Needless to say, in finding counts, fractions should be ignored.
('29', 118, 4, 13, 245251) 5. Members have been found to send unwound yarn pulled off the spindle.
('29', 118, 4, 14, 245323) It is most difficult to treat it after it is so pulled off.
('29', 118, 4, 15, 245383) If it is to be of use for weaving it must be hanked and properly leased as advised above.
('29', 118, 4, 16, 245473) It may be stated here that one or two spinners have not hesitated to send mill spun yarn.
('29', 118, 4, 17, 245563) I hope that these gentlemen have done so not knowing what they had to do.
('29', 118, 4, 18, 245637) There is no difficulty in detecting mill spun yarn.
('29', 118, 4, 19, 245689) The virtue lies not in sending any yarn but in sending good even yarn of one’s own spinning.
('29', 118, 4, 20, 245782) All parcels should be sent to Sabarmati and not to Ahmedabad and should be sent carriage paid.
('29', 118, 5, 21, 245877) SOME MORE FIGURES
('29', 118, 6, 22, 245895) Since the publication of the returns of yarn, more parcels have been received from Andhra and Tamilnad which show that the response in both these provinces is much better than appeared from the figures already published.
('29', 118, 6, 23, 246116) The Andhra total is 487, the Tamilnad total is 195. The total weight of yarn received was 23 maunds and 23 pounds.
('29', 118, 6, 24, 246231) Of this Gujarat contributed 13 maunds and the other provinces the rest.
('29', 118, 6, 25, 246303) The highest count reached was 100—not a bad record.
('29', 118, 6, 26, 246355) Our mills do not spin with rare exceptions more than 40 counts.
('29', 118, 6, 27, 246419) The spinners should remember that when labour is voluntary, it means a great saving of money to spin fine counts.
('29', 118, 6, 28, 246533) Thus if a spinner spins 20 counts instead of 10, he would save almost half the price of cotton.
('29', 118, 6, 29, 246629) It would be well therefore to attempt finer counts as soon as the fingers and the eyes are sufficiently trained.
('29', 118, 6, 30, 246742) According to religion over 40 Mussalmans and as many Parsis
('29', 119, 0, 1, 246802) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 119, 1, 2, 246844) the names.
('29', 119, 1, 3, 246855) Of the A.I.C.C. members 104 have sent in their quota.
('29', 119, 1, 4, 246909) Of the Working Committee all but 3 have sent in their quota.
('29', 119, 1, 5, 246970) Of the most noted ones outside the A.I.C.C. to send are Maulana Abdul Bari Sahib and Acharya P. C. Ray.
('29', 119, 2, 6, 247074) NON REPRESENTATIVES
('29', 119, 3, 7, 247094) It is not yet generally realized that, whilst it is obligatory on Congress representatives to spin regularly, the others who believe in the virtue of spinning are not free from that duty.
('29', 119, 3, 8, 247282) The A.I.C.C. resolution is but an indication of what every patriot should do.
('29', 119, 3, 9, 247360) If therefore all the provinces would organize themselves for voluntary spinning, they will soon find that the boycott of foreign cloth is a comparatively simple matter.
('29', 119, 3, 10, 247529) The two obstacles in the way are said to be the dearness and the coarseness of khaddar.
('29', 119, 3, 11, 247617) Both these can be completely disposed of, immediately spinning becomes a labour of love—not a very great price to pay for achieving a purpose for which we have been striving ever since the days of the late Shastri Chiplunkar and the Bengal partition.
('29', 119, 3, 12, 247868) Nor need members wait for the provincial committees to organize spinning.
('29', 119, 3, 13, 247942) Any person with sufficient knowledge and energy may organize a spinning club.
('29', 119, 3, 14, 248020) It requires very little outlay of money.
('29', 119, 3, 15, 248061) A little storing of cotton, preparing and distribution of slivers and collecting yarn is all that is required.
('29', 119, 3, 16, 248172) Not much space is required.
('29', 119, 3, 17, 248200) The poorest can attempt the work.
('29', 119, 3, 18, 248234) The wheelless spinning answers where a spinning wheel is unobtainable.
('29', 119, 3, 19, 248305) I hope therefore that not only will the second month’s returns show a marked rise in the number of representatives spinning, but that there will be a great increase in the returns from non representatives.
('29', 119, 4, 20, 248511) THE RIGHT THING
('29', 119, 5, 21, 248527) It was a fortunate thing that Sheth Jamnalalji found himself in the midst of the Hindu Muslim fighting last week.
('29', 119, 5, 22, 248641) The injury sustained by him was probably one of the causes if not the cause that arrested the progress of the fight.
('29', 119, 5, 23, 248758) I understand that Babu Kali Charan, the secretary of the local Congress Committee and Mr. Avari were also trying to prevent the fight at great personal risk.
('29', 119, 5, 24, 248916) I congratulate these three workers on their courage and sanity.
('29', 119, 5, 25, 248980) It may be necessary for some of us to lose our lives so that we may gain lasting peace.
('29', 119, 5, 26, 249068) It is not to be attained within our generation by organizing the worst elements of society against one another.
('29', 119, 5, 27, 249180) Such mutual strife is a process of
('29', 120, 0, 1, 249215) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 121
('29', 120, 1, 2, 249263) exhaustion.
('29', 120, 1, 3, 249275) And peace obtained by it is an armed peace requiring prolonged fighting.
('29', 120, 2, 4, 249348) VYKOM SATYAGRAHA
('29', 120, 3, 5, 249365) I tender my congratulations to the Maharani Regent of Travancore on her generosity in releasing all the satyagrahi prisoners.
('29', 120, 3, 6, 249491) It is a pretty custom for a State to release a certain number of prisoners on a new head occupying the gadi.
('29', 120, 3, 7, 249600) What can be more natural than that those prisoners who have no criminal taint in them should be released?
('29', 120, 3, 8, 249706) I tender too my congratulations to the satyagrahis on suspending satyagraha for the time being.
('29', 120, 3, 9, 249802) It paves the way for an understanding and enables the State authorities to review their attitude towards the satyagrahis without embarrassment.

('29', 129, 1, 10, 273060) As the reader will remember, I am in this matter a complete convert to Babu Bhagwandas’s 1 view.
('29', 129, 1, 11, 273157) I would therefore join any such conference, if my presence was required, and assist at framing the scheme.
('29', 129, 1, 12, 273264) The reason for insisting on this matter being treated as an activity outside the Congress is to keep the Congress purely for internal development for full one year.
('29', 129, 1, 13, 273429) When we have achieved a measure of success commensurate with the task before us, the Congress may function for outside political activity.
('29', 129, 1, 14, 273568) What if the proposal is not accepted and it is found difficult to bring together all parties on the Congress platform and to heal the breach between the Swarajists and ourselves?
('29', 129, 1, 15, 273747) My answer is simple.
('29', 129, 1, 16, 273768) If the whole fight is for ‘‘capturing” the Congress, I must refuse to enter upon it.
('29', 129, 1, 17, 273853) I would advise all who think with me to do likewise.
('29', 129, 1, 18, 273906) I would advise handing the Congress over to the Swarajists on their terms and leave the Swarajists to work the Councils programme unhampered by any counter propaganda.
('29', 129, 1, 19, 274074) I would engage the No changers purely on the constructive programme and advise them to seek such help from the other parties as they can give.
('29', 129, 1, 20, 274217) Those who depend for national regeneration solely on the constructive programme may be expected to lead in the matter of self sacrifice.
('29', 129, 1, 21, 274354) Not one of the things we hold dear can be achieved by trying to retain power in the Congress in opposition to the Swarajists.
('29', 129, 1, 22, 274480) We must hold it on their sufferance.
('29', 129, 1, 23, 274517) Both parties will be guilty of corrupting the simple people who worship the name”Congress”, if
('29', 129, 2, 24, 274612) 1 Scholar and public worker; took a leading part in establishing Kashi Vidyapith, a national university at Banaras
('29', 130, 0, 1, 274727) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 131
('29', 130, 1, 2, 274775) they are made at our bidding to engage in a suicidal tug of war.
('29', 130, 1, 3, 274840) Power that comes from service faithfully rendered ennobles.
('29', 130, 1, 4, 274900) Power that is sought in the name of service and can only be obtained by a majority of votes is a delusion and a snare to be avoided, especially at the present moment.
('29', 130, 1, 5, 275067) Whether I have convinced the reader of the soundness of my proposal or not my mind is made up.
('29', 130, 1, 6, 275162) It hurts me to think that those with whom I have hitherto worked hand in glove should be working in a seemingly opposite direction.
('29', 130, 1, 7, 275294) What I have sketched above is not conditions of surrender.
('29', 130, 1, 8, 275353) Mine is an unconditional surrender.
('29', 130, 1, 9, 275389) I would guide the Congress next year only if all parties wish me to.
('29', 130, 1, 10, 275458) I am trying to see daylight out of this impenetrable darkness.
('29', 130, 1, 11, 275521) I seem to see it dimly.

('29', 130, 1, 13, 275571) All I know is that there is no fight left in me.
('29', 130, 1, 14, 275620) This is much for a born fighter to say.
('29', 130, 1, 15, 275660) I have fought my dearest ones.

('29', 130, 1, 23, 275970) The Congress must, for sometime to come at least, remain largely a homogeneous body.
('29', 130, 1, 24, 276055) Young India, 11 9 1924
('29', 130, 2, 25, 276078) 92. MY JAIL EXPERIENCES—XI [Continued]
('29', 130, 3, 26, 276117) WHAT I READ—2
('29', 130, 4, 27, 276131) My Urdu studies proved as absorbing as the reading of Mahabharata.
('29', 130, 4, 28, 276198) They grew on me as I proceeded.
('29', 130, 4, 29, 276230) I approached this study with a light heart foolishly imagining that in two or three months I should be quite an adept in Urdu.
('29', 130, 4, 30, 276357) But to my sorrow I discovered that it had been made into a language distinct from Hindi and that the tendency was growing in that direction.
('29', 130, 4, 31, 276498) But that discovery only made me more determined than ever to be able to read and understand Urdu literature.
('29', 130, 4, 32, 276607) I therefore gave nearly three hours per day to Urdu reading.
('29', 130, 4, 33, 276668) The Urdu writers have purposely gone out of their way to use Arabic or Persian words even to the rejection of words current among Hindus and Mussalmans.
('29', 130, 4, 34, 276821) They have rejected even the common grammar and imported Arabic or Persian grammar.
('29', 130, 4, 35, 276904) The result is that the poor nationalist if he will keep in touch with the Mussalman thought, must study Urdu as a separate, new language.
('29', 131, 0, 1, 277042) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 131, 1, 2, 277084) The Hindi writers I know have done no better or no less.
('29', 131, 1, 3, 277141) Only I thought that the evil had not gone very deep and the separatist tendency was a mere passing phase.
('29', 131, 1, 4, 277247) Now I see that if we are to have a common national language being a mixture of Hindi and Urdu, special and prolonged effort will have to be made to effect a juncture between the two streams which seem at present to be diverging more and more one from the other.
('29', 131, 1, 5, 277509) In spite however of the difficulty I retain the opinion that it is necessary for a Hindu to complete his education to know literary Urdu as it is for a Mussalman to know literary Hindi.
('29', 131, 1, 6, 277695) It is easy enough if begun early.
('29', 131, 1, 7, 277729) This study may have no pecuniary value, it may not open up the treasures of Western knowledge.
('29', 131, 1, 8, 277824) But its national value is beyond compare.
('29', 131, 1, 9, 277866) I am the richer for my close study of Urdu.
('29', 131, 1, 10, 277910) I wish I could even now complete it.
('29', 131, 1, 11, 277947) I know the Mussalman mind much better than I did two years ago.
('29', 131, 1, 12, 278011) I was interested in the religious side of Urdu literature and therefore plunged, as soon as I was able, into Urdu religious books.
('29', 131, 1, 13, 278142) Fates have always favoured me.
('29', 131, 1, 14, 278173) Maulana Hasrat Mohani 1 had sent to Mr. Mansar Ali Leaves from the Lives of the Companions of the Prophet.
('29', 131, 1, 15, 278280) As he was teaching me Urdu he passed the volumes on to me.
('29', 131, 1, 16, 278339) And I went through them with the greatest diligence.
('29', 131, 1, 17, 278392) The volumes, though they contain repetitions and would gain in lucidity for compression, were to me deeply interesting for the insight they gave me into the doings of the Prophet’s many companions.
('29', 131, 1, 18, 278590) How their lives were transformed as if by magic, what devotion they showed to the Prophet, how utterly unmindful they became of worldly wealth, how they used power itself for showing the utter simplicity of their lives, how they were untouched by the lust for gold, how reckless they were of their own lives in a cause they held sacred, is all told with a wealth of detail that carries conviction with it.
('29', 131, 1, 19, 278996) When one notes their lives and then the lives of the present day representatives of Islam in India, one is inclined to shed a tear of bitter grief.
('29', 131, 1, 20, 279144) I passed from the companions to the Prophet himself.
('29', 131, 1, 21, 279197) The two bulky volumes written by Maulana Shibli are a creditable performance.
('29', 131, 1, 22, 279275) But I have the same complaints about them that I have lodged about the diffuseness of the volumes devoted to the companions.
('29', 131, 1, 23, 279400) But the diffuseness did not interfere with my interest to know how a Mussalman had treated the incidents of the life of one
('29', 131, 2, 24, 279524) 1 1875 1951; nationalist Muslim leader, took active part in the Khilafat movement
('29', 132, 0, 1, 279606) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 133
('29', 132, 1, 2, 279654) who has been almost uniformly maligned and abused in the West.
('29', 132, 1, 3, 279717) When I closed the second volume, I was sorry there was not more for me to read of that great life.
('29', 132, 1, 4, 279816) There are incidents in it which I do not understand, there are some I cannot explain.
('29', 132, 1, 5, 279902) But I did not approach the study as a critic or a scoffer.
('29', 132, 1, 6, 279961) I wanted to know the best of the life of one who holds today undisputed away over the hearts of millions of mankind.
('29', 132, 1, 7, 280078) And I found enough in the volumes to account for it.
('29', 132, 1, 8, 280131) I became more than ever convinced that it was not the sword that won a place for Islam in those days in the scheme of life.
('29', 132, 1, 9, 280255) It was the rigid simplicity, the utter self effacement of the Prophet, the scrupulous regard for pledges, his intense devotion to his friends and followers, his intrepidity, his fearlessness, his absolute trust in God and his own mission.
('29', 132, 1, 10, 280494) These and not the sword carried everything before them and surmounted every obstacle.
('29', 132, 1, 11, 280580) As I do not regard any human being absolutely perfect, be he a prophet or an avatar, it is unnecessary for me to be able to explain to the censor’s satisfaction every detail of the Prophet’s life.
('29', 132, 1, 12, 280777) It is enough for me to know that he was a man among millions who tried to walk in the fear of God died a poor man, wanted no grand mausoleum for his mortal remains and who did not forget even on his death bed the least of his creditors.
('29', 132, 1, 13, 281014) The teaching of the Prophet is no more responsible for the degrading intolerance or questionable proselytizing methods that one sees around himself than Hinduism is responsible for the degradation and intolerance of present day Hindus.
('29', 132, 1, 14, 281250) From the Prophet I passed to the two volumes devoted to the life of Umar the unconquerable.
('29', 132, 1, 15, 281342) As I pictured him before my mental eye walking to Jerusalem upbraiding some of his followers for aping the pomp of their neighbours, refusing to pray in a Christian church lest succeeding generations might claim to convert it into a mosque, granting the most liberal terms to the conquered Christians, and as I picture him declaring that the word of a follower of Islam, though pledged by one not authorized thereto, was as good as the written decree of the great Caliph himself, he commands my humble respect.
('29', 132, 1, 16, 281853) His was an iron will.
('29', 132, 1, 17, 281875) He weighed out the same justice to his daughter that he would weigh to an utter stranger.
('29', 132, 1, 18, 281965) I fancy I understand the breaking of idols and wanton desecration of temples, the thoughtless intolerance of Hindu music now going on in our midst.
('29', 132, 1, 19, 282113) These acts seem to me to be due to an utter misreading of the events in the life of the greatest of the Caliphs.
('29', 132, 1, 20, 282226) I fear that the acts of this great and just man are being presented to the Mussalman masses in a most
('29', 133, 0, 1, 282328) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 133, 1, 2, 282370) distorted fashion.
('29', 133, 1, 3, 282389) I know that if he rose from his grave, he would disown the many acts of the so called followers of Islam which are a crude caricature of those of the great Umar himself.
('29', 133, 2, 4, 282559) From this entrancing study, I went to the philosophical volumes called Al Kalam.
('29', 133, 2, 5, 282640) These are difficult to understand.
('29', 133, 2, 6, 282675) The language is highly technical.
('29', 133, 2, 7, 282709) Mr. Abdul Gani however made my study fairly easy.
('29', 133, 2, 8, 282759) I was only sorry, my illness interrupted my study when I had only half finished the volumes.
('29', 133, 3, 9, 282852) Of the English books Gobbon[’s] 1 takes easily the first place.
('29', 133, 3, 10, 282916) It was recommended to me years ago by so many English friends.
('29', 133, 3, 11, 282979) I was determined to read Gibbon in the jail this time.
('29', 133, 3, 12, 283034) I was glad of it.
('29', 133, 3, 13, 283052) For me even history has a spiritual significance.
('29', 133, 3, 14, 283102) As the author proceeds to trace the events in the life of the citizens of a single city who built up a world empire, one traces the history of the soul.
('29', 133, 3, 15, 283255) For Gibbon does not deal with trifles, he deals with vast masses of facts and arrays them before you in his own inimitable way.
('29', 133, 3, 16, 283383) He deals with three civilizations, Pagan, Christian and Islamic, in sufficient detail to enable you to frame your own conclusions.
('29', 133, 3, 17, 283514) His own compel attention.
('29', 133, 3, 18, 283540) But he is as a historian jealous of his calling, faithful enough to give you all his data so as to enable you to judge for yourself.
('29', 133, 4, 19, 283673) Motley is another type.
('29', 133, 4, 20, 283697) Gibbon traces the decay of a mighty empire.
('29', 133, 4, 21, 283741) Motley extracts from a little republic the life of his hero.
('29', 133, 4, 22, 283802) Gibbon’s heroes are subservient to the story of a mighty empire.
('29', 133, 4, 23, 283867) Motley’s story of a State is subservient to that of one single life.
('29', 133, 4, 24, 283936) The republic merges in William the Silent.
('29', 133, 5, 25, 283979) Add to these two Lord Rosebery’s Life of Pitt.
('29', 133, 5, 26, 284026) And you are perhaps then prepared to draw with me the conclusion that the dividing line between fact and fiction is very thin indeed and that even facts have at least two sides or as lawyers say facts are after all opinions.
('29', 133, 5, 27, 284251) However I have no desire to engage the reader’s attention upon my speculations on the value of history considered as an aid to the evolution of our race.
('29', 133, 5, 28, 284405) I believe in the saying that a nation is happy that has no history.
('29', 133, 5, 29, 284473) It is my pet theory that our Hindu ancestors solved the question for us by ignoring history as it is understood today and by building on slight events their philosophical structure.
('29', 133, 5, 30, 284655) Such is the Mahabharata.
('29', 133, 5, 31, 284680) And I look upon Gibbon and Motley as inferior edi tions of the Mahabharata.
('29', 133, 5, 32, 284756) The immortal but unknown author of the
('29', 133, 6, 33, 284795) 1 The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
('29', 134, 0, 1, 284838) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 135
('29', 134, 1, 2, 284886) Mahabharata weaves into his story sufficient of the supernatural to warn you against taking him literally.
('29', 134, 1, 3, 284993) Gibbon and Motley are unnece ssarily at pains to tell you they are giving you facts and nothing but facts.
('29', 134, 1, 4, 285100) Lord Rosebery comes to the rescue and tells you that even the last words said to have been uttered by Pitt are disputed by his butler.
('29', 134, 1, 5, 285235) The substance of all these stories is: Names and forms matter little, they come and go.
('29', 134, 1, 6, 285323) That which is permanent and therefore necessary eludes the historian of events.
('29', 134, 1, 7, 285403) Truth transcends history.

('29', 139, 7, 13, 292558) BHAI SANMUKHRAI, In order to observe brahmacharya the following things are absolutely necessary: (1) Solitude; (2) moderation in eating; (3) good books; (4) regular meditation; (5) plenty of physical and mental labour; (6) abstaining from spicy and intoxicating food or drinks; (7) abstaining from shows and other things having a sex appeal; (8) giving up the desire for sexual intercourse; (9) avoiding being alone with a woman; (10) repeating Ramanama or some other mantra [formula]

('29', 140, 5, 10, 293505) 104. HINDU MUSLIM UNITY
('29', 140, 6, 11, 293529) [September 14, 1924]
('29', 140, 7, 12, 293550) An important article by Mr. Gandhi on the Hindu Muslim tension in the last issue of Navajivan is translated below for the benefit of the readers of Young India.
('29', 140, 7, 13, 293711) I had occasion whilst addressing a public meeting at Surat 2 to refer to the question of Hindu Muslim unity in detail, as some friends there wanted to know my views about sangathan.
('29', 140, 7, 14, 293893) After the meeting I had a letter from a Mussalman friend offering suggestions for the solution of the question.
('29', 140, 7, 15, 294005) I now see that even Gujarat is not quite free from the dangers of communal disturbances.
('29', 140, 7, 16, 294094) The Visnagar affair can hardly be said to be yet settled.
('29', 140, 7, 17, 294152) There is some trouble in Mandal.
('29', 140, 7, 18, 294185) There was fear of a little disturbance in Ahmedabad.
('29', 140, 7, 19, 294238) Some trouble is apprehended in Umreth.
('29', 140, 7, 20, 294277) Other parts (e.g., Bhagalpur in Bihar) are also in the same plight.
('29', 140, 7, 21, 294345) The question of Hindu Muslim unity is getting more and more serious every day.
('29', 140, 7, 22, 294424) One thing should be made clear at the outset.
('29', 140, 7, 23, 294470) In the case of many of these disturbances, we hear of Government agents being at the back of them.
('29', 140, 7, 24, 294569) The allegation, if true, would be painful to
('29', 140, 8, 25, 294614) 1 In reply to his telegram of September 13 as correspondent of Servant which read:”.
('29', 140, 8, 26, 294699) we understand that you are either going to accept the Swarajist programme including their taking up offices and you remaining satisfied with constructive programme, or you are abandoning the Congress altogether.
('29', 140, 8, 27, 294911) We do not know your plan.
('29', 140, 8, 28, 294937) So long as you are in the Congress, No changers have to try to capture office.
('29', 140, 8, 29, 295016) Hence there is constant friction.
('29', 140, 8, 30, 295050) When you are out, No changers are free to come out with a clean conscience....
('29', 140, 8, 31, 295129) Under the circumstances, we, your followers, think it would be best for you and your followers to give up the Congress and form an independent association.
('29', 140, 8, 32, 295285) .” 2 Vide”Speech at Public Meeting, Surat”, 5 9 1924.
('29', 141, 0, 1, 295339) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 141, 1, 2, 295381) me, not surprising.
('29', 141, 1, 3, 295401) It should not be surprising if the Government fomented the troubles, it being their policy to divide us.
('29', 141, 1, 4, 295506) It would be painful because of the necessary implication that neither of the communities realizes wherein lies its interest.
('29', 141, 1, 5, 295631) Only those can be set by the ears by a third party, who are in the habit of quarrelling.
('29', 141, 1, 6, 295720) Government has never been heard of having fomented a quarrel, say, between the Brahmins and Banias, nor amongst the Sunni Mussalmans.
('29', 141, 1, 7, 295854) The suspicion or fear of their having set the Hindus and Mussalmans by the ears is always entertained, because both have quarrelled so often.
('29', 141, 1, 8, 295996) It is this habit of quarrelling that needs to be abandoned if we want to have swaraj and retain it.
('29', 141, 2, 9, 296096) Quarrels must break out so long as the Hindus continue to be seized with fear.
('29', 141, 2, 10, 296175) Bullies are always to be found where there are cowards.
('29', 141, 2, 11, 296231) The Hindus must understand that no one can afford them protection, if they go on hugging fear.
('29', 141, 2, 12, 296326) Fear of man argues want of faith in God.
('29', 141, 2, 13, 296367) Only he trusts to his physical strength who has no faith or very little faith in God’s omnipresence.
('29', 141, 2, 14, 296468) The Hindu must cultivate either of these two—faith in God or faith in one’s physical might.
('29', 141, 2, 15, 296560) If he does neither, it will spell the ruin of the community.
('29', 141, 3, 16, 296621) The first, viz., reliance on God and shaking off the fear of man is the way of non violence and the best way.
('29', 141, 3, 17, 296731) The second, viz., reliance on one’s physical might is the way of violence.
('29', 141, 3, 18, 296806) Both have a place in the world.
('29', 141, 3, 19, 296838) It is open to us to choose either.
('29', 141, 3, 20, 296873) One man cannot try both at the same time.
('29', 141, 3, 21, 296915) If all the Hindus and Mussalmans both elect the way of violence, we had better cease to talk of winning swaraj in the immediate future.
('29', 141, 3, 22, 297051) Armed peace means not a little fighting that will end with the breaking of a few heads or of a dozen temples.
('29', 141, 3, 23, 297161) It must mean prolonged fighting and rivers of blood.
('29', 141, 3, 24, 297214) I am against sangathan, and I am not.
('29', 141, 3, 25, 297252) If sangathan means opening akhadas and organizing the Hindu hooligans through them, I would regard it as a pitiable condition.
('29', 141, 3, 26, 297379) You cannot defend yourself and your religion with the help of hooligans.
('29', 141, 3, 27, 297452) It is substituting one peril for another, and even adding another.
('29', 141, 3, 28, 297519) I would have nothing to say against akhadas, if they were used by the Brahmins, Banias and others for the development of their physique.
('29', 141, 3, 29, 297656) Akhadas as akhadas are un exceptionable.
('29', 141, 3, 30, 297697) But I have no doubt that they are no good for giving a training to fight the Mussalmans.
('29', 141, 3, 31, 297786) It will take years to acquire the physical strength to fight.
('29', 141, 4, 32, 297848) The akhada is therefore not the way.
('29', 141, 4, 33, 297885) We will have to go in for tapasya, for self purification, if we want to win the hearts of
('29', 142, 0, 1, 297975) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 143
('29', 142, 1, 2, 298023) Mussalmans.
('29', 142, 1, 3, 298035) We shall have to cast off all the evil in us.
('29', 142, 1, 4, 298081) If they attack us, we shall have to learn not to return blow for blow, but bravely to face death—not to die a craven death leaving wife and children behind, but to receive their blows and meet death cheerfully.
('29', 142, 1, 5, 298292) I would tender the same advice to the Mussalmans.
('29', 142, 1, 6, 298342) But it is unnecessary, as the average Mussalman has been assumed to be a bully.
('29', 142, 1, 7, 298422) The general impression is that the Mussalmans can fight and fight well.
('29', 142, 1, 8, 298494) I do not, therefore, need to tell them how they should defend themselves from the attacks of the Hindus; on the contrary I have to appeal to them to forbear.
('29', 142, 1, 9, 298652) I have to appeal to them to get the goonda element under control and to behave peaceably.
('29', 142, 1, 10, 298742) The Mussalmans may regard the Hindus as a menace in other matters.
('29', 142, 1, 11, 298809) They do regard them as an economic menace.
('29', 142, 1, 12, 298852) They do dread the Hindus’ interference with their religious rites on the Bakri i Id day.
('29', 142, 1, 13, 298941) But they are in no fear of being beaten by the Hindus.
('29', 142, 1, 14, 298996) I will therefore tell them only this:”You cannot protect Islam with the lathi or the sword.
('29', 142, 1, 15, 299088) The age of the lathi is gone.
('29', 142, 1, 16, 299118) A religion will be tested by the purity of its adherents.
('29', 142, 1, 17, 299176) If you leave it to the goondas to defend your faith 1, you will do serious harm to Islam.
('29', 142, 1, 18, 299266) Islam will, in that case, no longer remain the faith of the fakirs and worshipers of Allah.” I have up to now confined myself to giving general advice.
('29', 142, 1, 19, 299418) Maulana Hasrat Mohani told me that the Mussalmans ought to protect the cow for the sake of the Hindus, and Hindus should cease to regard the Mussalmans as untouchables, as he said they are regarded in North India.
('29', 142, 1, 20, 299632) I told him:”I will not bargain with you in this matter.
('29', 142, 1, 21, 299688) If the Mussalmans think it their duty to protect the cow for the sake of Hindus, they may do so, irrespective of how the Hindus behave towards them.
('29', 142, 1, 22, 299837) I think it is sin for a Hindu to look upon a Mussalman as an untouchable, and the Hindu ought not to do so, irrespective of a Mussalman killing or sparing the cow.
('29', 142, 1, 23, 300001) The Mussalman ought to be no more untouchable to a Hindu than a Hindu of any of the four castes is to one of the other.
('29', 142, 1, 24, 300121) I regard these things as axiomatic.
('29', 142, 1, 25, 300157) If Hinduism teaches hatred of Islam or of non Hindus, it is doomed to destruction.
('29', 142, 1, 26, 300240) Each community should then put its house in order without bargaining with the other.
('29', 142, 1, 27, 300325) To nurse enmity against the Mussalman, for the sake of saving the cow, is a sure way to kill the cow, and doubly sinful.
('29', 142, 1, 28, 300446) Hinduism will not be destroyed by a non Hindu killing a cow.
('29', 142, 1, 29, 300507) The Hindu’s religion consists in saving

('29', 143, 1, 2, 300614) the cow, but it can never be his religion to save the cow by a resort to force towards a non Hindu.
('29', 143, 1, 3, 300714) The Hindus want swaraj in India and not a Hindu Raj.
('29', 143, 1, 4, 300767) Even if there was a Hindu Raj, and toleration one of its features, there would be place in it for Mussalmans as well as Christians; it would redound to the credit of Hinduism, if stopping of cow slaughter was brought about not by force, but as deliberate voluntary act of self denial on the part of Mussalmans and others.
('29', 143, 1, 5, 301089) I would therefore deem it unpatriotic even to nurse a dream of a Hindu Raj.”
('29', 143, 2, 6, 301166) Then there is the trouble about music.
('29', 143, 2, 7, 301205) It is fast growing every day.
('29', 143, 2, 8, 301235) A letter I had in Surat says that, as it is not obligatory on a Hindu to play music, he should stop it before mosques to spare the feelings of the Mussulmans.
('29', 143, 2, 9, 301394) I wish the question was as simple as the correspondent thinks.
('29', 143, 2, 10, 301457) But it is the opposite of simple.
('29', 143, 2, 11, 301491) Not a single Hindu religious ceremony can be performed without the accomp animent of music.
('29', 143, 2, 12, 301583) Some ceremonies require the accompaniment of continuous music.
('29', 143, 2, 13, 301646) No doubt, even here due regard ought to be had for the feelings of the Mussalmans.
('29', 143, 2, 14, 301729) The music may in such cases be less noisy.
('29', 143, 2, 15, 301772) But all this can be and ought to be done on the basis of”give and take”.
('29', 143, 2, 16, 301845) Having talked with a number of Mussalmans in the matter, I know that Islam does not make it obligatory for a Mussalman to prevent a non Mussalman from playing music near mosques.
('29', 143, 2, 17, 302024) Nor is such a thing on the part of a non Mussalman calculated to injure Islam.
('29', 143, 2, 18, 302103) Music should never, therefore, be a bone of contention.

('29', 143, 3, 20, 302255) This is clearly intolerable.
('29', 143, 3, 21, 302284) What is readily yielded to courtesy is never yielded to force.
('29', 143, 3, 22, 302347) Submission to a courteous request is religion, submission to force is irreligion.
('29', 143, 3, 23, 302429) If the Hindus stop music for fear of a beating from the Mussalmans, they cease to be Hindus.
('29', 143, 3, 24, 302522) The general rule in this respect may be said to be this, that where the Hindus have long been deliberately observing the custom to stop music before mosques, they must not break it.
('29', 143, 3, 25, 302704) But where they have been playing music without interference, the practice should continue.
('29', 143, 3, 26, 302795) Where trouble is apprehended and facts are disputed, both communities ought to refer the matter to arbitration.
('29', 143, 4, 27, 302907) Where a court of law has prohibited music, the Hindus should not take the law in their own hands.
('29', 143, 4, 28, 303005) And the Mussalmans should not insist on stopping music by force.

('29', 144, 1, 2, 303118) Where the Mussalrnans refuse to yield, or where the Hindus apprehend violence, and where there is no prohibition by a court of law the Hindus must take out their processions with music accompanying, and put up with all the beating inflicted on them.
('29', 144, 1, 3, 303368) All those who join processions or who form the musical band must thus sacrifice themselves.
('29', 144, 1, 4, 303460) They will thereby defend their Faith and their self respect.
('29', 144, 1, 5, 303521) Where the Hindus are unequal to this soul force, it is open to them to resort to force in self defence.
('29', 144, 1, 6, 303625) Where death without resistance or death after resistance is the only way, neither party should think of resorting to law courts or help from Government.
('29', 144, 1, 7, 303778) Even if one of the parties resorts to such aid, the other should refrain.
('29', 144, 1, 8, 303852) If resort to law courts cannot be avoided, there ought to be at least no resort to false evidence.
('29', 144, 1, 9, 303951) It is the rule of honourable combat that, after having heartily given and taken blows both the parties quiet down, and seek no reinforcement from outside.
('29', 144, 1, 10, 304106) There should be no bitterness or feeling of revenge behind.
('29', 144, 1, 11, 304166) A quarrel should in no case be carried from one street to another.
('29', 144, 1, 12, 304233) The fair sex, the aged and the infirm, children and all, non combatants ought to be free from molestation.
('29', 144, 1, 13, 304340) Fighting would be regarded as sportsmanlike if these rules are observed.
('29', 144, 2, 14, 304413) I hope that the Hindus and Mussalmans in Gujarat will keep their heads cool and keep the peace.
('29', 144, 2, 15, 304509) I hope also that the fear of a possible trouble in Umreth is unjustified.
('29', 144, 2, 16, 304583) Let both the communities there hold mutual consultations and settle their differences amicably.
('29', 144, 3, 17, 304679) Running away for fear of death leaving one’s dear ones, temples or music to take care of themselves.

('29', 144, 3, 21, 304885) The coward is innocent of it.
