('29', 202, 1, 2, 420889) 152.”ADHARMA” FOR DHARMA
('29', 202, 2, 3, 420914) A brother asks :
('29', 202, 3, 4, 420931) If someone indulges in gambling for the sake of Malabar Relief and offers his takings to the Malabar people, would this gambling be proper or improper?
('29', 202, 3, 5, 421083) Will you accept or refuse that money?
('29', 202, 4, 6, 421121) Gambling is wholly despicable.
('29', 202, 4, 7, 421152) If relief work cannot be paid for without gambling, let millions die of starvation.
('29', 202, 4, 8, 421236) Adharma 1 can never lead to dharma.
('29', 202, 4, 9, 421272) I would, therefore, ask everyone to refrain from gambling even for the relief of sufferers in Malabar.
('29', 202, 4, 10, 421375) The money that is saved by abstaining from gambling may be given to me.
('29', 202, 4, 11, 421447) This will kill two birds with one stone.
('29', 202, 4, 12, 421488) You will protect yourself from a vice and the money that might have been wasted over the vice will be utilized for the sake of those who need it.
('29', 202, 4, 13, 421634) How can a man think of gambling when he is concerned about a calamity?
('29', 202, 4, 14, 421705) He will rather feed the hungry by starving himself.
('29', 202, 5, 15, 421757) The questioner gives a vivid picture of gambling that is going on at Karamala town in Orpad tahsil and says that even boys indulge in it.
('29', 202, 5, 16, 421895) Occasionally there are altercations.
('29', 202, 5, 17, 421932) The questioner also seeks a remedy for this evil.
('29', 202, 5, 18, 421982) The remedy lies in cultivating local public opinion.
('29', 202, 5, 19, 422035) Public opinion has a miraculous effect on vices.
('29', 202, 5, 20, 422084) Just as burglars, etc., disappear when it dawns, similarly, when the sun of public opinion rises, vices disappear.
('29', 202, 5, 21, 422199) If the majority of people at some place are gamblers and only a few are free from the vice, these should warn the townsfolk and if the vice still persists, they should migrate from the town.

('29', 203, 4, 11, 422951) 154. TEST OF FAITH
('29', 203, 5, 12, 422970) I feared that the suggestion to abandon boycott would have the effect of disheartening the weaker sections of the schools.
('29', 203, 5, 13, 423093) It looks as if I was right.
('29', 203, 5, 14, 423121) Many teachers have started asking whether the national schools will not now be converted into government schools.
('29', 203, 5, 15, 423235) I have reproduced this extract from a letter.
('29', 203, 5, 16, 423281) In the first place, I have not at all used the word”abandoning”.
('29', 203, 5, 17, 423346) I have suggested suspending the boycott.
('29', 203, 5, 18, 423387) Secondly, the present national schools which are running without Government affiliation should be continued and, if we have the capacity, new national schools may be opened.
('29', 203, 5, 19, 423561) Thirdly, suspension does not mean that those who have spontaneous faith in boycott should give it up.
('29', 203, 5, 20, 423663) My suggestion simply means that those who have undertaken boycott as a matter of Congress discipline, and not out of spontaneous faith, are absolved from the binding for one year.
('29', 203, 5, 21, 423843) And those who on account of the boycott have kept out of the Congress may join it at least for a year and engage themselves in essential work universally approved and educate the people.
('29', 203, 5, 22, 424030) My suggestion provides a test for the public and for individuals.
('29', 203, 5, 23, 424096) If after an experience of four years it is clear that the number of those who have spontaneous faith in boycott is negligible, then the Congress cannot authorize boycott.
('29', 203, 5, 24, 424267) The Congress cannot reflect the wishes of the people, right or wrong, and that alone will entitle it to be called a national organization.
('29', 203, 5, 25, 424406) That which commands the spontaneous faith of a large section can alone deserve to be called the Congress policy and should be implemented as such.
('29', 203, 5, 26, 424553) The number of those who abide by a
('29', 204, 0, 1, 424588) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 205
('29', 204, 1, 2, 424636) particular policy because it has been adopted by the Congress should always be small.
('29', 204, 1, 3, 424722) The Congress cannot be run with the help of such people.
('29', 204, 1, 4, 424779) The Congress is like a prop for them; they can bring no strength to it.
('29', 204, 1, 5, 424851) Persons with spontaneous faith can alone be the backbone of the Congress.
('29', 204, 1, 6, 424925) If the reader undertakes a survey of organizations functioning in the world, he will discover that every living organization fulfils this condition.
('29', 204, 1, 7, 425074) The reason is obvious.
('29', 204, 1, 8, 425097) An organisation has no soul.
('29', 204, 1, 9, 425126) It has no independent existence of its own.
('29', 204, 1, 10, 425170) The organizers are its soul.
('29', 204, 1, 11, 425199) From them it derives its strength.
('29', 204, 1, 12, 425234) The soul of a prohibition council is its crusading members unwaveringly abstaining from liquor.
('29', 204, 1, 13, 425330) A council cannot be expected to strengthen the abstention of members.
('29', 204, 1, 14, 425400) Assuming, however, that they do not get enough members for the council and they have to wind it up, would they start drinking?
('29', 204, 1, 15, 425527) Or would they persevere with their efforts by choosing another region for propagating abstention to the public?
('29', 204, 2, 16, 425639) The plain meaning of my suggestion is that we have no desire to implement boycott by compulsion.
('29', 204, 2, 17, 425736) Compulsion means violence.
('29', 204, 2, 18, 425763) Although our movement entirely eschews force, our minds and our actions harbour force.
('29', 204, 2, 19, 425850) The present bitterness between Hindus and Muslims is positive evidence of this fact.
('29', 204, 2, 20, 425935) The estrangement between Swarajists and No changers is further evidence of the same thing.
('29', 204, 2, 21, 426026) A freedom fighter’s first task is to eliminate this force.
('29', 204, 2, 22, 426085) Just as I define compulsion as violence, freedom is non violence.
('29', 204, 2, 23, 426151) We are afraid of the word non violence.
('29', 204, 2, 24, 426191) We all claim to be lovers of freedom.
('29', 204, 2, 25, 426229) But we are indifferent to non violence or love, which is the source of freedom.
('29', 204, 2, 26, 426309) I have noted this fault in us, recognized my duty in the matter and am trying to explain the issues to the advocates of boycott.
('29', 204, 2, 27, 426438) If a majority of members of the Congress do not approve of boycott spontaneously, it would be violence for advocates of boycott to retain control of the Congress.
('29', 204, 3, 28, 426601) But whether the advocates of boycott retain control of the Congress or boycott is suspended in the Congress, in either case it can never mean that those who have spontaneous faith in boycott should give it up.
('29', 204, 3, 29, 426811) In fact, it is by suspending boycott that we have to ascertain the number of real advocates of boycott.
('29', 204, 3, 30, 426915) If only a few such advocates are left at the end of the year, I shall take it as proof of the advisability of withdrawal of boycott by the Congress.
('29', 204, 3, 31, 427064) If, at the end of the year, all those who regard themselves as advocates of boycott adhere to theirviews in thought and action, the Congress may reintroduce
('29', 205, 0, 1, 427221) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 205, 1, 2, 427263) boycott next year.
('29', 205, 1, 3, 427282) This revival of boycott will have one feature, namely, the sting of compulsion will have been removed from it.
('29', 205, 1, 4, 427393) If it produces no effect by the end of the year and there is no change in the Government’s attitude, then the advocates of boycott, instead of attempting to revive it in the Congress, should attract others to it by their patient and persistent practice.
('29', 205, 1, 5, 427647) Voluntary and peaceful boycott is no joke.
('29', 205, 1, 6, 427690) It cannot last long if it is practised for fear of being disgraced in public.
('29', 205, 1, 7, 427768) An impulsive boycott is as momentary as the effervescence of soda water.
('29', 205, 1, 8, 427841) Only that boycott which is practised deliberately and purposefully can overcome all obstacles and remain steadfast.
('29', 205, 1, 9, 427957) Therefore I expect No changers not only to continue their boycott but to enforce it more rigorously even if the Congress suspends it.
('29', 205, 1, 10, 428091) I can expect nothing else from Gujarat.
('29', 205, 1, 11, 428131) While we ourselves persist thus in our boycott, if we take to heart the lesson of not deriding our co workers it will be a mark of our invaluable progress and a great step forward on our march to freedom.
('29', 205, 2, 12, 428336) [From Gujarati]

('29', 208, 8, 15, 431448) 160. ALL ABOUT THE FAST
('29', 208, 9, 16, 431472) September 22, 1924
('29', 208, 10, 17, 431491) I wish to assure the reader that the fast has not been undertaken without deliberation.
('29', 208, 10, 18, 431579) As a matter of fact my life has been a stake ever since the birth of non co operation.
('29', 208, 10, 19, 431666) I did not blindly embark upon it.
('29', 208, 10, 20, 431700) I had ample warning of the dangers attendant upon it.
('29', 208, 10, 21, 431754) No act of mine is done without prayer.
('29', 208, 10, 22, 431793) Man is a fallible being.
('29', 208, 10, 23, 431818) He can never be sure of his steps.
('29', 208, 10, 24, 431853) What he may regard as answer to prayer may be an echo of his pride.
('29', 208, 10, 25, 431921) For infallible guidance man has to have a perfectly innocent heart incapable of evil.
('29', 208, 10, 26, 432007) I can lay no such claim.
('29', 208, 10, 27, 432032) Mine is a struggling, striving, erring, imperfect soul.
('29', 208, 10, 28, 432088) But I can rise only by experimenting upon myself and others.
('29', 208, 10, 29, 432149) I believe in absolute oneness of God and therefore also of humanity.
('29', 208, 10, 30, 432218) What though we have many
('29', 208, 11, 31, 432243) 1 From the postmark.
('29', 209, 0, 1, 432264) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 209, 1, 2, 432306) bodies?
('29', 209, 1, 3, 432314) We have but one soul.
('29', 209, 1, 4, 432336) The rays of the sun are many through refraction.
('29', 209, 1, 5, 432385) But they have the same source.
('29', 209, 1, 6, 432416) I cannot therefore detach myself from the wickedest soul (nor may I be denied identity with the most virtuous).
('29', 209, 1, 7, 432528) Whether therefore I will or no, I must involve in my experiment the whole of my kind.
('29', 209, 1, 8, 432614) Nor can I do without experiment.
('29', 209, 1, 9, 432647) Life is but an endless series of experiments.
('29', 209, 2, 10, 432693) I knew that non co operation was a dangerous experiment.
('29', 209, 2, 11, 432750) Non co operation in itself is unnatural, vicious and sinful.
('29', 209, 2, 12, 432811) But non violent non co operation, I am convinced, is a sacred duty at times.
('29', 209, 2, 13, 432888) I have proved it in many cases.
('29', 209, 2, 14, 432920) But there was every possibility of mistake in its application to large masses.
('29', 209, 2, 15, 432999) But desperate diseases call for desperate remedies.
('29', 209, 2, 16, 433051) Non violent non co operation was the only alternative to anarchy and worse.
('29', 209, 2, 17, 433127) Since it was to be non violent, I had to put my life in the scales.
('29', 209, 3, 18, 433195) The fact that Hindus and Mussalmans, who were only two years ago apparently working together as friends, are now fighting like cats and dogs in some places, shows conclusively that the non co opera tion they offered was not non violent.
('29', 209, 3, 19, 433432) I saw the symptoms in Bombay, Chauri Chaura and in a host of minor cases.
('29', 209, 3, 20, 433506) I did penance then.
('29', 209, 3, 21, 433526) It had its effect pro tanto.
('29', 209, 3, 22, 433555) But this Hindu Muslim tension was unthinkable.
('29', 209, 3, 23, 433602) It became unbearable on hearing of the Kohat tragedy.
('29', 209, 3, 24, 433656) On the eve of my departure from Sabarmati for Delhi, Sarojini Devi wrote to me that speeches and homilies on peace would not do.
('29', 209, 3, 25, 433785) I must find out an effective remedy.
('29', 209, 3, 26, 433822) She was right in saddling the responsibility on me.
('29', 209, 3, 27, 433874) Had I not been instrumental in bringing into being the vast energy of the people?
('29', 209, 3, 28, 433956) I must find the remedy if the energy proved self destruc tive.
('29', 209, 3, 29, 434019) I wrote to say that I should find it only by plodding.
('29', 209, 3, 30, 434074) Empty prayer is”as sounding brass or a tinkling cymbal”.
('29', 209, 3, 31, 434131) I little knew then that the remedy was to be this prolonged fast.
('29', 209, 3, 32, 434197) And yet I know that the fast is not prolonged enough for quenching the agony of my soul.
('29', 209, 3, 33, 434286) Have I erred, have I been impatient, have I compromised with evil?
('29', 209, 3, 34, 434353) I may have done all these things or none of them.
('29', 209, 3, 35, 434403) All I know is what I see before me.
('29', 209, 3, 36, 434439) If real non violence and truth had been practised by the people who are now fighting, the gory duelling that is now going on would have been impossible.
('29', 209, 3, 37, 434592) My responsibility is clearly some where.
('29', 209, 4, 38, 434633) I was violently shaken by Amethi, Shambhar and Gulbarga.
('29', 209, 4, 39, 434690) I had read the reports about Amethi and Shambhar prepared by Hindu and Mussalman friends.
('29', 209, 4, 40, 434780) I had learnt the joint finding of Hindu and
('29', 210, 0, 1, 434824) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 211
('29', 210, 1, 2, 434872) Mussalman friends who went to Gulbarga.
('29', 210, 1, 3, 434912) I was writhing in deep pain and yet I had no remedy.
('29', 210, 1, 4, 434965) The news of Kohat set the smouldering mass aflame.
('29', 210, 1, 5, 435016) Something had got to be done.
('29', 210, 1, 6, 435046) I passed two nights in restlessness and pain.
('29', 210, 1, 7, 435092) On Wednesday I knew the remedy.
('29', 210, 1, 8, 435124) I must do penance.
('29', 210, 1, 9, 435143) In the Satyagraha Ashram at the time of morning prayer we ask Siva, God of Mercy, to forgive our sins knowingly or unknowingly committed.
('29', 210, 1, 10, 435281) My penance is the prayer of a bleeding heart for forgiveness for sins unwittingly committed.
('29', 210, 2, 11, 435374) It is a warning to the Hindus and Mussalmans who have professed to love me.
('29', 210, 2, 12, 435450) If they have loved me truly and if I have been deserving of their love, they will do penance with me for the grave sin of denying God in their hearts.
('29', 210, 2, 13, 435601) To revile one another’s religion, to make reckless statements, to utter untruth, to break the heads of innocent men, to desecrate temples or mosques, is a denial of God.
('29', 210, 2, 14, 435771) The world is watching—some with glee and some with sorrow—the dogfight that is proceeding in our midst.
('29', 210, 2, 15, 435875) We have listened to Satan.
('29', 210, 2, 16, 435902) Religion—call it by what you like— is made of sterner stuff.
('29', 210, 2, 17, 435963) The penance of Hindus and Mussalmans is not fasting but retracing their steps.
('29', 210, 2, 18, 436042) It is true penance for a Mussalman to harbour no ill for his Hindu brother and an equally true penance for a Hindu to harbour none for his Mussalman brother.
('29', 210, 3, 19, 436200) I ask of no Hindu or Mussalman to surrender an iota of his religious principle.
('29', 210, 3, 20, 436280) Only let him be sure that it is religion.
('29', 210, 3, 21, 436322) But I do ask of every Hindu and Mussalman not to fight for an earthly gain.
('29', 210, 3, 22, 436398) I should be deeply hurt if my fast made either community surrender on a matter of principle.
('29', 210, 3, 23, 436491) My fast is a matter between God and myself.
('29', 210, 4, 24, 436535) I did not consult friends—not even Hakim Sahib who was closeted with me for a long time on Wednesday—not Maulana Maho med Ali under whose roof I am enjoying the privilege of hospitality.
('29', 210, 4, 25, 436722) When a man wants to make up with his Maker, he does not consult a third party.
('29', 210, 4, 26, 436801) He ought not to.
('29', 210, 4, 27, 436818) If he has any doubt about it, he certainly must.
('29', 210, 4, 28, 436867) But I had no doubt in my mind about the necessity of my step.
('29', 210, 4, 29, 436929) Friends would deem it their duty to prevent me from undertaking the fast.
('29', 210, 4, 30, 437003) Such things are not matters for consultation or argument.
('29', 210, 4, 31, 437061) They are matters of feeling.
('29', 210, 4, 32, 437090) When Rama decided to fulfil his obligation, he did not swerve from his resolve either by the weepings and wailings of his dear mother or the advice of his preceptors or the entreaty of his people, or even the certainty of his father’s death if he carried out his resolve.
('29', 210, 4, 33, 437362) These things are momentary.
('29', 210, 4, 34, 437390) Hinduism would not have been
('29', 211, 0, 1, 437419) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 211, 1, 2, 437461) much of a religion, if Rama had not steeled his heart against every temptation.
('29', 211, 1, 3, 437541) He knew that he had to pass through every travail, if he was to serve humanity and become a model for future generations.
('29', 211, 1, 4, 437663) But was it right for me to go through the fast under a Mussalman roof?
('29', 211, 1, 5, 437734) Yes, it was.
('29', 211, 1, 6, 437747) The fast is not born out of ill will against a single soul.
('29', 211, 1, 7, 437807) My being under a Mussalman roof ensures it against any such interpretation.
('29', 211, 1, 8, 437883) It is in the fitness of things that this fast should be taken up and completed in a Mussalman house.
('29', 211, 1, 9, 437984) And who is Mahomed Ali?
('29', 211, 1, 10, 438008) Only two days before the fast we had a discussion about a private matter in which I told him, what was mine was his and what was his was mine.
('29', 211, 1, 11, 438151) Let me gratefully tell the public that I have never received warmer or better treatment than under Mahomed Ali’s roof.
('29', 211, 1, 12, 438270) Every want of mine is anticipated.
('29', 211, 1, 13, 438305) The dominant thought of every one of his household is to make me and mine happy and comfortable.
('29', 211, 1, 14, 438402) Doctors Ansari and Abdur Rahman have constituted themselves my medical advisers.
('29', 211, 1, 15, 438483) They examine me daily.
('29', 211, 1, 16, 438506) I have had many a happy occasion in my life.
('29', 211, 1, 17, 438551) This is no less happy than the previous ones.
('29', 211, 1, 18, 438597) Bread is not everything.
('29', 211, 1, 19, 438622) I am experiencing here the richest love.

('29', 211, 1, 21, 438693) It has been whispered that by being so much with Mussalman friends, I make myself unfit to know the Hindu mind.
('29', 211, 1, 22, 438805) The Hindu mind is myself.

('29', 213, 5, 10, 441604) 164. NO WORK, NO VOTE
('29', 213, 6, 11, 441626) September 23, 1924
('29', 213, 7, 12, 441645) Maulana Hasrat Mohani brought me the other day the constitution of the Russian Soviet, and told me that I should read it, if only to find a striking resemblance between the Soviet constitution and that of the Congress.
('29', 213, 7, 13, 441864) I have cursorily read that constitution, and whilst there is undoubtedly a striking resemblance in form between the two constitutions, showing that there is nothing new or original under the sun, there are also vital differences into which I need not go.
('29', 213, 7, 14, 442119) But the one thing that captivated me was the formula of” no work, no vote”.
('29', 213, 7, 15, 442195) The qualification under the Soviet constitution is not money, not even four annas, not landed property, not even education, but honest labour.
('29', 213, 7, 16, 442338) Thus the Soviet Congress is a worker’s Congress.
('29', 213, 7, 17, 442387) The philosophers, the professors, and all others must do some labour.
('29', 213, 7, 18, 442457) What form that labour takes, I do not know.
('29', 213, 7, 19, 442501) As I gave it only a few minutes, even if the information is to be found in the booklet, it has escaped me.
('29', 213, 7, 20, 442608) The important and relevant fact is that every voter has to show sound work.
('29', 213, 7, 21, 442684) My proposal therefore that everyone henceforth who desires to belong to the Congress organization should have some labour for the nation to his credit is neither original nor ridiculous.
('29', 213, 7, 22, 442871) Seeing that a great nation has accepted before us the formula, we need not be ashamed of copying it.
('29', 213, 7, 23, 442972) Labour given for only a few minutes per day to be fruitful must be of the same kind for the millions.
('29', 213, 7, 24, 443074) And there is nothing but hand spinning which can be made universal in a big country like ours.
('29', 213, 7, 25, 443169) But it has been urged that my proposal is not a mere labour
('29', 214, 0, 1, 443229) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 215
('29', 214, 1, 2, 443277) proposal; it surreptitiously raises the pecuniary qualification.
('29', 214, 1, 3, 443342) No matter how fine the yarn may be, the quantity for the year can never be brought down so low as to cost four annas.
('29', 214, 1, 4, 443460) But the critics forget, that I have said in the article in which I sketched the proposal, that those who cannot afford 1 cotton should have it given to them by the Provincial Congress Committees, so that the free gift of cotton would be under my plan a donation, not a subscription.
('29', 214, 1, 5, 443743) Experience shows that it is perfectly possible for thousands to find sufficient cotton to spin 24,000 yards per year.
('29', 214, 1, 6, 443861) The total of those who have sent their yarn to the All India Khaddar Board is nearly five thousand.
('29', 214, 1, 7, 443961) They have not asked for cotton from the Khaddar Board.
('29', 214, 1, 8, 444016) It is possible that some provinces have made arrangements for supplying spinners with cotton.
('29', 214, 1, 9, 444110) If they have done so, there is nothing improper about it.
('29', 214, 1, 10, 444168) For the chief thing is the labour for half an hour.
('29', 214, 1, 11, 444220) The nation is not dying for want of raw products, but it is dying for want of labour and minimum skill.
('29', 214, 1, 12, 444324) My proposal seems to jar, because we have not been used to toil with our hands and find it difficult to appreciate the possibilities of a whole nation voluntarily giving half an hour’s labour to a single national necessity.
('29', 214, 1, 13, 444548) Surely there is nothing immoral about my proposal.
('29', 214, 1, 14, 444599) There is nothing in it that can come to conflict with anybody’s conscience.
('29', 214, 1, 15, 444675) There is nothing Herculean about it.
('29', 214, 1, 16, 444712) Indeed, half an hour’s easy labour is too insignificant to become exacting for the most industrious worker.
('29', 214, 1, 17, 444820) The most, therefore, that can be urged against the proposal is that the labour will be fruitless.
('29', 214, 1, 18, 444918) Assume for one moment that it will be fruitless in terms of swaraj or immediate economic solution.
('29', 214, 1, 19, 445017) But surely it is not fruitless if cheap khaddar can be brought out from the maunds of yarn received by the All India Khaddar Board from month to month.
('29', 214, 1, 20, 445169) A single yard of cloth added to the national production cannot be called a fruitless effort.
('29', 214, 1, 21, 445262) Another objection that has been advanced against the proposal is that it will disfranchise thousands of Congress voters.
('29', 214, 1, 22, 445383) I make bold to say that the objection is chimerical.
('29', 214, 1, 23, 445436) A voter is one who actively interests himself in the organization in which he is a voter.
('29', 214, 1, 24, 445526) Our voters are not of that type.
('29', 214, 1, 25, 445559) The fault is not theirs, but ours.
('29', 214, 1, 26, 445594) We have not interested ourselves sufficiently in them.
('29', 214, 1, 27, 445649) And we are not going to do so without being spurred thereto.
('29', 214, 1, 28, 445710) The spindle is the spur.
('29', 214, 1, 29, 445735) From month to month Congress officials will have to keep themselves in direct touch with every single voter.
('29', 214, 1, 30, 445844) It surprises me that it should be
('29', 214, 2, 31, 445878) 1 The source has” give”.
('29', 214, 2, 32, 445903) But vide” The Realities”, 11 9 1924.
('29', 215, 0, 1, 445940) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 215, 1, 2, 445982) necessary to demonstrate the obvious.
('29', 215, 1, 3, 446020) Think of the possibilities of an organization of honest workers who must render an account of their work from month to month.
('29', 215, 1, 4, 446146) Surely, a living organization containing a few earnest workers is infinitely superior to an organization containing many indifferent members whose work is confined merely to registering their votes at the bidding of a few men.
('29', 215, 1, 5, 446373) The indications, however, are that if only we would have the courage to make the necessary change, we will have a very large number of voters, much larger than many expect.
('29', 215, 1, 6, 446546) The number of the second month is double the number of the first month.
('29', 215, 1, 7, 446618) If every worker in every province properly organizes this voluntary spinning, we must have a steady increase in the spinners.
('29', 215, 1, 8, 446744) We should not be surprised to find the figure of two lakhs being reached in a few months.
('29', 215, 1, 9, 446834) Two lakhs means ten thousand for each province.
('29', 215, 1, 10, 446882) It does not need extraordinary organizing ability to register ten thousand voluntary spinners in each province on an average.
('29', 215, 1, 11, 447008) I hope, therefore, that my proposal will not be rejected.
('29', 215, 1, 12, 447066) I have purposely called my proposal the lowest common measure, not the highest.
('29', 215, 1, 13, 447146) And the lowest does not mean the lowest acceptable to the whole of India, but the lowest necessary for the national achievement.
('29', 215, 1, 14, 447275) And I hold that, if we are to achieve swaraj by bloodless methods, the three things mentioned by me are absolutely necessary.
('29', 215, 1, 15, 447401) If the ideal is to have as many voters as we can, irrespective of efficiency, then Hindu Muslim unity and [anti ]untouchability also must go by the board.
('29', 215, 1, 16, 447556) For I know that our intense work about untouchability has driven away many men from the Congress.
('29', 215, 1, 17, 447654) They still hug it as an integral part of Hinduism.
('29', 215, 1, 18, 447705) The same may be said of Hindu Muslim unity.
('29', 215, 1, 19, 447749) For recent experiences have shown that there are many who not only do not want Hindu Muslim unity, but want to perpetuate our differences.
('29', 215, 1, 20, 447888) They want to pick quarrels on the slightest pretext.
('29', 215, 1, 21, 447941) They do not hesitate to manufacture pretexts.
('29', 215, 1, 22, 447987) If, therefore, we dispense with all conditions conducive to internal growth, we will have a Congress of rabble, not a Congress that would respond as one man to the call of the nation.
('29', 215, 1, 23, 448171) I for one would absolutely freeze in an organization in which the three things mentioned by me were not living realities.
('29', 215, 1, 24, 448293) To paraphrase a Biblical verse, if it is no profanation, I would say:” Seek you first Hindu Muslim unity, removal of untouchability and the spinning wheel and khaddar, and everything will be added unto you.”

('29', 217, 1, 2, 449635) 168. TO THE READER
('29', 217, 2, 3, 449654) DELHI, Wednesday, Bhadarva Vad 11 [September 24, 1924]
('29', 217, 3, 4, 449709) What should I write to you?
('29', 217, 3, 5, 449737) The relationship between you and me is, I think, unusual.
('29', 217, 3, 6, 449795) It is not for money or fame that I have taken up the editorship of Navajivan.
('29', 217, 3, 7, 449873) I have taken it up in order to enter your heart with my words.
('29', 217, 3, 8, 449936) The editorship came my way unsought; but ever since I have been thinking of you.
('29', 217, 3, 9, 450017) Every week I endeavour to put my soul into Navajivan.
('29', 217, 3, 10, 450071) I do not write even one word there without God as witness.
('29', 217, 3, 11, 450130) I have not considered it my duty to place before you only such offerings as would please you.
('29', 217, 3, 12, 450224) I have often offered bitter doses.
('29', 217, 3, 13, 450259) Through every dose, whether bitter or sweet, I have sought to define my ideas of plain duty and pure patriotism.
('29', 217, 3, 14, 450372) The fast which I am undergoing now is for making me more fit for the editorship.
('29', 217, 3, 15, 450453) I know that many readers of Navajivan are guided by my writings.
('29', 217, 3, 16, 450518) I may perhaps have done them some harm by wrong guidance.
('29', 217, 3, 17, 450576) This thought used to torture me.
('29', 217, 3, 18, 450609) I had not the least doubt regarding untouchability.
('29', 217, 3, 19, 450661) There was no room for doubt regarding the spinning wheel either.
('29', 217, 3, 20, 450726) The wheel is like crutches to the lame.
('29', 217, 3, 21, 450766) It is the means of satisfying the hunger of the starving.
('29', 217, 3, 22, 450824) To a poor woman, it is a fortress for protecting her virtue.
('29', 217, 3, 23, 450885) I am convinced that it would be impossible to ward off starvation from India without a general acceptance of the spinning wheel.
('29', 217, 3, 24, 451014) Therefore there is no chance of error in plying or propagating the spinning wheel.
('29', 217, 3, 25, 451097) There is also no room for doubt about the need for Hindu Muslim unity.
('29', 217, 3, 26, 451168) Swaraj is inconceivable without it.
('29', 217, 3, 27, 451204) But I had always my doubts whether you were prepared to comprehend absolute non violence.
('29', 217, 3, 28, 451294) I have repeatedly and loudly proclaimed that tolerance and non violence are the qualities of the brave.
('29', 217, 3, 29, 451398) Those who have the strength to kill can alone refrain from killing.
('29', 217, 3, 30, 451466) Might not my writings lead you to regard cowardice as non violence?
('29', 217, 3, 31, 451534) Might it not be that you abandon the duty of defending yourself?
('29', 217, 3, 32, 451599) That would stand to my discredit.
('29', 217, 3, 33, 451633) I have said very often in speech and writing that cowardice can never be considered a virtue.
('29', 217, 3, 34, 451727) The sword indeed has a place in this world; but not cowardice.
('29', 217, 3, 35, 451790) It is likely that the coward would perish and that is but
('29', 218, 0, 1, 451848) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 219
('29', 218, 1, 2, 451896) What I am trying to prove is that even he who takes a sword is likely to perish.
('29', 218, 1, 3, 451977) The man with a sword, whom does he protect and whom does he kill?
('29', 218, 1, 4, 452043) Physical strength stands no comparison before spiritual strength.
('29', 218, 1, 5, 452109) Non violence reveals the strength of spirit, while the sword that of the body.
('29', 218, 1, 6, 452188) With the use of the sword, spirit degenerates into matter.
('29', 218, 1, 7, 452247) By resorting to non violence, the soul recovers its spiritual nature.
('29', 218, 1, 8, 452317) One who does not understand this truth must protect his wards by using the sword, if necessary.
('29', 218, 1, 9, 452413) I cannot explain with words the priceless virtue of non violence.
('29', 218, 1, 10, 452479) It can be taught only through practice.
('29', 218, 1, 11, 452519) That is why I am practising this virtue at the moment.
('29', 218, 1, 12, 452574) I would not touch with a sword even those Muslims who destroy our temples; I would not hate them; I would win them over only with love.
('29', 218, 1, 13, 452710) I have written that even if one true premi 1 is born in India, he would be able to protect his religion.
('29', 218, 1, 14, 452815) I wish to become such a one.
('29', 218, 1, 15, 452844) I always write to persuade you too to do likewise.
('29', 218, 1, 16, 452895) I know that I am filled with overflowing love.
('29', 218, 1, 17, 452942) But is there any limit to love?
('29', 218, 1, 18, 452974) I know that my love is not limitless.
('29', 218, 1, 19, 453012) Can I play with a serpent?
('29', 218, 1, 20, 453039) I have a firm belief that even a serpent would be at peace in the presence of an incarnation of non violence.
('29', 218, 1, 21, 453149) I am examining myself by fasting; I am gathering more love.
('29', 218, 1, 22, 453209) While I do my duty, I wish to make you aware of yours.
('29', 218, 1, 23, 453264) Nothing would be gained by your fasting with me.
('29', 218, 1, 24, 453313) For fasting too there is a time and a title.
('29', 218, 1, 25, 453358) Your duty is to fulfil the threefold programme which I have placed before you in various ways.
('29', 218, 1, 26, 453453) I am confident that you will draw many other corollaries from that programme.
('29', 218, 1, 27, 453531) Instead of doubting the propriety of my fast or lamenting over it, you should pray to God that it may proceed smoothly, that I may resume my service to you through Navajivan and that my words may acquire a new power.
('29', 218, 2, 28, 453748) Your servant,
('29', 218, 3, 29, 453762) MOHANDAS GANDHI [From Gujarati]

('29', 219, 5, 9, 454183) 170. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS ON UNITY CONFERENCE 1
('29', 219, 7, 10, 454233) September 24, 1924
('29', 219, 8, 11, 454252) It is a matter of great regret to me that I shall not be able to attend the coming Conference.
('29', 219, 8, 12, 454347) I am aware that my fast is itself a disturbing factor.
('29', 219, 8, 13, 454402) My presence will be still more so, but though I must not be present in body, my spirit will be there.
('29', 219, 8, 14, 454504) My fast has brought the Conference together.
('29', 219, 8, 15, 454549) I should be glad if it tends to induce heart searching and makes us all frank, fearless and truthful, if it enables us to forgo the non essentials and confines us strictly to the essentials, but I should be deeply hurt if it makes a single Hindu or Mussalman surrender a tittle of what he may regard as his principle.
('29', 219, 8, 16, 454867) The Conference will be fruitless if it produces a patched up peace.
('29', 219, 8, 17, 454935) It will fail in its effect.
('29', 219, 8, 18, 454963) What is wanted is a heart unity and that can only come if heart speaks to heart.
('29', 219, 8, 19, 455044) If Mussalmans consider that desecration of temples is a duty, that a man who honestly gives up Islam or a man who having embraced it changes to another faith deserves punishment at their hands, or if they consider that music before mosques must be forcibly stopped, they should declare it.
('29', 219, 8, 20, 455334) I shall honour them for it.
('29', 219, 8, 21, 455362) But I shall know that then there is no peace for this unhappy land.
('29', 219, 8, 22, 455430) I would far rather face the consequence than have a single Mussalman suppress his religious conviction under outside pressure.
('29', 219, 9, 23, 455557) 1 Which began its session at Delhi on September 26, 1924
('29', 220, 0, 1, 455614) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 221
('29', 220, 1, 2, 455662) As a Hindu I know that a Hindu dare not say that his religion compels him to desecrate mosques or force a Mussalman to stop the slaughter of cows.
('29', 220, 1, 3, 455809) I know that he commits a grievous sin if he does any of these acts.
('29', 220, 1, 4, 455877) But if there are Hindus who regard the desecration of other peoples’ places of worship or the forcible stopping of cow slaughter a duty, let them say so.
('29', 220, 1, 5, 456031) I shall know then that again there is no peace in this land of tears and sorrow.
('29', 220, 1, 6, 456112) All I wish to emphasize is that there should be no mental reservations because of the fast and that a false truce will only aggravate my agony, and my next state will be worse than the present.
('29', 220, 1, 7, 456306) The fast should therefore be ruled out of our deliberations but if the members consider that it is impossible to do so I would urge the postponement of the Conference till the weight of the fast is lifted.

('29', 221, 2, 10, 458244) INHUMAN TREATMENT
('29', 221, 3, 11, 458262) I had the pleasure of seeing Mrs. Gangabai Gidwani 1 and Dr. Choithram 2 after their visit to Acharya Gidwani.
('29', 221, 3, 12, 458373) They tell me that Acharya Gidwani is kept confined the whole day long and is permitted to receive visitors only once every three months and that he must have lost over thirty pounds in weight.
('29', 221, 3, 13, 458566) They tell me too that the Acharya has not been weighed by the authorities for a long time and, when they asked the Superintendent why no weight was taken for a long time, he shrugged his shoulders and said,” That is not the system here.” I know that jails are not palaces, that prisoners must not expect to have all the facilities of home life.
('29', 221, 3, 14, 458911) But I do know many jails where the treatment meted out to Acharya Gidwani would be impossible.

('29', 221, 3, 26, 459655) Even murderers have plenty of fresh air and exercise allowed to them.
('29', 221, 3, 27, 459725) The brutal solitary confinement imposed upon Acharya Gidwani is, so far as I am aware, without any cause.
('29', 221, 3, 28, 459831) Such confinement is imposed as a punishment for serious prison offences.
('29', 221, 3, 29, 459904) If Acharya Gidwani has committed any, the public should be informed of it.
('29', 221, 3, 30, 459979) It may be that the Nabha State has no facility for keeping the Acharya outdoor the whole day long.
('29', 221, 3, 31, 460078) If so, I would suggest his transfer to another prison.

('29', 224, 7, 12, 463752) The Conference 3 tenders its warm sympathy to the sufferers.
('29', 224, 7, 13, 463813) This Conference is of opinion that it is unlawful and irreligious for any person to take the law into his own hands.

('29', 224, 7, 16, 464113) (should be such men as would give their whole time) to work as arbitrators with power to appoint agents to decide all disputes between the two communities, to inquire into past wrongs and to publish their findings.

('29', 226, 1, 2, 466731) 176. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU
('29', 226, 2, 3, 466760) September 27, 1924
('29', 226, 3, 4, 466779) DEAR MOTILALJI, Moved by affection and pity the Conference guided by you has passed the resolution 1, you kindly read to me last night.
('29', 226, 3, 5, 466915) I would ask you to assure the meeting that if I could have complied with its wishes, I would gladly have done so.
('29', 226, 3, 6, 467029) But I have examined and re examined myself and I find it is not possible for me to recall the fast.
('29', 226, 3, 7, 467129) My religion teaches me that a promise once made or a vow once taken for a worthy object may not be broken.
('29', 226, 3, 8, 467236) And you know my life has been regulated on that basis for now more than 40 years.
('29', 226, 3, 9, 467318) The causes of the fast are much deeper than I can explain in this note.
('29', 226, 3, 10, 467390) For one thing, I am expressing my faith through this fast.
('29', 226, 3, 11, 467449) Non co operation was not conceived in hatred or ill will towards a single Englishman.
('29', 226, 3, 12, 467535) Its non violent character was intended to conquer Englishmen by our love.
('29', 226, 3, 13, 467609) Not only has it not resulted in that consequence, but the energy generated by it has brought about hatred and ill will against one another amongst ourselves.
('29', 226, 3, 14, 467767) It is the knowledge of this fact which has weighed me down and imposed this irrevocable penance upon me.
('29', 226, 3, 15, 467872) The fast is therefore a matter between God and myself, and I would therefore not only ask you to forgive me for not breaking it but would ask you even to encourage me and pray for me that it may
('29', 226, 4, 16, 468067) 1 This Conference places on record its deep grief and concern at the fast which Mahatma Gandhi has undertaken.
('29', 226, 4, 17, 468178) The Conference is emphatically of opinion that the utmost freedom of conscience and religion is essential, and condemns any desecration of places of worship, to whatsoever faith they may belong, and any persecution or punishment of any person for adopting or reverting to any faith; and further condemns any attempts by compulsion to convert people to one’s faith or to secure or enforce one’s own religious observation at the cost of the rights of others.
('29', 226, 4, 18, 468635) The members of the Conference assure Mahatma Gandhi and pledge themselves to use their utmost endeavours to enforce these principles and to condemn any deviation from them even under provocation.
('29', 226, 4, 19, 468831) This Conference further authorizes the President to convey personally to Mahatma Gandhi the solemn assurance of this Conference to the above effect as also the united wishes of this Conference that Mahatma Gandhi should immediately break his fast in order to permit the Conference to have the benefit of his co operation, advice and guidance in deciding upon the speediest means of effectively checking the evil which is fast over spreading the country.
('29', 227, 0, 1, 469285) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 227, 1, 2, 469327) end successfully.
('29', 227, 1, 3, 469345) I have not taken up the fast to die, but I have taken it up to live a better and purer life for the service of the country.
('29', 227, 1, 4, 469469) If, therefore, I reach a crisis (of which humanly speaking I see no possibility whatsoever) when the choice lies between death and food, I shall certainly break the fast.
('29', 227, 1, 5, 469640) 1 But Drs.
('29', 227, 1, 6, 469651) Ansari and Abdul Rahman, who are looking after me with the greatest attention and care, will tell you that I am keeping wonderfully fresh.
('29', 227, 1, 7, 469790) I would therefore respectfully urge the meeting to transmute all personal affection of which the resolution is an index into solid, earnest and true work for unity for which the Conference has met.
('29', 227, 2, 8, 469988) Yours sincerely,

('29', 228, 8, 14, 471830) That change has still to come.

('29', 230, 8, 12, 475468) 184. WILL GUJARAT ACCEPT DEFEAT?
('29', 230, 9, 13, 475501) Wednesday, Aso Sud 3 [October 1, 1924]
('29', 230, 10, 14, 475540) Andhradesh and Bengal have threatened to surpass Gujarat in respect of the number of spinners.
('29', 230, 10, 15, 475635) If either province surpasses Gujarat, I shall, of course, congratulate it; but why should Gujarat be defeated?
('29', 230, 10, 16, 475746) One achieves success even if one is surpassed after making one’s best effort.
('29', 230, 10, 17, 475824) Gujarat has just now launched upon its endeavour.
('29', 230, 10, 18, 475874) Do all the teachers spin?
('29', 230, 10, 19, 475900) Do the students spin?
('29', 230, 10, 20, 475922) Let all of them spin, let all the numberless brothers and sisters who attend public meetings spin—and then it would not matter if Gujarat is left behind.
('29', 230, 10, 21, 476076) The challenge is for the organizers; let them get busy.

('29', 231, 0, 1, 476169) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 231, 1, 2, 476211) 185. MESSAGE TO INTERNATIONAL OPIUM CONFERENCE, GENEVA 1
('29', 231, 2, 3, 476268) [Before October 2, 1924]
('29', 231, 3, 4, 476293) The following has been signed by Mahatma Gandhi and Rabindranath Tagore: The undersigned, viewing the growing addiction to narcotic drugs to be a deadly menace to individuals and to nations, and also an insidious, rapidly spreading poisoning of the human race, which can be overcome only by co operation among nations, respectfully petition the International Opium Conference assembling in November, 1924 to adopt measures adequate for total extirpation of the plants from which these drugs originate, except as found necessary for medicine and science in the judgment of the best medical opinion of the world.
('29', 231, 4, 5, 476904) Young India, 2 10 1924

('29', 233, 10, 22, 479445) You have said besides that Islam is not a false religion.

('29', 233, 10, 27, 479783) This brother has insistently asked for a reply.
('29', 233, 10, 28, 479831) It has nowhere

('29', 234, 1, 2, 480268) been enjoined that everyone should do everything that is not false.
('29', 234, 1, 3, 480336) Just as I do not consider Islam to be a false religion, so also do I not consider Christianity, Zoroastrianism or Judaism to be false religions.
('29', 234, 1, 4, 480481) Which religion, then, should I embrace?
('29', 234, 1, 5, 480521) Moreover, I do not consider Hinduism a false religion either.
('29', 234, 1, 6, 480583) What, then, should one like me, a seeker of truth, do?
('29', 234, 1, 7, 480638) I studied the mysteries of Islam and hence declared that it is not a false religion.
('29', 234, 1, 8, 480723) I thought it necessary to declare it since Islam was under attack, and since I wished to be friends with Muslim brothers, I defended their religion.
('29', 234, 1, 9, 480872) Everyone feels that his religion is nearest to perfection and hence he is devoted to it.
('29', 234, 1, 10, 480961) Likewise, not only do I feel that Hinduism is not false but I also feel that it is the most perfect.
('29', 234, 1, 11, 481062) Hence I cling to my religion, as a child to its mother.
('29', 234, 1, 12, 481118) But I have no dislike for other religions, as a child has none for other mothers.

('29', 235, 1, 2, 482228) 192. MY REFUGE
('29', 235, 2, 3, 482243) DELHI, October 6, 1924
('29', 235, 3, 4, 482266) Today is the twentieth day of my penance and prayer.
('29', 235, 3, 5, 482319) Presently from the world of peace I shall enter the world of strife.
('29', 235, 3, 6, 482388) The more I think of it, the more helpless I feel.
('29', 235, 3, 7, 482438) So many look to me to finish the work begun by the Unity Conference.
('29', 235, 3, 8, 482507) So many expect me to bring together the political parties.
('29', 235, 3, 9, 482566) I know that I can do nothing.
('29', 235, 3, 10, 482596) God can do everything.
('29', 235, 3, 11, 482619) make me Thy fit instrument and use me as Thou wilt.
('29', 235, 3, 12, 482671) Man is nothing.
('29', 235, 3, 13, 482687) Napoleon planned much and found himself a prisoner in St. Helena.
('29', 235, 3, 14, 482753) The mighty Kaiser aimed at the crown of Europe and is reduced to the status of a private gentleman.
('29', 235, 3, 15, 482853) God had so willed it.
('29', 235, 3, 16, 482875) Let us contemplate such examples and be humble.
('29', 235, 3, 17, 482923) During these days of grace, privilege and peace, I have hummed to myself a hymn we often sing at the Satyagraha Ashram.
('29', 235, 3, 18, 483043) It is so good that I cannot resist the pleasure of sharing a free rendering of it with the reader.
('29', 235, 3, 19, 483142) The words of the hymn better express my state than anything else I can write.
('29', 235, 3, 20, 483220) Here they are: My honour, O!
('29', 235, 3, 21, 483249) God, is in Thy keeping; Thou art ever my Refuge, For Thou art Protector of the weak, It is Thy promise to listen to the wail of sinners; I am a sinner of old, help me Thou To cross this ocean of darkness.
('29', 235, 3, 22, 483454) It is Thine to remove the sin And the misery of mankind.
('29', 235, 3, 23, 483511) Be gracious to Tulsidas And make him Thy devotee.
('29', 235, 4, 24, 483561) Young India, 9 10 1924
('29', 235, 5, 25, 483584) 1 The original text of the hymn of Tulsidas was reproduced under” Notes” in the same issue of Young India.

('29', 236, 7, 17, 484575) 194. STATEMENT BEFORE BREAKING FAST
('29', 236, 8, 18, 484611) DELHI, October 8, 1924
('29', 236, 9, 19, 484634) Mr. Gandhi broke his fast at 12 noon today.
('29', 236, 9, 20, 484678) After the Hindu, Muslim and Christian prayers were over .
('29', 236, 9, 21, 484736) in a low voice, at times almost inaudible .
('29', 236, 9, 22, 484780) he said: Hindu Muslim unity is not a new interest with me.
('29', 236, 9, 23, 484839) It has been my chief concern for 30 years.
('29', 236, 9, 24, 484882) But I have not succeeded in achieving it.
('29', 236, 9, 25, 484924) I do not know what is the will of God.
('29', 236, 9, 26, 484963) You know how originally my vow consisted of two parts.
('29', 236, 9, 27, 485018) One of them is fulfilled.
('29', 236, 9, 28, 485044) Another part I held back in response to the wishes of friends who were present at Mr.
('29', 236, 10, 29, 485130) 1 From the postmark 2 Music teacher in the Ashram; a member of the Dandi March group 3 Addressee’s son
('29', 237, 0, 1, 485233) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 237, 1, 2, 485275) Mahomed Ali’s house that night.
('29', 237, 1, 3, 485307) Even if I had retained this second part, my fast would now have been broken in view of the success of the Unity Conference.
('29', 237, 2, 4, 485431) Addressing the Mussalmans through Hakim Ajmal Khan and Mr. Mahomed Ali, Mr. Gandhi said: Today I beseech you to promise that you will, if necessary, lay down your life for the sake of Hindu Muslim unity.
('29', 237, 2, 5, 485635) For me, Hinduism would be meaningless if that unity is not achieved, and I make bold to say the same thing about Islam.
('29', 237, 2, 6, 485755) We ought to be able to live together.
('29', 237, 2, 7, 485793) The Hindus must be able to offer their worship in perfect freedom in their temples, and so should Mussalmans be able to say their azan and prayer with equal freedom in their mosques.
('29', 237, 2, 8, 485976) If we cannot ensure this elemental freedom of worship, then neither Hinduism nor Islam has any meaning.
('29', 237, 2, 9, 486080) I want this promise from you, and I know I have it; but as I am about to break my fast, I am so weighed down with the sense of responsibility that I am asking you to renew the pledge.
('29', 237, 3, 10, 486264) New India, 9 10 1924
('29', 237, 4, 11, 486285) 195. IMPORTANCE OF” TAPAS”
('29', 237, 5, 12, 486312) October 8, 1924
('29', 237, 6, 13, 486328) There are instances of tapas [penance] at every step in Hindu mythology.
('29', 237, 6, 14, 486401) Parvati desired to win Shankara and she took to tapas.
('29', 237, 6, 15, 486456) Siva did something wrong and so he undertook tapas.
('29', 237, 6, 16, 486508) Vishwamitra was the very incarnation of tapas.
('29', 237, 6, 17, 486555) When Rama went into exile, Bharata plunged into yoga discipline, practised austere tapas and wore out his body.
('29', 237, 6, 18, 486667) God cannot test man in any other manner.
('29', 237, 6, 19, 486708) If the soul is different from the body, it should remain blissful even when the body is tormented.
('29', 237, 6, 20, 486807) Food is nourishment for the body, whereas knowledge and meditation are sustenance to the soul.
('29', 237, 6, 21, 486902) Everyone has to realize this for himself as and when occasion arises.
('29', 237, 6, 22, 486972) If, however, the tapas is not accompanied by faith, devotion and humility, then all that austerity becomes a futile exercise.
('29', 237, 6, 23, 487098) It also becomes hypocrisy.
('29', 237, 6, 24, 487125) A devotee of God who enjoys eating his meal is a thousand times better than such an ascetic.
('29', 237, 6, 25, 487218) I have not the strength today to narrate the story of my tapas
('29', 238, 0, 1, 487281) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 239
('29', 238, 1, 2, 487329) but I may state this much that I cannot possibly live without tapas.
('29', 238, 1, 3, 487398) Once again I am destined to plunge into the stormy ocean.
('29', 238, 1, 4, 487456) Please, God, know that I am humble and protect me.
('29', 238, 1, 5, 487507) [From Gujarati]
('29', 238, 2, 6, 487523) Navajivan, I2 10 1924

('29', 241, 7, 11, 491418) 203. DUTY OF A NON CO OPERATOR
('29', 241, 8, 12, 491449) Wednesday, Aso Vad 3 [October 15, 1924]
('29', 241, 9, 13, 491489) It may be said that non co operation will be suspended at the forthcoming Congress session.
('29', 241, 9, 14, 491581) However, this does not imply that non co operators will suspend work.
('29', 241, 9, 15, 491651) In fact, what was only an illusion of non co operation will be suspended.
('29', 241, 9, 16, 491725) Where there is love, both co operation and non co operation are in fact one and the same thing.
('29', 241, 10, 17, 491821) Whether the father and son co operate or non co operate with each other, both the attitudes should be the fruit of love.
('29', 241, 10, 18, 491942) Co operation is not worth the name when born out of selfishness; it is rather a kind of bribe.
('29', 241, 10, 19, 492037) So also non co operation born out of hatred is a grave sin.
('29', 241, 10, 20, 492097) Both these should be eschewed.
('29', 241, 11, 21, 492128) The non co operation that was introduced in I920 was rooted in love; maybe the people were not aware of this and joined it out of hatred.
('29', 241, 11, 22, 492266) Nevertheless, if all the leaders had understood its true nature and acted in accordance with it, we could have avoided the bitter results that have followed.
('29', 241, 12, 23, 492424) 1 From the postmark
('29', 242, 0, 1, 492444) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 243
('29', 242, 1, 2, 492492) We did not understand peaceful non co operation.
('29', 242, 1, 3, 492541) Hence hatred increased, and we have now to suffer the fruit of our own actions.
('29', 242, 1, 4, 492621) That hatred which inspired our non co operation with the British has now raised its head within our own ranks.
('29', 242, 1, 5, 492732) That hatred has appeared not only between Hindus and Muslims but also between co operators and non co operators.
('29', 242, 1, 6, 492845) Hence in order to prevent such perverted results of non co operation, we have to suspend it.
('29', 242, 1, 7, 492938) This does not mean merely that lawyers who would like to take up their legal practice or students who would like to return to Government schools could do so without a sense of shame.
('29', 242, 1, 8, 493121) In fact, those lawyers who have grasped the principle of non co operation will not resume practice; nor will such students return to Government schools.
('29', 242, 1, 9, 493274) The suspension of non co operation should result in our being repentant, in the non co operator embracing the co operator, winning the latter over through love and bearing no ill will towards him.
('29', 242, 1, 10, 493471) The latter may take assistance from the Government, be he a Government pleader, a Government servant, or a member of the Legislative Assembly; still the former should make friends and associate with them all and help and be helped by them in resolving disputes between Hindus and Muslims, in removing untouchability, in boycotting foreign cloth, in getting rid of the addiction to liquor and opium and in many such tasks.
('29', 242, 1, 11, 493893) It is for the non co operator to take the lead in these tasks.
('29', 242, 1, 12, 493956) In doing so, his tact, discretion, civility, love of peace and humility will be put to the test.
('29', 242, 1, 13, 494053) It is in winning over the co operator through love that the quality of the non co operator will be tested.
('29', 242, 1, 14, 494160) False flattery and rudeness should both be avoided.
('29', 242, 1, 15, 494212) The very first lesson consists in all of us uniting in order to strike the middle path.
('29', 242, 1, 16, 494300) May God help us.
('29', 242, 2, 17, 494317) [From Gujarati]
('29', 242, 3, 18, 494333) Navajivan, 19 10 1924

('29', 250, 1, 2, 510474) 207. SPINNING FRANCHISE
('29', 250, 2, 3, 510498) “Spinning as a voluntary sacrifice is all right, but as a qualification for franchise it is galling.” This is the substance of the objection that I hear against my proposal.
('29', 250, 2, 4, 510672) I must confess I am surprised at the objection, for it is offered not because it is spinning that matters, but because with the critics it is the restriction, the obligation that matters.
('29', 250, 2, 5, 510860) But why?
('29', 250, 2, 6, 510869) If a monetary qualification, that is, restriction, may be imposed, why not a working qualification?
('29', 250, 2, 7, 510969) Is it more honourable to pay than to labour?
('29', 250, 2, 8, 511014) Is it galling in a temperance association to require every member to be a teetotaller?
('29', 250, 2, 9, 511101) Is it galling in a naval association to require every member to possess certain naval qualifications?
('29', 250, 2, 10, 511203) Is it galling, say, in France where military skill is considered a necessity of national existence, to require every member to practise the use of arms?
('29', 250, 2, 11, 511356) If it is not galling to have the requisite test in any of these cases, why should it be galling in an Indian National Assembly to have spinning and the wearing of khaddar, which is a national necessity, to be the qualification for the franchise, or which is the same thing, the test of membership?
('29', 250, 2, 12, 511654) Is it not the easiest and readiest method of popularizing it and bringing it home to the people?
('29', 250, 2, 13, 511751) Of course, my argument is addressed only to those who regard as absolutely necessary that India should be self contained in so far as her clothing is concerned and that, principally, through the spinning wheel and the handloom.
('29', 250, 3, 14, 511979) Young India, 16 10 1924
('29', 250, 4, 15, 512003) 208. ALLAHABAD AND JUBBULPUR
('29', 250, 5, 16, 512032) My fast and the Unity Conference notwithstanding, riots have taken place in Allahabad and Jubbulpur.
('29', 250, 5, 17, 512133) No one expected that all riots will end as if by magic because of the Conference or the fast.
('29', 250, 5, 18, 512227) But I do expect that the Press will write of such riots with restraint and without bias.
('29', 250, 5, 19, 512316) I do hope, too, that the leaders of both the communities and belonging to all parties will co operate to find out the causes and deal with them and issue to the public a correct version.

('29', 252, 1, 2, 513726) 211. DISCUSSION WITH HASSAN NIZAMI
('29', 252, 2, 3, 513761) [About October 16, 1924] 1
('29', 252, 3, 4, 513788) Gandhiji said: I ought to acknowledge that I have read this article of yours.
('29', 252, 3, 5, 513866) I too did not approve of it.
('29', 252, 3, 6, 513895) There is a reason for this.
('29', 252, 3, 7, 513923) You are free to criticize, but you have made fun of the conference as a whole.
('29', 252, 3, 8, 514002) Your criticism is not in the right spirit.
('29', 252, 3, 9, 514045) The purport of it appears to be that you do not desire unity at all and that you disapprove of the very fact that the conference was held.
('29', 252, 3, 10, 514184) Why should we not be critical?
('29', 252, 3, 11, 514215) We must admit, at any rate, that those who had assembled meant to do some good work and made an honest effort to do so.
('29', 252, 3, 12, 514335) You, however, have adopted an attitude of fun and ridicule alone.
('29', 252, 3, 13, 514401) And what a newspaper you chose for this!
('29', 252, 3, 14, 514442) Muballig, a paper which has long been and is still full of hatred.
('29', 252, 3, 15, 514509) Could you not have chosen any other newspaper?
('29', 252, 3, 16, 514556) You could have written to Young India.
('29', 252, 3, 17, 514595) You could have admitted the bona fides of the conference.
('29', 252, 3, 18, 514653) However, because your article appears in a newspaper which is given to venomous and acrimonious writing, some persons may perhaps get the impression that Khwaja Sahib is opposed to the very idea of unity.
('29', 252, 3, 19, 514858) Are you not talking of Abdul Kadar Jilani?
('29', 252, 3, 20, 514901) 2 In jail too I had read of him.
('29', 252, 3, 21, 514934) Once, when he, as a child, set out on a journey, his mother had given him some gold coins.
('29', 252, 3, 22, 515025) As he was but a child she sewed them up in his coat and, together with these coins, gave him the instruction not to tell a lie under any circumstances, even if heaven and earth crashed but always to tell the truth.
('29', 252, 3, 23, 515240) The party was waylaid by robbers, who searched everyone and took that they had.
('29', 252, 3, 24, 515320) It was Abdul Kadar’s turn.
('29', 252, 3, 25, 515347) He was asked what he had on him.
('29', 252, 3, 26, 515380) He pointed to the gold coins sewed inside the coat.
('29', 252, 3, 27, 515432) The robbers were astonished and set him free.
('29', 252, 3, 28, 515478) More than that, his truthfulness resulted in their returning the loot taken from the others as well.
('29', 252, 3, 29, 515579) Even though Islam abounds in such instances, it is not proper that you cite them before Hindus.
('29', 252, 3, 30, 515675) Are there such instances only in Islam?
('29', 252, 3, 31, 515715) They can be found at every step in Hinduism also.
('29', 252, 3, 32, 515765) However, just as one need not give up one’s own religion and take to Hinduism
('29', 252, 4, 33, 515843) 1 Mahadev Desai reports that the discussion took place in the fifth week after commencement of Gandhiji’s fast.
('29', 252, 4, 34, 515955) 2 During the conversation Khwaja Hassan Nizami narrated how Hazrat Ghaus or Abdul Kadar Jilani won over his rowdy neighbour to Islam by his generous good neighbourly behaviour.
('29', 253, 0, 1, 516132) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 253, 1, 2, 516174) because of these instances, similarly, one need not embrace Islam because of instances like those of Abdul Kadar.
('29', 253, 1, 3, 516288) I do not mind if there are many such instances among Muslims and, because of them, the whole of India gets converted to Islam.
('29', 253, 1, 4, 516415) However, just as there have been the best as well as the worst of men among Hindus, so too there are wicked persons among the Muslims also.
('29', 253, 1, 5, 516555) I would not like you to cite the example of Abdul Kadar to convert anyone to Islam.
('29', 253, 1, 6, 516639) You can talk to Hindus on other matters.
('29', 253, 1, 7, 516680) Why do you ask the Dheds and the Bhangis to become Muslims?
('29', 253, 1, 8, 516740) You could tell the Hindus,” There have been very tolerant men amongst you; you treat all creatures alike; how can you regard human beings as untouchables?
('29', 253, 1, 9, 516895) Are you not ashamed of keeping humans apart?” You can serve Hinduism in this manner.
('29', 253, 1, 10, 516980) By quoting the example of Abdul Kadar, I could tell Muslims,” Your religion is practised by such lovers of truth who advocate tolerance and who would forgive even their enemies.
('29', 253, 1, 11, 517158) How can you bring disgrace upon them?” Thus would I serve Islam.
('29', 253, 1, 12, 517223) We would then be purifying our own religion to such an extent that no one would be able to prevent those who wish to embrace it.
('29', 253, 1, 13, 517352) It would, however, be an outrage to take advantage of someone’s poverty and tell him,” Come my friend, I shall give you so many rupees, pay off your debts; because your co religionists are pestering you, you come over to us.” He does this not because of his love for Islam, but because of the sum that is offered to him.
('29', 253, 1, 14, 517673) What food did the people get who came to Mohammed Sahib?
('29', 253, 1, 15, 517730) Dates and water, and when even that was not available, a fast.
('29', 253, 1, 16, 517793) Nevertheless, out of respect for his personality and drawn by his spiritual power, people used to flock to him and embrace Islam.
('29', 253, 1, 17, 517923) Speaking for myself, if a new Mohammed Sahib comes forward and, drawn by his personal magnetism, the whole world gets converted to Islam, I would not mind this in the least.
('29', 253, 1, 18, 518097) I say all this only because I know the appeal of Islam.
('29', 253, 1, 19, 518153) I do not believe that Islam was spread through the sword; it has been spread by fakirs.
('29', 253, 1, 20, 518241) It has spread through truth, austerity and courage.
('29', 253, 1, 21, 518293) Everyone will admit that Islam has been defended by the sword; but for its spread only the fakirs can claim credit.
('29', 253, 1, 22, 518409) I, therefore, assert that spreading Islam through force or favours or in any such way is not rendering service to it but rather bringing disgrace upon it.
('29', 253, 1, 23, 518564) I say this only because of my love for Islam.
('29', 253, 1, 24, 518610) [From Gujarati]

('29', 256, 13, 15, 521940) Aso Vad 7, 1980 [October 20, 1924]
('29', 256, 14, 16, 521975) The Education Conference has passed a resolution that the Vidyapith should accord the first priority to primary education.
('29', 256, 14, 17, 522098) I intended to place some practical suggestions about this resolution before the Vidyapith; but an age has passed before I could do so, as I was occupied with other matters.
('29', 256, 14, 18, 522271) I have not, however, forgotten the subject of primary education.
('29', 256, 14, 19, 522336) But before offering any practical suggestion to the Vidyapith, I take the liberty of placing before the teachers some of my ideas about education.
('29', 256, 14, 20, 522483) I have felt for many years that in the curriculum we have been placing a disproportionate emphasis on mere literacy and, in consequence, we find text books multiplying day after day.
('29', 256, 14, 21, 522666) We have been misled into the belief that no knowledge can be

('29', 257, 0, 1, 523088) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 257, 1, 2, 523130) imparted to children until they learn the letters of the alphabet.
('29', 257, 1, 3, 523197) I have not known a stronger superstition in the field of education.
('29', 257, 1, 4, 523265) This wrong notion, I am convinced curbs the child’s development.
('29', 257, 1, 5, 523330) This belief is based on experience—that a child’s mind can grow before he picks up the alphabet.
('29', 257, 1, 6, 523427) By insisting on the alphabet, the child’s development is arrested.
('29', 257, 1, 7, 523494) Every teacher can see within a month what great progress a seven year old child can make if he imparts oral lessons instead of making him learn the alphabet.
('29', 257, 1, 8, 523652) Teachers can easily talk history, geography and science to children.
('29', 257, 1, 9, 523721) A child can learn the essence of the Ramayana and the Mahabharata in the course of a year.
('29', 257, 1, 10, 523812) Generally the child is taught these things after a schooling of four or five years.
('29', 257, 1, 11, 523896) How pathetic is it that a child should take one year to say and read” Mother, give me water to drink!” By burdening the child with the alphabet, we arrest his progress, keep him from knowledge, clog his memory and in our zeal to teach him the alphabet, we distort his handwriting; we make him a slave of text books from his childhood and ultimately we place the unnecessary burden of buying barren books on poor India.
('29', 257, 1, 12, 524315) If I could convince the teachers, I would abolish all textbooks in primary education or give them only to teachers.
('29', 257, 1, 13, 524431) These books have to be planned differently.
('29', 257, 1, 14, 524475) Instead of teaching the child the letters of the alphabet in the beginning, I would teach him drawing so that the child, from the very beginning, learns to draw beautiful designs.
('29', 257, 1, 15, 524655) He may well take two or three years to learn the alphabet.
('29', 257, 1, 16, 524714) We can impart orally to him a lot of practical and religious instruction in those three years.
('29', 257, 1, 17, 524809) We can develop has memory by making him repeat verses from the Gita and other sacred books.
('29', 257, 1, 18, 524901) Thereby his ears get tuned up, his tongue practises clear pronunciation, and his eyes learn to observe.
('29', 257, 1, 19, 525005) Thus all the power of the child can be developed simultaneously.
('29', 257, 1, 20, 525070) Meanwhile the alphabet can be introduced to him as a distinct art.
('29', 257, 1, 21, 525137) The handwriting of young people today is deplorable and disgusting.
('29', 257, 1, 22, 525205) I say this from personal experience because my handwriting is so bad that I am ashamed to write to anyone and I always regret my crude, untrained hand.
('29', 257, 1, 23, 525357) Raw cereals are not eaten; similarly, one writing a raw hand is deemed a savage.
('29', 257, 1, 24, 525438) I have often felt that there should be a boycott of articles written by such a man.
('29', 257, 1, 25, 525522) If we take this first and necessary step in primary education, we shall be saved much expenditure and also add to the life span of the children by hastening their development.
('29', 257, 1, 26, 525698) [From Gujarati] Navajivan (Education Supplement), Vol. I, No 7, 26 10 1924
