('29', 261, 13, 15, 529717) 229. DISCUSSION WITH G. RAMACHANDRAN 3
('29', 261, 14, 16, 529756) [Tuesday and Wednesday, October 21 and 22, 1924] 4
('29', 261, 15, 17, 529807) Among those who visited Dilkhush, during the weeks of penance and prayer, there was a young student from Shantiniketan named Ramachandran.
('29', 261, 15, 18, 529946) He is one of the pupils of Mr. Andrews and he had no difficulty in persuading his teacher to permit him to stay at Delhi for some time.
('29', 261, 15, 19, 530082) On the evening when Mr. Andrews left Delhi, he took Ramachandran upstairs and said to Gandhiji,” I have not even introduced
('29', 261, 16, 20, 530206) 1 In reply to the addressee’s telegram received on October 21 which read:” Brickbat at Tazia excited fight.
('29', 261, 16, 21, 530314) Four Mohammedans shot injured.
('29', 261, 16, 22, 530345) Four Hindus shot injured.
('29', 261, 16, 23, 530371) Several wounded.
('29', 261, 16, 24, 530388) Few temples and Arya Samaj mandir alleged desecrated.
('29', 261, 16, 25, 530442) Feelings high.
('29', 261, 16, 26, 530457) Thirty six Hindus under trial.
('29', 261, 16, 27, 530488) Three cases 307/338 Penal Code.” 2 This has been written on the back of the telegram received from the Congress Secretary, Pilibhit; vide footnote to preceding item.
('29', 261, 17, 28, 530654) 3 This appeared in two instalments in Young India, 13 11 1924 and 26 11 1924, under the title,” A Morning with Gandhiji”, over the signature of Mahadev Desai.
('29', 261, 17, 29, 530813) 4 In Navajivan, 2 11 1924, Mahadev Desai writing under the date line” Delhi, Wednesday, October 29, 1924” referred to the departure of Ramachandran” in the last week”.
('29', 261, 17, 30, 530981) The discussion, therefore, appears to have taken place on these dates.
('29', 262, 0, 1, 531052) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 263
('29', 262, 1, 2, 531100) Ramachandran as yet to you.
('29', 262, 1, 3, 531128) But he has been here all the while with us helping us.
('29', 262, 1, 4, 531183) He wants to ask you some questions and I shall be so glad if you could have a talk with him before he leaves tomorrow to go back to Shantiniketan.” The” tomorrow” was a silent Monday, and so Ramachandran stayed a day more.
('29', 262, 1, 5, 531406) On Tuesday morning he had to take his train for Calcutta.
('29', 262, 1, 6, 531464) Exactly at half past five, after the morning prayer, he was summoned.
('29', 262, 1, 7, 531534) He had set down his questions—the doubts and difficulties that tormented him.
('29', 262, 1, 8, 531612) Yet he could not altogether trust himself at first to be able to ask all that he wanted to.
('29', 262, 1, 9, 531704) But ultimately he mustered sufficient courage, and he found to his utter surprise that in a moment Bapu’s gentle inquiries about him, his place, his studies, had left no room for hesitation or nervousness.
('29', 262, 1, 10, 531910) It is impossible to reproduce all the conversation that Ramachandran was privileged to have that morning with Gandhiji.
('29', 262, 1, 11, 532030) I call but present the barest summary.
('29', 262, 2, 12, 532069) [RAMACNANDRAN:] How is it that many intelligent and eminent men, who love and admire you, hold that you consciously or unconsciously have ruled out of the scheme of national regeneration all considerations of Art?
('29', 262, 2, 13, 532283) [GANDHIJI:] I am sorry that in this matter I have been generally misunderstood.
('29', 262, 2, 14, 532363) There are two aspects of things—the outward and the inward.
('29', 262, 2, 15, 532423) It is purely a matter of emphasis with me.
('29', 262, 2, 16, 532466) The outward has no meaning except in so far as it helps the inward.
('29', 262, 2, 17, 532534) All true Art is thus the expression of the soul.
('29', 262, 2, 18, 532583) The outward forms have value only in so far as they are the expression of the inner spirit of man.
('29', 262, 3, 19, 532682) [R:] (Hesitatingly.) The great artists themselves have declared, that Art is the translation of the urge and unrest in the soul of the artist into words, colours, shapes, etc.
('29', 262, 3, 20, 532858) Yes, Art of that nature has the greatest possible appeal for me.
('29', 262, 3, 21, 532923) But I know that many call themselves as artists, and are recognized as such, and yet in their works there is absolutely no trace of the soul’s upward urge and unrest.
('29', 262, 4, 22, 533090) [R:] Have you any Instance in mind?
('29', 262, 4, 23, 533126) Yes, take Oscar Wilde.
('29', 262, 4, 24, 533149) I can speak of him, as I was in England at the time that he was being much discussed and talked about.
('29', 262, 5, 25, 533252) [R:] I have been told that Oscar Wilde was one of the greatest literary artists of modern times.
('29', 262, 5, 26, 533349) Yes, that is just my trouble.
('29', 262, 5, 27, 533379) Wilde sat the highest Art simply in outward forms and therefore succeeded in beautifying immorality.
('29', 262, 5, 28, 533480) All true Art must help the soul to realize its inner self.
('29', 262, 5, 29, 533539) In my own case, I find that I can do entirely without external forms in my soul’s realization.
('29', 262, 5, 30, 533634) I can claim, therefore, that there is truly sufficient Art in
('29', 263, 0, 1, 533696) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 263, 1, 2, 533738) my life, though you might not see what you call works of Art about me.
('29', 263, 1, 3, 533809) My room may have blank walls; and I may even dispense with the roof, so that I may gaze out upon the starry heavens overhead that stretch in an unending expanse of beauty.
('29', 263, 1, 4, 533981) What conscious Art of man can give me the panoramic scenes that open out before me, when I look up to the sky above with all its shining stars?
('29', 263, 1, 5, 534125) This, however, does not mean that I refuse to accept the value of productions of Art, generally accepted as such, but only that I personally feel how inadequate these are compared with the eternal symbols of beauty in Nature.
('29', 263, 1, 6, 534351) These productions of man’s Art have their value only so far as they help the soul onward towards self realization.
('29', 263, 2, 7, 534466) [R:] But the artists claim to see and to find Truth through outward beauty.
('29', 263, 2, 8, 534542) Is it possible to see and find Truth in that way?
('29', 263, 2, 9, 534592) I would reverse the order.
('29', 263, 2, 10, 534619) I see and find Beauty in Truth or through Truth.
('29', 263, 2, 11, 534668) All Truths, not merely true ideas, but truthful faces, truthful pictures, or songs, are highly beautiful.
('29', 263, 2, 12, 534774) People generally fail to see Beauty in Truth, the ordinary man runs away from it and becomes blind to the beauty in it.
('29', 263, 2, 13, 534894) Whenever men begin to see Beauty in Truth, then true Art will arise.
('29', 263, 3, 14, 534963) [R:] But cannot Beauty be separated from Truth, and Truth from Beauty?
('29', 263, 3, 15, 535034) I should want to know exactly what is Beauty.
('29', 263, 3, 16, 535080) If it is what people generally understand by that word, then they are wide apart.
('29', 263, 3, 17, 535162) Is a woman with fair features necessarily beautiful?
('29', 263, 4, 18, 535215) [R :] Yes.
('29', 263, 4, 19, 535226) Even if she may be of an ugly character?
('29', 263, 5, 20, 535267) [R:] But her face in that case cannot be beautiful.
('29', 263, 5, 21, 535319) It will always be the index of the soul within.
('29', 263, 5, 22, 535367) The true artist with the genius of perception will produce the right expression.
('29', 263, 5, 23, 535448) But here you are begging the whole question.
('29', 263, 5, 24, 535493) You now admit that mere outward form may not make a thing beautiful.
('29', 263, 5, 25, 535562) To a true artist only that face is beautiful which, quite apart from exterior, shines with the Truth within the soul.
('29', 263, 5, 26, 535680) There is then, as I have said, no Beauty apart from Truth.
('29', 263, 5, 27, 535739) On the other hand, Truth may manifest itself in forms which may not be outwardly beautiful at all.
('29', 263, 5, 28, 535838) Socrates, we are told, was the most truthful man of his time and yet his features are said to have been the ugliest in Greece.
('29', 263, 5, 29, 535965) To my mind he was beautiful, because all his life was a striving after Truth, and you may remember that his outward form did not prevent Phidias from appreciating the
('29', 264, 0, 1, 536132) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 265
('29', 264, 1, 2, 536180) beauty of Truth in him, though as an artist he was accustomed to see Beauty in outward forms also!
('29', 264, 2, 3, 536279) [R:] But, Bapuji, the most beautiful things have often been created by men whose own lives were not beautiful.
('29', 264, 2, 4, 536390) That only means that Truth and untruth often co exist; good and evil are often found together.
('29', 264, 2, 5, 536485) In an artist also not seldom the right perception of things and the wrong co exist.
('29', 264, 2, 6, 536569) Truly beautiful creations come when right perception is at work.
('29', 264, 2, 7, 536634) If these moments are rare in life, they are also rare in Art.
('29', 264, 3, 8, 536696) [R:] If only truthful or good things can be beautiful, how can things without a moral quality be beautiful?
('29', 264, 3, 9, 536804) Is there truth, Bapuji, in things that are neither moral nor immoral in themselves?
('29', 264, 3, 10, 536888) For instance, is there truth in a sunset or a crescent moon that shines amid the stars at night?
('29', 264, 3, 11, 536985) Indeed these beauties are truthful, inasmuch as they make me think of the Creator at the back of them.
('29', 264, 3, 12, 537088) How else could these be beautiful, but for the Truth that is in the centre of creation?
('29', 264, 3, 13, 537176) When I admire the wonder of a sunset or the beauty of the moon, my soul expands in worship of the Creator.
('29', 264, 3, 14, 537283) I try to see Him and His mercies in all these creations.
('29', 264, 3, 15, 537340) But even the sunsets and sunrises would be mere hindrances, if they did not help me to think of Him.
('29', 264, 3, 16, 537441) Anything which is a hindrance to the flight of the soul, is a delusion and a snare; even, like the body, which often does hinder you in the path of salvation.
('29', 264, 4, 17, 537600) [R:] I am grateful to hear your views on Art, and l understand and accept them.
('29', 264, 4, 18, 537680) Would it not be well for you to set them down for the benefit of the younger generation in order to guide them aright?
('29', 264, 4, 19, 537799) That I could never dream of doing, for the simple reason that it would be an impertinence on my part to hold forth on Art.
('29', 264, 4, 20, 537922) I am not an art student, though these are my fundamental convictions.
('29', 264, 4, 21, 537992) I do not speak or write about it, because I am conscious of my own limitations.
('29', 264, 4, 22, 538072) That consciousness is my only strength.
('29', 264, 4, 23, 538112) Whatever I might have been able to do in my life has proceeded more than anything else out of the realisation of my own limitations.
('29', 264, 4, 24, 538245) My functions are different from the artist’s and I should not go out of my way to assume his position.
('29', 264, 5, 25, 538348) [R:] Are you against all machinery, Bapuji?
('29', 264, 5, 26, 538392) How can I be when I know that even this body is a most delicate piece of machinery?
('29', 264, 5, 27, 538476) The spinning wheel itself is amachine; a little tooth pick is a machine.
('29', 264, 5, 28, 538549) What I object to, is the craze for machinery, not machinery as such.
('29', 264, 5, 29, 538618) The craze is for what they call labour saving
('29', 265, 0, 1, 538664) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 265, 1, 2, 538706) machinery.
('29', 265, 1, 3, 538717) Men go on” saving labour” till thousands are without work and thrown on the open streets to die of starvation.
('29', 265, 1, 4, 538828) I want to save time and labour, not for a fraction of mankind, but for all.
('29', 265, 1, 5, 538904) I want the concentration of wealth, not in the hands of a few, but in the hands of all.
('29', 265, 1, 6, 538992) Today machinery merely helps a few to ride on the backs of millions.
('29', 265, 1, 7, 539061) The impetus behind it all is not the philanthropy to save labour, but greed.
('29', 265, 1, 8, 539138) It is against this constitution of things that I am fighting with all my might.
('29', 265, 2, 9, 539218) [R:] Then Bapuji, you are fighting not against machinery as such, but against its abuses which are so much in evidence today?
('29', 265, 3, 10, 539344) I would unhesitatingly say” yes”; but I would add that scientific truths and discoveries should first of all cease to be the mere instruments of greed.
('29', 265, 3, 11, 539496) Then labourers will not be over worked and machinery instead of becoming a hindrance will be a help.
('29', 265, 3, 12, 539597) I am aiming, not at eradication of all machinery, but limitations.
('29', 265, 4, 13, 539664) [R:] When logically argued out, that would seem to imply that all complicated power driven machinery should go.
('29', 265, 5, 14, 539776) It might have to go, but I must make one thing clear.
('29', 265, 5, 15, 539830) The supreme consideration is man.
('29', 265, 5, 16, 539864) The machine should not tend to make atrophied the limbs of man.
('29', 265, 5, 17, 539928) For instance, I would make intelligent exceptions.
('29', 265, 5, 18, 539979) Take the case of the Singer Sewing Machine.
('29', 265, 5, 19, 540023) It is one of the few useful things ever invented, and there is a romance about the device itself.
('29', 265, 5, 20, 540121) Singer saw his wife labouring over the tedious process of sewing and seaming with her own hands, and simply out of his love for her, he devised the sewing machine, in order to save her from unnecessary labour.
('29', 265, 5, 21, 540331) He, however, saved not only her labour but also the labour of everyone who could purchase a sewing machine.
('29', 265, 6, 22, 540439) [R:] But, in that case, there would have to be a factory for making these Singer Sewing Machines, and it would have to contain power driven machinery of ordinary type.
('29', 265, 7, 23, 540607) But I am socialist enough to say that such factories should be nationalized, or State controlled.
('29', 265, 7, 24, 540705) They ought only to be working under the most attractive and ideal conditions, not for profit, but for the benefit of humanity, love taking the place of greed as the motive.
('29', 265, 7, 25, 540878) It is an alteration in the conditions of labour that I want.
('29', 265, 7, 26, 540939) This mad rush for wealth must cease, and the labourer must be assured, not only of a living wage, but a daily task that is not a mere drudgery.
('29', 266, 0, 1, 541083) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 267
('29', 266, 1, 2, 541131) machine will, under these conditions, be as much a help to the man working it as to the State, or the man who owns it.
('29', 266, 1, 3, 541250) The present mad rush will cease, and the labourer will work (as I have said) under attractive and ideal conditions.
('29', 266, 1, 4, 541366) This is but one of the exceptions I have in mind.
('29', 266, 1, 5, 541416) The sewing machine had love at its back.
('29', 266, 1, 6, 541457) The individual is the one supreme consideration.
('29', 266, 1, 7, 541506) The saving of labour of the individual should be the object, and honest humanitarian considerations, and not greed, the motive.
('29', 266, 1, 8, 541634) Thus, for instance, I would welcome any day a machine to straighten crooked spindles.
('29', 266, 1, 9, 541720) Not that blacksmiths will cease to make spindles; they will continue to provide the spindles; but when the spindle gets wrong, every spinner will have a machine of his own to get it straight.
('29', 266, 1, 10, 541912) Therefore, replace greed by love and everything will come right.
('29', 266, 2, 11, 541977) Ramachandran was evidently not satisfied with this.
('29', 266, 2, 12, 542029) He had understood Gandhiji to be against all machinery and he had felt that this was right too.
('29', 266, 2, 13, 542125) So he wanted to go to the root of the matter.
('29', 266, 2, 14, 542171) But it was getting late and he had many more questions to ask.
('29', 266, 2, 15, 542234) Don’t mind losing your train.
('29', 266, 2, 16, 542264) I am prepared to satisfy you.
('29', 266, 2, 17, 542294) You may ask any questions you like this morning, and it won’t tire me now in the least.
('29', 266, 3, 18, 542382) The young friend had by no means exhausted his list of questions.
('29', 266, 3, 19, 542448) The assurance from Gandhiji that he would give him full liberty that morning put him entirely at ease and gathering courage once more he proceeded with the next question which dealt with the institution of marriage.
('29', 266, 4, 20, 542664) [R:] The third question that I would like to ask you is whether you are against the institution of marriage.
('29', 266, 4, 21, 542773) I shall have to answer this question at some length.
('29', 266, 4, 22, 542826) The aim of human life is moksha.
('29', 266, 4, 23, 542859) As a Hindu, I believe that moksha is freedom from birth, by breaking the bonds of the flesh, by becoming one with God.
('29', 266, 4, 24, 542978) Now marriage is a hindrance in the attainment of this supreme object, inasmuch as it only tightens the bonds of flesh.
('29', 266, 4, 25, 543097) Celibacy is a great help, inasmuch as it enables one to lead a life of full surrender to God.
('29', 266, 4, 26, 543191) What is the object generally understood of marriage, except a repetition of one’s own kind?
('29', 266, 4, 27, 543283) And why need you advocate marriage?
('29', 266, 4, 28, 543319) It propagates itself.
('29', 266, 4, 29, 543341) It requires no agency to promote its growth.
('29', 266, 5, 30, 543386) [R:] But must you advocate celibacy and preach it to one and all?
('29', 266, 5, 31, 543452) Then you fear there will be an end of creation?
('29', 266, 5, 32, 543500) The extreme logical result would be, not extinction of the human species,
('29', 267, 0, 1, 543574) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 267, 1, 2, 543616) but the transference of it to a higher plane.
('29', 267, 2, 3, 543662) [R:] But may not an artist or a poet or a great genius leave a legacy of his genius to posterity through his own children?
('29', 267, 2, 4, 543785) Certainly not.
('29', 267, 2, 5, 543800) He will have more disciples than he can ever have children; and through those disciples all his gifts to the world will be handed down in a way that nothing else can do it.
('29', 267, 2, 6, 543973) It will be the soul’s marriage with the spirit; the progeny being the disciple—a sort of divine procreation.
('29', 267, 2, 7, 544082) You must leave marriage to take care of itself.
('29', 267, 2, 8, 544130) Repetition and not growth would be the result; for lust has come to play the most important part in marriage.
('29', 267, 3, 9, 544240) [R:] Mr. Andrews does not like your emphasis on celibacy.
('29', 267, 3, 10, 544298) Yes, I know that is the legacy of Protestantism.
('29', 267, 3, 11, 544347) Protestantism did many good things, but one of its few evils was that it ridiculed celibacy.
('29', 267, 4, 12, 544440) [R:] That was because it had to fight the deep abuses in which the clergy of the age had sunk.
('29', 267, 4, 13, 544535) But all that was not due to any inherent evil of celibacy.
('29', 267, 4, 14, 544594) It is celibacy that has kept Catholicism green up to the present day.
('29', 267, 5, 15, 544664) Ramachandran’s last question was about the much discussed”Spinning Franchise”.
('29', 267, 5, 16, 544743) Ramachandran assured Gandhiji, at the outset, that he was a spinner, but had to confess that he, with three friends at Shantiniketan, only began spinning after they had heard of the fast.
('29', 267, 5, 17, 544931) He also affirmed that he believed in universal spinning.
('29', 267, 5, 18, 544988) But he could not understand how the Congress could compel its members to spin.
('29', 267, 5, 19, 545067) Persuasion and not compulsion should be the method.
('29', 267, 5, 20, 545119) I see you go even farther than Mr. Andrews.
('29', 267, 5, 21, 545163) He would not have the Congress to compel its members; but he would fain become a member of a voluntary spinning association, with rules about spinning.
('29', 267, 5, 22, 545315) You object to any such association whatsoever?
('29', 267, 6, 23, 545362) Ramachandran sat silent.
('29', 267, 6, 24, 545387) Well, then I ask you, has the Congress any right to say that its members shall not drink?
('29', 267, 6, 25, 545477) Will that be a restriction of the freedom of the individual too?
('29', 267, 6, 26, 545542) If the Congress exercised the right of enjoining abstinence from drinking, there would be no objection.
('29', 267, 6, 27, 545646) Because the evils of drink are obvious.
('29', 267, 6, 28, 545686) Well, I say that in India today, where millions are on the brink of starvation and plunged in utter misery, it is perhaps a much worse evil to import foreign cloth.
('29', 267, 6, 29, 545851) Think of the starving millions of Orissa.
('29', 267, 6, 30, 545893) When I went there, I saw the famine stricken.
('29', 267, 6, 31, 545939) Thanks to a kind superintendent, who was in charge of an
('29', 268, 0, 1, 545996) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 269
('29', 268, 1, 2, 546044) industrial home, I saw also their children, bright, healthy and merry, working away at their carpets, baskets, etc.
('29', 268, 1, 3, 546160) There was no spinning, because these other things were much in vogue at the time.
('29', 268, 1, 4, 546242) But on their faces there was the lustre of joyful work.
('29', 268, 1, 5, 546298) But when I came to the famine stricken, what did I see?
('29', 268, 1, 6, 546354) They were merely skin and bone, only waiting to die.
('29', 268, 1, 7, 546407) They were then in that condition, because they would under no circumstances work.
('29', 268, 1, 8, 546489) Even though you had threatened to shoot them, if they refused to work, I am sure they would have preferred to be shot, rather than do any honest work.
('29', 268, 1, 9, 546640) This aversion from work is a greater evil than drink itself.
('29', 268, 1, 10, 546701) You can take some work out of a drunkard.
('29', 268, 1, 11, 546743) A drunkard retains something of a heart!
('29', 268, 1, 12, 546784) He has intelligence.
('29', 268, 1, 13, 546805) These starved men, refusing to work, were like mere animals.
('29', 268, 1, 14, 546866) Now, how can we solve the problem of getting work out of people like this?
('29', 268, 1, 15, 546941) I see no way except that of universalizing spinning.
('29', 268, 1, 16, 546994) Every yard of foreign cloth brought into India is one bit of bread snatched out of the mouths of the starving poor.
('29', 268, 1, 17, 547110) If you could visualise, as I can, the supreme need of the hour which is to give India’s starving millions a chance to earn their bread with joy and gladness, you would not object to the Spinning Franchise.
('29', 268, 1, 18, 547316) I take the Congress to be a body of men and women who accept the paramount necessity of spinning.
('29', 268, 1, 19, 547414) Why should it not ensure the integrity of membership in the body by making it compulsory for every member to spin?
('29', 268, 1, 20, 547529) And you talk of persuasion.
('29', 268, 1, 21, 547557) What can be better persuasion than that every member of the Congress spins regularly a certain quantity of yarn every month?
('29', 268, 1, 22, 547682) How would it be honest for the Congress members to ask people to spin, when they do not spin themselves?

('29', 268, 3, 32, 548353) Some men will have to be excluded under any franchise.
('29', 268, 3, 33, 548408) No; today many will not accept my position, but I have faith that the day will come—it may be after my death—when men will say that after all what Gandhi said was right.
('29', 269, 0, 1, 548578) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 269, 1, 2, 548620) It was now seven o’clock and Ramachandran had missed his train.
('29', 269, 1, 3, 548684) But he had gained what was infinitely more precious.
('29', 269, 1, 4, 548737) The next morning, before starting, he was fortunate enough to get another talk—this time a brief one, but one that at last converted him.
('29', 269, 2, 5, 548875) [R:] So, Bapuji, Truth is the main thing; Beauty and Truth are not separate aspects of the same thing.
('29', 269, 2, 6, 548978) Truth is the first thing to be sought for, and Beauty and Goodness will then be added unto you.
('29', 269, 2, 7, 549074) Jesus was, to my mind, a supreme artist, because he saw and expressed Truth; and so was Mohammed, the Koran being the most perfect composition in all Arabic literature—at any rate—that is what scholars say.

('29', 269, 2, 9, 549429) That is the Truth and Beauty I crave for, live for, and would die for.

('29', 269, 5, 17, 550078) No, I don’t, because they do not satisfy any of the primary wants of man; for it is not the primary need of man to traverse distances with the rapidity of a motor car.

('29', 273, 1, 5, 556432) It has done much harm already, in that it has divided the country into opposing parties.

('29', 276, 1, 2, 561521) 239. HINDUS AND MUSLIMS
('29', 276, 2, 3, 561545) The Conference for unity was only the starting point of unity.
('29', 276, 2, 4, 561608) Its resolutions were inadequate; those attending it were imperfect; hence the beginning too has been deficient.
('29', 276, 2, 5, 561720) Nevertheless, the Conference was of great importance.
('29', 276, 2, 6, 561774) It will strike deep roots; it is our duty to protect and water the tender plant it has set up.
('29', 276, 2, 7, 561869) We shall find on deeper reflection that the solution to this difficult question lies in one thing alone.
('29', 276, 2, 8, 561974) One should never take the law into one’s own hands.
('29', 276, 2, 9, 562026) It is uncivilized to take possession of the house across the street because I believe it is mine.
('29', 276, 2, 10, 562124) I should prove my claim before the pancha or the law court and respect the verdict given by one or the other.
('29', 276, 2, 11, 562234) Where this rule is not followed, the people perish.
('29', 276, 2, 12, 562286) No comment is necessary at all where both parties abide by this golden rule.
('29', 276, 2, 13, 562363) But even where one party is bent on violence, it is enough if the other party abides by this rule.
('29', 276, 2, 14, 562462) It is certain that the latter will not come to harm in the end.
('29', 276, 2, 15, 562526) Let us suppose, a third person takes possession of my house.
('29', 276, 2, 16, 562587) In a well organized society, the pancha would certainly have it restored to me.
('29', 276, 2, 17, 562667) In a less organized society, law courts would do this work.
('29', 276, 2, 18, 562727) Public opinion is the sanction behind the pancha, whereas prisons and guns are the sanctions behind the courts.
('29', 276, 2, 19, 562839) In either form of organization the person who does not resort to violence can regain his possession.
('29', 276, 3, 20, 562940) Disputes between us will undoubtedly continue so long as we do not abide by this inescapable rule; and it is an obvious fact that we shall never be able to win swaraj by peaceful means so long as such disputes continue.
('29', 276, 3, 21, 563160) It may be that neither Hindus nor Muslims are enamoured of swaraj and both prefer domestic disputes to swaraj.
('29', 276, 3, 22, 563271) No arguments would appeal to such people.
('29', 276, 3, 23, 563313) But for those who desire swaraj there is no alternative to the above rule.
('29', 276, 3, 24, 563388) We, who find it difficult to live without swaraj will not resort to the uncivilized rule of violence.
('29', 276, 4, 25, 563490) However, some occasions arise when, despite one’s firm resolution to appeal to the pancha or the law court, one has willingly or unwillingly to participate in acts of violence, or to run away or to face death peacefully.
('29', 276, 4, 26, 563711) What should I do if I am attacked by someone as I am passing before a mosque singing devotional songs?
('29', 276, 4, 27, 563814) What should I do if someone starts placing a tombstone in my own premises or what should a poor Muslim do if attacked by a Hindu while killing
('29', 277, 0, 1, 563957) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 277, 1, 2, 563999) a cow inside his own house?
('29', 277, 1, 3, 564027) In all these three instances there is no time to wait for the law to take its course.
('29', 277, 1, 4, 564113) What then should those individuals do?
('29', 277, 1, 5, 564152) If they can peacefully face death, there is no better way out.
('29', 277, 1, 6, 564215) Even the pancha is an inferior alternative.
('29', 277, 1, 7, 564259) But not many can make such a sacrifice.
('29', 277, 1, 8, 564299) Should one then run away?
('29', 277, 1, 9, 564325) That is a sign of cowardice.
('29', 277, 1, 10, 564354) So, ordinarily, there remains only one way out.
('29', 277, 1, 11, 564402) Everyone in such a situation finds the means of self defence by exchanging blows.
('29', 277, 1, 12, 564484) Under a well organized government each individual does have, and should have this right.
('29', 277, 1, 13, 564573) However, such occasions arise only rarely.
('29', 277, 1, 14, 564616) The chances of a good person being put to such a test are one in a hundred.
('29', 277, 1, 15, 564692) The common experience is that God does not put to test the person who remains peaceful.
('29', 277, 1, 16, 564780) On impartial consideration we shall find that in ninety nine cases out of a hundred, both the parties are to a greater or less extent responsible for the resulting violence.
('29', 277, 1, 17, 564954) In all such instances, even one party can, if it wishes to, remain free from blame.
('29', 277, 1, 18, 565038) And here, the one who remains blameless is the victor.

('29', 277, 4, 22, 565167) DELHI, October 26, 1924

('29', 278, 14, 17, 566060) It contains a statement by a girl implicating the Ali Brothers.
('29', 278, 14, 18, 566124) I showed it to Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('29', 278, 14, 19, 566160) Here is a copy of his statement.
('29', 278, 14, 20, 566193) Could you please see the editor of the paper and ask him if he has any further evidence to prove the allegations in the statement?
('29', 278, 14, 21, 566324) In my opinion he should have sent a copy of the statement to the Maulana before publishing it.
('29', 278, 14, 22, 566419) What I think should now be done is for the editor to call upon the parties to substantiate the allegations or withdraw them to the extent that is necessary.
('29', 278, 14, 23, 566576) If they would let us investigate the statement as arbitrators we should take up the matter.
('29', 278, 14, 24, 566668) Even if the girl’s statement is substantially correct, apart from the allegations against the Ali Brothers and others, it is a case we should probe if we are given the facilities.
('29', 278, 14, 25, 566848) If you agree with me and if the editor of Milap would help us, I would consult the other members of the Board.

('29', 282, 5, 11, 572490) 248. MESSAGE TO U.P. POLITICAL CONFERENCE, GORAKHPUR 2
('29', 282, 6, 12, 572545) DELHI, October 30, 1924
('29', 282, 7, 13, 572569) The policy that the Government has lately adopted in Bengal has distressed all.
('29', 282, 7, 14, 572649) The distress is natural.
('29', 282, 7, 15, 572674) It is not, however, owing to the lawlessness of policy; it is owing to our inability to give it a prompt reply.
('29', 282, 7, 16, 572786) I hope and I want that we shall not lose patience at this critical juncture.
('29', 282, 7, 17, 572863) I firmly hold that by becoming angry or impatient we shall not find the right remedy.
('29', 282, 7, 18, 572949) Action can only be answered with action.
('29', 282, 7, 19, 572990) And I dare say that we can answer the Government’s policy of violence only by a policy of non violence; we can answer its violent action only by non violent action.
('29', 282, 7, 20, 573155) If this is true we have to consider what non violent action we can undertake.
('29', 282, 7, 21, 573233) On a little reflection we see that the biggest obstacle in the way of any practical work that we can do is the schism between Hindus and Muslims.
('29', 282, 7, 22, 573379) The obstacle to our bringing the common people together is our indifference to the
('29', 282, 9, 23, 573462) 2 Published under the caption “The Cure for Government Lawlessness”.

('29', 283, 1, 2, 573573) charkha and khadi; and untouchability is a thing that is ruining the Hindu society.
('29', 283, 1, 3, 573657) So long as we have not rid ourselves of this threefold sin our portion can only be, in my humble opinion, Government lawlessness, slavery and poverty.
('29', 283, 1, 4, 573808) I can, therefore, offer no other counsel to the nation.
('29', 283, 1, 5, 573864) If we can achieve these three aims, we can demonstrate a strength even fiercer than what we showed in 1920 21. Then we can remove the misery not only of Bengal but of the whole of India.

('29', 283, 4, 8, 574107) 249. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU
('29', 283, 6, 9, 574136) October 30, 1924
('29', 283, 7, 10, 574153) DEAR MOTILALJI, Ever since the firing of the Viceregal bomb I have been taxing myself as to what we can do and our helplessness has preyed upon me.
('29', 283, 7, 11, 574301) This is our conclusion!
('29', 283, 7, 12, 574325) We must not do anything in haste or anger.
('29', 283, 7, 13, 574368) We must therefore bow before the storm.
('29', 283, 7, 14, 574408) For the time being we must revert to the old method of simply expressing our opinion and we should concentrate all India opinion upon the lawless methods of the Government and therefore attack the principle of the Government adopting extra ordinary measures and should therefore call upon the Government to repeal even Regulation III of 1818. If extraordinary powers are required by an extraordinary situation, they can be taken only upon a vote of elected representatives.
('29', 283, 7, 15, 574882) I know that even this is tall talk and it jars on me.
('29', 283, 7, 16, 574936) But I see no other way out at the present moment.
('29', 283, 7, 17, 574986) So much to the all India work.
('29', 283, 7, 18, 575017) If I could carry you, that is, you personally and Swarajists, with me, I would ask the Working Committee or the A.I.C.C. to concentrate its efforts upon the three items mentioned.
('29', 283, 7, 19, 575197) Give me a compact disciplined Congress, and I can see my way again to answering Government action with popular action.
('29', 283, 7, 20, 575316) But till then, and till Hindus and Mussalmans speak with one mind and till we show substantial work about khaddar and untouchability, I for one see no prospect of any effective direct
('29', 284, 0, 1, 575500) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 285
('29', 284, 1, 2, 575548) action.
('29', 284, 1, 3, 575556) Since the Bengal arrests, the idea of retiring from the Congress has possessed me, unless I receive the enthusiastic support of Swarajists in my proposals.
('29', 284, 1, 4, 575712) I simply want to bring into being a compact organization which will respond to every call.
('29', 284, 1, 5, 575803) I do not care how small that organization is.
('29', 284, 1, 6, 575849) All other non violent activities may go on.
('29', 284, 1, 7, 575893) I can understand their utility up to a point.
('29', 284, 1, 8, 575939) But I am convinced that they will all be a wasted effort, if nobody concerns himself with bringing into being a disciplined and effective organization.
('29', 284, 1, 9, 576091) I feel deeply hurt and humiliated that we cannot take up with any degree of effect the Government challenge.
('29', 284, 1, 10, 576200) I think I have told you all you can want to know from me.
('29', 284, 1, 11, 576258) I am sending you the following telegram: 1
('29', 284, 2, 12, 576301) I sent a little note to Das as he passed through Delhi.

('29', 286, 6, 18, 579106) 253. TWO SCENES
('29', 286, 7, 19, 579122) During my visit to Puri in 1921, I saw many things that I shall not easily forget.
('29', 286, 7, 20, 579205) But among them all there were two that I shall never forget.
('29', 286, 7, 21, 579266) One of them haunts me day and night.
('29', 286, 7, 22, 579303) In those days Puri had a philanthropic Superintendent of Police.
('29', 286, 7, 23, 579368) He managed an orphanage.
('29', 286, 7, 24, 579393) He showed it to me.
('29', 286, 7, 25, 579413) It had many happy, well looking, bright children who were engaged in all kinds of industries—mat weaving, basket making, spinning, weaving, etc.
('29', 286, 7, 26, 579558) The Superintendent told me they were all children of famine stricken
('29', 286, 8, 27, 579627) 1 The source has November 10, 1924; however, Kartik Sud 2 fell on this date.
('29', 287, 0, 1, 579704) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 287, 1, 2, 579746) parents, some of whom were picked up as mere skin and bone.
('29', 287, 2, 3, 579806) He then took me to an open space in the very shadow of the hoary temple where were arranged in rows the famine stricken people who were living within twelve miles of Puri.
('29', 287, 2, 4, 579978) Some of these no doubt owed their lives to the charity of the Gujaratis and the loving service of Amritlal Thakkar who doled out to them the rice he bought with the monies supplied by the Gujaratis.
('29', 287, 2, 5, 580177) The life was ebbing away in them.
('29', 287, 2, 6, 580211) They were living pictures of despair.
('29', 287, 2, 7, 580249) You could count every rib.
('29', 287, 2, 8, 580276) You could see every artery.
('29', 287, 2, 9, 580304) There was no muscle, no flesh.
('29', 287, 2, 10, 580335) Parched, crumpled skin and bone was all you could see.
('29', 287, 2, 11, 580390) There was no lustre in their eyes.
('29', 287, 2, 12, 580425) They seemed to want to die.
('29', 287, 2, 13, 580453) They had no interest in anything save the handful of rice they got.
('29', 287, 2, 14, 580521) They would not work for money.
('29', 287, 2, 15, 580552) For love, perhaps!
('29', 287, 2, 16, 580571) It almost seems as if they would condescend to eat and live if you would give them the handful of rice.
('29', 287, 2, 17, 580675) It is the greatest tragedy I know of—these men and women, our brothers and sisters, dying a slow torturing death.
('29', 287, 2, 18, 580789) Theirs is an eternal compulsory fast.
('29', 287, 2, 19, 580827) And as they break it occasionally with rice they seem to mock us for the life we live.
('29', 287, 2, 20, 580914) “Why could they not be kept like the orphans?” I asked the Superintendent.”They will not work and will not stay there”, was the reply.
('29', 287, 2, 21, 581049) The Superintendent might also have added that he could not accommodate thousands of starving men and women, even if they were ready to work, in an asylum.
('29', 287, 3, 22, 581204) There is on the face of the earth no other country that has the problem that India has, of chronic starvation and slow death —a process of dehumanization.
('29', 287, 3, 23, 581359) The solution must therefore be original.
('29', 287, 3, 24, 581400) In trying to find it we must discover the causes of the tremendous tragedy.

('29', 291, 2, 3, 589138) [October 31, 1924] 1
('29', 291, 3, 4, 589159) Some Urdu literature happened to come my way when I was in the Yeravda Jail.
('29', 291, 3, 5, 589236) Through it I had the great advantage of informing myself about Islam.
('29', 291, 3, 6, 589306) A copy of Hindustani Shikshak that Maulana Abul Kalam Azad had given me, I already had.
('29', 291, 3, 7, 589394) Having read it I became eager to read more.
('29', 291, 3, 8, 589438) What books worth reading were with Mr. Shwaib Qureshi, I had sent for.
('29', 291, 3, 9, 589509) But I had be come a little impatient.
('29', 291, 3, 10, 589547) I searched the jail library for books in Indian languages.
('29', 291, 3, 11, 589606) To my pleasant surprise I found Urdu, Marathi, Tamil, Kanarese and Gujarati books there.
('29', 291, 3, 12, 589695) To be sure the books were very few, but they were enough for my need at the time.
('29', 291, 3, 13, 589777) The catalogue that I saw included Urdu text books on religion for Muslim prisoners.
('29', 291, 3, 14, 589861) I was delighted.
('29', 291, 3, 15, 589878) I thought that by reading these text books I would not only be improving my knowledge of Urdu but would also have an opportunity of finding out what Muslim children were being taught.
('29', 291, 3, 16, 590062) In the text book for grade two there are a number of instructive lessons.
('29', 291, 3, 17, 590136) In one lesson some incidents from Prophet Mohammed’s life are described.
('29', 291, 3, 18, 590209) There are stories in it showing the Prophet’s humility, generosity, evenness of feeling for enemy and friend, ability to forgive, punctuality and fear of God.
('29', 291, 3, 19, 590368) Take, for instance, his behaviour towards the Jew money lender who had gone to abuse and denounce him.
('29', 291, 3, 20, 590471) Hazrat Omar felt that great insult was being offered to his preceptor.
('29', 291, 3, 21, 590542) He could not bear it.
('29', 291, 3, 22, 590564) But the Prophet took his disciple to task and asked him to pay the money lender not only the principal but also something more as a token of repentance for the wrong he had done.
('29', 291, 3, 23, 590743) This extraordinary treatment of the money lender had a consequence that Hazrat Omar had never hoped for.
('29', 291, 3, 24, 590848) That Jew, it is said, embraced Islam.
('29', 291, 3, 25, 590886) In this same lesson there is something about a non Muslim also.
('29', 291, 3, 26, 590950) Once the Prophet was sleeping under a tree, alone and unarmed.
('29', 291, 3, 27, 591013) A man went to him and said,”Speak up, Mohammed, who is there to save you now?” The answer was:”Allah.” The man began to tremble like a leaf and the sword fell from his hands.
('29', 291, 3, 28, 591188) The Prophet took up the sword and asked him,”Now it is your turn, say who can save you now?” The infidel trembled as he answered,”There

('29', 292, 1, 2, 591497) is no one except you.” The Prophet did not take his life, but generously forgave him.
('29', 292, 1, 3, 591583) The infidel became a Mussalman then and there.

('29', 296, 3, 6, 599563) 260. MY DISSATISFACTION
('29', 296, 4, 7, 599587) I am not in the least happy over what I have written 1 in Young India regarding the”bomb” thrown by H.E. the Viceroy.
('29', 296, 4, 8, 599705) Vehement writing, even if it is charged with truth, is no answer to violent action.
('29', 296, 4, 9, 599789) The Government’s policy in Bengal is violent action.
('29', 296, 4, 10, 599842) It can be answered only with some form of action.
('29', 296, 4, 11, 599892) Just as we put out a raging fire with water, similarly we could overcome this violent action through peaceful deeds alone.
('29', 296, 5, 12, 600015) But how do we cultivate this peaceful attitude?
('29', 296, 5, 13, 600063) Today,”peaceful non co operation” and”civil disobedience” have become mere words.
('29', 296, 5, 14, 600145) If Hindus and Muslims ceased today from fighting between themselves, if hundreds of thousands of men and women in India took to spinning from today, if today the Hindus cleanse themselves of the blot of untouchability—the Viceregal”bomb” would not have exploded at all.
('29', 296, 5, 15, 600415) We have, however, forgotten non violence, and at the slightest opportunity Hindus and Muslims start fighting between themselves.
('29', 296, 5, 16, 600544) There has been little increase in the use of the spinning wheel.
('29', 296, 5, 17, 600609) We are still fond of foreign cloth.
('29', 296, 5, 18, 600645) Only a few Hindus have done atonement for untouchability.
('29', 296, 5, 19, 600703) In these circumstances, the people have no means of replying to the atrocities of the Government.
('29', 296, 5, 20, 600801) The latter has attempted to clip the wings of Deshbandhu Das, while Bengal and the other provinces look on helplessly.
('29', 296, 5, 21, 600920) Basketfuls of articles opposing— or expressing disapproval of—this action have appeared, but beyond that we do not seem to be able to do anything.

('29', 300, 17, 21, 605996) It is a common charge against us as a nation that we have no sense of the time; we are as a rule behind time.

('29', 300, 17, 24, 606243) He has neglected a hundred things to enable him to be four hours before time.
('29', 300, 17, 25, 606321) The villager when he wants to catch a train reaches the station hours before the scheduled time.

('29', 300, 17, 29, 606622) It is a most usual thing not to commence proceedings at the appointed time.

('29', 301, 1, 4, 607125) But it bodes ill for its progress.
('29', 301, 1, 5, 607160) This lack of time sense is now being noticed in connection with the working of the spinning resolution of the A.I.C.C. To read the resolution is simple and innocent enough.
('29', 301, 1, 6, 607333) But it is taxing all the resources of the All India Khadi Board.
('29', 301, 1, 7, 607398) The collection, transmission and classification of yarn requires a large organization and much organizing ability.
('29', 301, 1, 8, 607513) The difficulty is increased tenfold when the workers do not work to time.
('29', 301, 1, 9, 607587) The fifteenth of each month is the last date for the delivery of yarn.
('29', 301, 1, 10, 607658) That date was fixed not to give more time to spinners but to give enough time to the secretaries of different committees.
('29', 301, 1, 11, 607780) Only if spinners deliver or workers collect their yarn on stated dates, the whole work can be efficiently organized.
('29', 301, 1, 12, 607897) Each province may fix its own dates so as to enable it to send packets of yarn in time to the A.I.K.B. ('29', 301, 1, 13, 608270) When thousands of details require attention, time is of the utmost importance.
('29', 301, 1, 14, 608349) Even as the slightest slip in observing times on railways may result in disastrous consequences, so may want of attention to the A.I.K.B. time table result in consequences just as serious to the prospect of universalizing spinning.
('29', 301, 1, 15, 608581) In fact no organization is possible without punctilious regard to the observance of agreed time tables.
('29', 301, 1, 16, 608685) I trust therefore that all the workers connected with the spinning organization will religiously keep to the times agreed to or appointed by them.

('29', 302, 4, 11, 610053) A resident of Kenya writes: 1

('29', 302, 5, 18, 610545) Ending it in India would automatically bring about an end to it elsewhere.
('29', 302, 5, 19, 610620) If Indian leaders do not render greater service to the cause of Indians abroad it is because they are unable to do so, however much they desire to.

('29', 302, 5, 22, 610846) A cripple can do nothing else than curb his desire to run.
('29', 302, 5, 23, 610905) India is crippled in two ways—politically and economically.
('29', 302, 5, 24, 610965) Her sons living abroad cannot certainly say to such a crippled mother:”What sort of justice is this, mother, that you do not help us and yet seek money from us?” The mother would say:”My sons, I know that you suffer; but I am a widow.
('29', 302, 5, 25, 611200) How can I help you?
('29', 302, 5, 26, 611220) Moreover, I am poor; you went abroad with the hope of earning some money; I believe that I can claim a share in your meal.
('29', 302, 5, 27, 611343) Hence I look at you expectantly.” India finds herself in such curious circumstances.
('29', 302, 5, 28, 611428) Having lived abroad for twenty years, I have experienced this.
('29', 302, 5, 29, 611491) We used to send money from South Africa to India even though we could not get any

('29', 303, 1, 10, 612553) A large portion of the funds that came from India was returned to the country.

('29', 303, 1, 13, 612834) Thousands including women courted prison; some were killed; others were banished from the country; many were left destitute; a young girl 1 died of a disease contacted in prison; two youths 2 died—one as a result of the sufferings undergone in prison and the other through hardships resulting from being banished; some had to endure whipping—as a result of all this and after eight years of satyagraha the objective of the struggle was achieved and yet the struggle has to be carried on.
('29', 303, 1, 14, 613322) It is an inevitable law that the weapon which is responsible for victory is the only one which can preserve the fruits of victory and win more.
('29', 303, 1, 15, 613466) Just as the Kshatriya loses the territory he has conquered in case the enemy gains strength or he himself loses it, similarly the satyagrahi too loses what he has gained if he loses strength or the opponent gains it.
('29', 303, 1, 16, 613683) For the hardships suffered by Indians living in South Africa or in other foreign countries, the remedy lies in their own hands.
('29', 303, 1, 17, 613811) They will be able to uphold their self respect to the extent that they are able to increase their capacity to put up with extreme suffering, to become pure and remain so.

('29', 304, 3, 10, 614957) 271. JOINT STATEMENT WITH SWARAJ PARTY LEADERS
('29', 304, 4, 11, 615004) CALCUTTA, November 6, 1924
('29', 304, 5, 12, 615031) The following is the text of the statement issued in Calcutta on the 6th instant over the signatures of Mr. Gandhi, Mr. C. R. Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru: Whereas, although swaraj is the goal of all the parties in India, the country is divided into different groups seemingly working in opposite directions, and whereas such antagonistic activity retards the progress of the nation towards swaraj, and whereas it is desirable to bring, so far as possible, all such parties within the Congress and on a common platform and whereas the Congress itself is divided into two opposing sections, resulting in harm to the country’s cause, and whereas it is desirable to reunite these parties for the purpose of furthering the common cause, and whereas a policy of repression has been commenced in Bengal by the local Government with the sanction of the Governor General, and whereas in the opinion of the undersigned this repression is aimed in reality not at any party of violence but at the Swaraj Party in Bengal and therefore at constitutional and orderly activity, and whereas, therefore, it has become a matter of immediate necessity to invite and secure the co operation of all parties for putting forth the united strength of the nation against the policy of repression, we, the undersigned, strongly recommend the following for adoption by all parties and eventually by the Congress at Belgaum: The Congress should suspend the programme of non co 
('29', 305, 0, 1, 616481) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 305, 1, 2, 616523) operation as the national programme, except in so far as it relates to the refusal to use or wear cloth made out of India.
('29', 305, 1, 3, 616646) The Congress should further resolve that different classes of work of the Congress may be done, as may be found necessary, by the different sections within the Congress and should resolve that the spread of hand spinning, hand weaving and all the antecedent progress and the spread of hand spun and hand woven khaddar, and the promotion of unity between different communities, specially between the Hindus and the Mussalmans, and the removal of untouchability by the Hindus from amongst them should be carried on by all sections within the Congress; and the work in connection with the Central and Provincial Legislatures should be carried on by the Swaraj Party on behalf of the Congress and as an integral part of the Congress organization and for such work the Swaraj Party should make its own rules and raise and administer its own funds.
('29', 305, 1, 4, 617489) Inasmuch as experience has shown that without universal spinning India cannot become self supporting regarding her clothing requirements and inasmuch as hand spinning is the best and the most tangible method of establishing a visible and substantial bond between the masses and Congressmen and women and in order to popularize hand spinning and its products, the Congress should repeal Article VII of the Congress Constitution and should substitute the following therefor: No one shall be a member of any Congress Committee or organization who is not of the age of 18 and who does not wear hand spun and hand woven khaddar at political and Congress functions or while engaged in Congress business, and does not make a contribution of 2,000 yards of evenly spun yarn per month of his or her own spinning or in case of illness, unwillingness or any such cause alike quantity of yarn spun by any other parson.

('29', 306, 1, 2, 618468) 272. SPEECH IN REPLY TO CORPORATION ADDRESS, CALCUTTA 1
('29', 306, 2, 3, 618524) November 6, 1924
('29', 306, 3, 4, 618541) MR. MAYOR, ALDERMEN AND COUNCILLORS OF THE CORPORATION
('29', 306, 4, 5, 618596) OF CALCUTTA AND LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, You will pardon me for not standing while addressing you.
('29', 306, 4, 6, 618692) It is not from want of courtesy but from want of strength to face a big audience like this.
('29', 306, 4, 7, 618784) I tender you my sincere thanks for your address and the very kind and generous sentiments expressed in it.
('29', 306, 4, 8, 618891) I am not unfamiliar with this great city—the city of palaces.
('29', 306, 4, 9, 618953) Nor am I unaware of the importance that is attached for the performance of civic duty.
('29', 306, 4, 10, 619040) And I have often felt that though less ambitious and still less dazzling than the work on the political arena, civic work is not less necessary and not less fruitful.
('29', 306, 4, 11, 619207) Many a time have I rehearsed to myself what I could do if I was a member of a Corporation and when years ago I used to walk through the slums of Calcutta and compare the palaces with their beautiful and sanitary surroundings with the ugliness and insanitation of the slums, I used to say to myself that the worth and work of the Corporation of Calcutta should he measured not by the number or beauty of its palaces but by the conditions of its slums and I felt then that the Corporation had neglected its duties.
('29', 306, 4, 12, 619720) Later on I had the opportunity of visiting some of its dairies and I was horrified not merely with the wretched condition in which they were kept but also at the cruelty to which the cattle were subjected by the gowalas in drawing by unmentionable methods the last drop of milk not unmixed with blood from the poor cattle.
('29', 306, 4, 13, 620043) I commend these stray observations to your notice in the hope that during your term of office a great step will have been taken towards ridding Calcutta of insanitation wherever it exists and by municipalizing the dairies ensuring the supply of cheap and pure milk to its many inhabitants.
('29', 306, 4, 14, 620333) In my humble opinion it is the primary duty of a Corporation to ensure pure air, pure water, cheap and pure milk and fruit and free education for the children of its ratepayers and I wish that this Corporation will take the first step among the cities of India.
('29', 306, 5, 15, 620595) 1 C. R. Das, the Mayor, read out the address of welcome which was presented in the Town Hall before a large gathering.
('29', 307, 0, 1, 620714) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 307, 1, 2, 620756) You have drawn attention to the arrest under Regulation III of 1818 of your Chief Executive Officer.
('29', 307, 1, 3, 620857) I tender you my deep sympathy.
('29', 307, 1, 4, 620888) It is unthinkable that under a Government supposed to be civilized a man of Mr. Subhash Chandra Basu’s 1 position, indeed any man, should be summarily arrested and detained without the prospect of a trial, indeed even the prospect of knowing the reason for which he was so arrested.
('29', 307, 1, 5, 621171) My views about anarchical activities are well known.
('29', 307, 1, 6, 621224) I am opposed to them with my whole soul.
('29', 307, 1, 7, 621265) I believe that they can do no good whatever to India.
('29', 307, 1, 8, 621319) But this is not the occasion to air my views in the matter.
('29', 307, 1, 9, 621379) I may be accused, however, for adding that I detest the extraordinary measures adopted by the Government just as much as I detest the anarchical activities.
('29', 307, 1, 10, 621536) I can only hope that the Government will retrace its steps and abandon the procedure which can only be described as lawless and that Mr. Subhash Chandra Basu will soon be restored to the Corporation and be able to resume the services which, from all accounts I have heard, he was rendering with great ability, efficiency and integrity.

('29', 307, 3, 12, 621904) 273. SPEECH AT SPINNING DEMONSTRATION 2 CALCUTTA
('29', 307, 4, 13, 621953) November 6, 1924
('29', 307, 5, 14, 621970) I am pleased: to see you spinning.
('29', 307, 5, 15, 622005) I hope those of you who are not spinning will begin spinning at once.

('29', 308, 3, 4, 622647) Explaining his own feelings at the outset, Gandhiji said: I myself have no doubts as to the rightness of my action.
('29', 308, 3, 5, 622763) I was caught in a whirlpool of doubt regarding my duty; but now I feel relieved.
('29', 308, 3, 6, 622844) I am certain that I could not have done otherwise than what I have done.
('29', 308, 3, 7, 622917) It is the very dharma of an advocate of non violence that he should renounce till he has nothing farther to renounce.
('29', 308, 3, 8, 623035) Hence I have arrived at the final decision.
('29', 308, 3, 9, 623079) I should practise surrender to such an extent that my opponent would see, it is the limit and would be taken aback by it.

('29', 313, 5, 14, 634748) 276. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA 3
('29', 313, 6, 15, 634794) CALCUTTA, November 7, 1924
('29', 313, 7, 16, 634821) Asked what would be the effect in the country of the agreement between him and the Swaraj Party, Mr. Gandhi said: It is too early yet to say, but I hope that No changers will be able heartily to accept it and that those who felt called upon to retire from the Congress in 1920, will see their way to rejoin the Congress.
('29', 313, 8, 17, 635142) 1 At the Howrah Town Hall 2Vide”Speeeh in Reply to Corporation Address, Calcutta”, 6 11 1924.
('29', 313, 9, 18, 635236) 3 Before leaving Calcutta
('29', 314, 0, 1, 635262) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 315
('29', 314, 1, 2, 635310) Mr. Gandhi also hoped that the new change would help the production of more khaddar.
('29', 314, 2, 3, 635395) Questioned regarding the situation in Bengal and the arrests under Regulation III and the Special Ordinance, he said: Repression should result in uniting the political parties in India, because, after such a careful study as was open to me, I retain the opinion that repression is an attack upon the Swaraj Party, in other words, upon determined and inconvenient opposition to the Government, no matter how constitutional it may be.
('29', 314, 2, 4, 635828) If all parties unite in expressing unequivocal disapproval of its policy, the Government will realize that public opinion is entirely against it.
('29', 314, 2, 5, 635974) Personally, I regret that, at this critical juncture, there is no atmosphere for non co operation or, putting it more accurately, civil disobedience, for I consider that the measures adopted by the Bengal Government are such as to call for the strongest direct action that is open to believers in the uttermost non violence.
('29', 314, 2, 6, 636299) It would be at once an answer to the Government for its arbitrary action and to the revolutionary party to show the futility of its method.
('29', 314, 2, 7, 636439) I regard both repression of the type adopted by the Government and the violent methods of the revolutionary party as anarchy.
('29', 314, 2, 8, 636565) The activity of the Government is possibly more dangerous, because it is more organized and is adopted in the name of law.
('29', 314, 2, 9, 636688) But, I recognize that, whilst we are warring amongst ourselves and whilst the atmosphere is surcharged with violence, though for the moment turned upon ourselves, civil disobedience is an impossibility, but had the Hindus and Mohamme dans not lost their heads and had there been no dissensions within the Congress, I could have shown that civil disobedience was infinitely more effective and expeditious than violent methods.
('29', 314, 2, 10, 637114) That civil disobedience must always be non violent, open and strictly truthful, makes it a weapon capable of being handled by scrupulously honourable men.
('29', 314, 3, 11, 637269) Asked as to what should be the attitude of non official Europeans in India at the present time, Mr. Gandhi said: In my opinion, their way is perfectly clear.
('29', 314, 3, 12, 637427) So far as I am aware, all India will co operate with them in discountenancing and putting down anarchical activities, but they are expected to appreciate the Indian standpoint and Indian aspirations and make common cause with Indians in resisting the arbitrary use of authority and co operate with them in their attempt to vindicate their fight for freedom.

('29', 315, 1, 2, 637848) 277. VALUE OF TIME
('29', 315, 2, 3, 637867) It is said of us that we do not realize the value of time.
('29', 315, 2, 4, 637926) There is much truth in this complaint.
('29', 315, 2, 5, 637965) I know that even our great leaders do not fully realize the value of time.
('29', 315, 2, 6, 638040) Hardly any meeting begins at the appointed hour.
('29', 315, 2, 7, 638089) Thousands of people wait patiently and have their time wasted.
('29', 315, 2, 8, 638152) But the English have a saying, a good one,”time is money”.
('29', 315, 2, 9, 638211) For no task—no work—can be accomplished without time; and without work there can be no wealth.
('29', 315, 2, 10, 638306) Gems which lie buried in mines have no value whatsoever.
('29', 315, 2, 11, 638363) What has value is the time spent in discovering them or the effort made to get them.
('29', 315, 2, 12, 638448) If gold were as easily available as iron, it would not for all its glitter have the same value that it has today.
('29', 315, 2, 13, 638562) The sun’s rays are a million times more beautiful than gold, but in this country we hardly value them, as we can have them to our heart’s content.
('29', 315, 2, 14, 638709) But where there is a dearth of sunshine, people are ready to pay a price for them.
('29', 315, 2, 15, 638792) We do not realize the loss suffered by society and the time wasted as a result of our meetings not starting punctually.
('29', 315, 2, 16, 638912) However, universal voluntary spinning is giving us adequate training.
('29', 315, 2, 17, 638982) So long as every individual spinner or the committee does complete its work in time, the task of collecting and examining the yarn, when there are hundreds and millions of spinners, will become difficult, if not impossible.
('29', 315, 2, 18, 639206) We have no cause for elation because Gujarat stands first.
('29', 315, 2, 19, 639265) Where little is being done, the one who does somewhat more shines out; but so long as the one who so distinguishes himself does not reach the minimum limit, the distinction won by him would be meaningless.
('29', 315, 2, 20, 639471) There are not even two thousand spinners in Gujarat today.
('29', 315, 2, 21, 639530) However, even if the number reaches two thousand, it is hardly worth mentioning!
('29', 315, 2, 22, 639611) Our aim is to make everyone take to khadi, to start sacrificial spinning in every home.
('29', 315, 2, 23, 639699) Having regard to this objective, the figures in Gujarat have little value or significance.
('29', 315, 2, 24, 639790) If we wish to make great strides in this work, we must learn to realize the value of time.
('29', 315, 2, 25, 639881) It is for this very reason that I have suggested that every spinner should spin regularly for half an hour, regarding it as his dharma.
('29', 315, 2, 26, 640017) If he wishes to spin without fail for even half an hour, he should appoint in advance the time to do so.
('29', 316, 0, 1, 640122) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 317
('29', 316, 1, 2, 640170) Thereby he will find that he does not miss even a single day.
('29', 316, 1, 3, 640232) On the appointed day and at the appointed time, he should send his yarn to the prescribed destination.
('29', 316, 1, 4, 640335) This will save everyone’s time.
('29', 316, 1, 5, 640367) The sub committees should collect yarn at the appointed time on the appointed day, so as to enable them to send their lot to the larger committees at the appointed time and the provincial committee should send it to the central committee on the appointed day.
('29', 316, 1, 6, 640627) What a great deal of time is saved and how much more convenient does it become when this is done!
('29', 316, 1, 7, 640725) A fair amount of orderliness has been achieved in Gujarat.
('29', 316, 1, 8, 640784) Yet, much remains to be done.
('29', 316, 1, 9, 640814) This task of spinning is not for a day or for a year.
('29', 316, 1, 10, 640868) It is related to the very existence of India.
('29', 316, 1, 11, 640914) Without it, swaraj can be neither won nor defended.
('29', 316, 1, 12, 640966) Anyone who chooses may consider swaraj in this context as meaning economic independence.
('29', 316, 1, 13, 641055) This restricted meaning is sufficient for our purpose.
('29', 316, 1, 14, 641110) It is my firm conviction that if we gain economic independence, all else will automatically follow.
('29', 316, 1, 15, 641210) Hence, spinning must take firm strides ahead and spread day by day.
('29', 316, 1, 16, 641278) In this programme of spinning lies the test of our readiness for sacrifice, our patriotism, our ability to value time, our capacity to organize, and of our faith and our determination.
('29', 316, 1, 17, 641463) There is not much time left before the Congress session.
('29', 316, 1, 18, 641520) We have no more than two months.
('29', 316, 1, 19, 641553) Let us send all our yarn along with proper accounts to the All India Khadi Association before the 15th of the month.
('29', 316, 1, 20, 641670) I would like to see a marked increase in the number of spinners.
('29', 316, 1, 21, 641735) The key to this lies in our carrying out our tasks within the time appointed.
('29', 316, 2, 22, 641813) [From Gujarati]
('29', 316, 3, 23, 641829) Navajivan, 9 11 1924

('29', 318, 1, 2, 643299) 280. INTERVIEW TO A. P. I. ON CALCUTTA PACT
('29', 318, 2, 3, 643343) DELHI, November 10, 1924
('29', 318, 3, 4, 643368) The following interview on the question of the agreement arrived at between the leaders of the Swaraj Party and Mr. Gandhi at Calcutta which a representative of the Associated Press of India had with Mr. Gandhi on his return to Delhi on the 10th instant is published:
('29', 318, 4, 5, 643636) Asked as to why, if the agreement signed by himself and Messrs Das and Nehru was intended to be an invitation to Liberals and others to rejoin the Congress, they had not conferred with them before issuing the appeal, Mr. Gandhi replied: Such a conference was impossible before the Swarajists and No changers could agree upon a joint course, because any appeal must be a joint appeal by the two wings of the Congress.
('29', 318, 4, 6, 644053) As a matter of fact there has been no conference even with the No changers.
('29', 318, 4, 7, 644129) It is true that I met the No changers of Bengal and discussed the situation with them, as also I met, for instance, Mr. Satyanand Bose and discussed matter with him.
('29', 318, 4, 8, 644295) But I did not even make an endeavour to secure their assent for the simple reason that I had at my disposal no machinery whereby I could ascertain the wishes of the No changers as a body and bind them formally.
('29', 318, 4, 9, 644506) I, therefore, thought it best to give my own individual opinion and place it before the country for what it was worth.
('29', 318, 4, 10, 644625) You will see that the agreement is a recommendation addressed to all parties within and without the Congress.
('29', 318, 4, 11, 644735) The time for a confer ence is now.
('29', 318, 4, 12, 644770) The No changers will express their opinion through the forthcoming All India Congress Committee.
('29', 318, 4, 13, 644867) Maulana Mahomed Ali as President of the Congress has invited to the conference repre sentatives of all parties including the European Association.
('29', 318, 4, 14, 645014) The recommendation made by the Swaraj Party and myself will be submitted at the meeting for their sympathetic consideration.
('29', 318, 4, 15, 645139) There is no finality about the agreement except for the Swaraj Party and for myself personally.
('29', 318, 4, 16, 645235) Everybody is free to appeal to our reason, and I am sure that neither the Swaraj Party nor I will stand in the way of any other settlement that may bring all the parties together on a common platform and facilitate our progress towards the common goal and supply an effective answer to the Bengal Government’s repressive pol icy on the one hand and satisfy the ambition of the misguided anar chists on the other, and thus wean them from their error.
('29', 318, 4, 17, 645685) I appeal to
('29', 319, 0, 1, 645697) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 319, 1, 2, 645739) all the leaders to accept Maulana Mahomed Ali’s invitation and assist and guide the deliberations of the forthcoming conference at Bombay.
('29', 319, 2, 3, 645878) Young India, 13 11 1924
('29', 319, 3, 4, 645902) 281. LETTER TO MAHOMED ALI
('29', 319, 4, 5, 645929) November 11, 1924
('29', 319, 5, 6, 645947) MY DEAR BROTHER, Mahadev would not give me Navajivan Manager’s letter but I insisted.
('29', 319, 5, 7, 646033) I have read it.
('29', 319, 5, 8, 646049) I feel deeply hurt and humiliated.
('29', 319, 5, 9, 646084) I was not prepared for such a letter to you from the Navajivan.
('29', 319, 5, 10, 646148) I dare not divest myself of responsibility for that letter.
('29', 319, 5, 11, 646208) But I see that my life must close in that imperfect fashion.
('29', 319, 5, 12, 646269) An imperfect man is gambling with life and burning his fingers continuously.
('29', 319, 5, 13, 646346) That is the reason why some of the best men of the world have ever chosen to live alone in the company of their Maker.
('29', 319, 5, 14, 646465) I have neither the heart nor the courage to part company with Swami.
('29', 319, 5, 15, 646534) He is a good man.
('29', 319, 5, 16, 646552) He is brave; he is honest.
('29', 319, 5, 17, 646579) He has no prejudices of race or religion.
('29', 319, 5, 18, 646621) But he has something in him which makes him act offensively at times.
('29', 319, 5, 19, 646691) I must ask you to forgive him for my sake.
('29', 319, 5, 20, 646734) And if you will forgive him then you must tell me all you think Navajivan owes you.
('29', 319, 5, 21, 646818) This will save me much worry.
('29', 319, 5, 22, 646848) I write this because when we meet we are full of politics and philosophy.
('29', 319, 5, 23, 646922) Domestic matters are trifles for us.
('29', 319, 5, 24, 646959) But they occupy the principal part of my life.
('29', 319, 5, 25, 647006) They teach me to know my limitations.
('29', 319, 7, 26, 647044) M. K. GANDHI
('29', 319, 8, 27, 647057) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('29', 321, 9, 10, 649132) 285. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI 4
('29', 321, 10, 11, 649172) DARYAGANJ, DELHI, November 12, 1924
('29', 321, 11, 12, 649208) DEAR FRIEND, You must have read 5 Maulana Mahomed Ali’s invitation to the forthcoming conference between the All India Congress Committee and the representatives of other public associations.
('29', 321, 11, 13, 649400) I hope that you will be able to attend the conference.
('29', 321, 11, 14, 649455) The idea is to focus, if it is at all possible, every variety of opinion on the Bengal repression, which so far as I can judge, is directed against constitutional agitation when it becomes inconvenient to the Government, rather than anarchical activity.
('29', 321, 11, 15, 649709) The idea further is to find out whether it is possible to bring together on the Congress platform all parties for joint work on a common constructive programme conducive to national growth, each party otherwise retaining its own individuality.
('29', 321, 11, 16, 649953) I am sure that if you can attend, your co operation and advice will be valuable to the conference in coming to a conclusion satisfactory to all parties.
('29', 321, 12, 17, 650106) Yours sincerely,
('29', 321, 13, 18, 650123) M. K. GANDHI

('29', 322, 1, 2, 650528) 286. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('29', 322, 2, 3, 650560) DELHI, November 12, 1924
('29', 322, 3, 4, 650585) MY DEAR JAWAHARLAL,
('29', 322, 4, 5, 650605) It does appear to me to be necessary to have a flying column of workers, Hindu and Mohammedan, who would on a moment’s notice be ready to go to afflicted parts for investigation.
('29', 322, 4, 6, 650784) We may not wait always for distinguished men to go.
('29', 322, 4, 7, 650836) Take for instance the case sent to you yesterday.
('29', 322, 4, 8, 650886) If the statements made are true, the culprits should be exposed.
('29', 322, 4, 9, 650951) If they are false, newspaper reporters should be brought to book.
('29', 322, 4, 10, 651017) The investigation should be prompt and thorough.
('29', 322, 4, 11, 651066) I am preparing Mahadev for the work and am trying to induce Pyarelal.
('29', 322, 4, 12, 651136) The latter is unnecessarily diffident.
('29', 322, 4, 13, 651175) Will Manzar Ali do the work?
('29', 322, 4, 14, 651204) He may be paid for it?
('29', 322, 4, 15, 651227) He should have no objection to accepting remuneration.
('29', 322, 4, 16, 651282) His spinning work need not be disturbed.
('29', 322, 4, 17, 651323) His activity may be confined to U.P. only, though I would prefer not to have any restrictions unless we get an army of workers in the field.
('29', 322, 4, 18, 651464) For the case sent to you yesterday, I hope you will send some one at once.
('29', 322, 4, 19, 651539) What about the case that was sent to you some weeks ago?
('29', 322, 5, 20, 651596) Yours sincerely,
('29', 322, 6, 21, 651613) M. K. GANDHI [PS.] I take it you will be in Bombay with Father on Thursday morning if not earlier.
('29', 322, 6, 22, 651712) I reach there that morning.
('29', 322, 6, 23, 651740) Mrs. Naidu is leaving here tomorrow morning.
('29', 322, 7, 24, 651785) M. K. G.

('29', 322, 9, 27, 651864) 287. LETTER TO SHWAIB QURESHI
('29', 322, 10, 28, 651894) November 12, 1924
('29', 322, 11, 29, 651912) MY DEAR SHWAIB, Mrs. Naidu tells me you are in a most dejected mood and have almost become a misanthrope having lost faith in men and things.
('29', 322, 11, 30, 652054) If it is so, it is unworthy of you whom I have always known and heard of
('29', 323, 0, 1, 652127) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 323, 1, 2, 652169) as a man of God.
('29', 323, 1, 3, 652186) That you are oversensitive I have discovered for myself.
('29', 323, 1, 4, 652243) But that sensitiveness can be got rid of without much difficulty.
('29', 323, 1, 5, 652309) Dejection is not so easy.
('29', 323, 1, 6, 652335) Why have you become so?
('29', 323, 1, 7, 652359) We have a long and weary battle to fight.
('29', 323, 1, 8, 652401) It may become short if God so wills.
('29', 323, 1, 9, 652438) But may a soldier grumble if the battle is found to be long and weary?
('29', 323, 1, 10, 652509) Not surely for him to grumble.
('29', 323, 1, 11, 652540) If others falter he who has faith becomes correspondingly stronger.
('29', 323, 1, 12, 652608) I would like you to be stronger and more determined for all the weakness and confusion around us.
('29', 323, 1, 13, 652706) So please cheer up.
('29', 323, 1, 14, 652726) Open out your heart.
('29', 323, 1, 15, 652747) Kristodas was telling me you had not yet returned the Gulburga report duly completed.
('29', 323, 1, 16, 652833) Do please send it or keep it ready when I come there on 20th.
('29', 323, 1, 17, 652895) I hope to leave by the Express on the 18th.
('29', 323, 1, 18, 652939) Probably Hakim Sahib and Dr. Ansari will be with me.
('29', 323, 1, 19, 652992) Kristodas stayed behind for a week.
('29', 323, 1, 20, 653028) His people wanted to meet him badly.
('29', 323, 1, 21, 653065) He therefore went to Chandpur.
('29', 323, 1, 22, 653096) He returns on or before 18th.
('29', 323, 1, 23, 653126) Mrs. Naidu leaves tomorrow to prepare for the Conference.
('29', 323, 1, 24, 653184) You may not know that I am now housed at Dr. Ansari’s.
('29', 323, 1, 25, 653239) With love,
('29', 323, 2, 26, 653250) Yours sincerely,
('29', 323, 3, 27, 653267) M. K. GANDHI

('29', 326, 11, 15, 658254) From a photostat: S.N. 11718
('29', 326, 12, 16, 658283) 292. THE AGREEMENT
('29', 326, 13, 17, 658302) I thank God that He gave me strength to surrender to the Swarajists all that it was possible for me to surrender—much more than I or many friends had expected.
('29', 326, 13, 18, 658462) I must acknowledge my indebtedness to the Swarajists for their accommodation.
('29', 326, 13, 19, 658540) I know that many do not put the same emphasis that I do on the constructive part of the programme.
('29', 326, 13, 20, 658639) With many the stiffening of the franchise was the bitterest pill and yet for the sake of unity and for the sake of the country they have yielded.
('29', 326, 13, 21, 658785) All honour to them for so doing.
('29', 326, 13, 22, 658818) The agreement puts Swarajists on a par with the No changers.
('29', 326, 13, 23, 658879) It was inevitable if voting and all it means was to be avoided.
