('29', 428, 2, 3, 890211) December 7, 1924
('29', 428, 3, 4, 890228) In explaining how he came to accept the presidentship, he read Pandit Motilalji’s letter to Lalaji, wherein the former had explained how his pre occupations prevented him from going to Lahore to preside.
('29', 428, 3, 5, 890432) Panditji also had said that he was fed up with conferences and that he feared that they were nothing but empty shows.
('29', 428, 3, 6, 890550) Mahatmaji fully agreed with Panditji and said Hakimji and he had come not to attend the Conference but to find a solution of the burning problem.
('29', 428, 3, 7, 890696) He was told that the Tanzeem had said that the Conference was a purely Hindu show and that Mussalmans
('29', 428, 4, 8, 890798) should stand aloof.
('29', 428, 4, 9, 890818) He had not seen the particular paragraph, but he wanted to tell them that Dr. Kitchlew and the President of the Khilafat Conference as also Dr. Ansari and Hakimji and Maulanas Mahomed Ali and Shaukat Ali had left the Khilafat Conference to come down to Lahore to attend the Leaders, Conference.
('29', 428, 5, 10, 891113) In coming to the question of Hindu Muslim tension, Mahatmaji said that the root cause of the tension lay in the Punjab, that all the disturbances in other parts of the country could be traced to the root cause in the Punjab, and that, therefore, the moment the Hindus and Mussalmans in the Punjab were united, there would be Hindu Muslim unity all over India.
('29', 428, 5, 11, 891473) Non co operation had not failed—there was no failure in non co operation—the Hindu Muslim disturbances had failed them.
('29', 428, 5, 12, 891593) He even felt that the question of Council entry would not have arisen but for differences.
('29', 428, 5, 13, 891684) In 1921, they felt that they were united, but it was not true unity, it was the momentary result of excitement, and it was best that they were face to face with realities today.
('29', 428, 6, 14, 891862) Hakimji and Dr. Ansari and the Ali Brothers had come not to attend the Khilafat Conference, not to attend the Provincial Conference, but to help to find out a solution of the Hindu Muslim problem.
('29', 428, 6, 15, 892059) Mahatmaji said, he had no other solution to offer than that of surrender on the part of one of the communities to all the political demands of the others.
('29', 428, 6, 16, 892214) How, it would be asked, could a minor community, like the Sikhs, surrender all its political rights to Hindus and Mussalmans?
('29', 428, 6, 17, 892340) He had not the slightest doubt that a community that had given to the world a unique lesson in non violence, that had given evidence of matchless sacrifice, would not find it difficult to make what really was a trifling sacrifice.
('29', 428, 7, 18, 892571) But with what face could he offer that solution to the Sikhs and the Mussalmans, when he had not been able to get it accepted by the Hindus?

('29', 433, 4, 7, 903644) 372. MY PUNJAB DIARY
('29', 433, 5, 8, 903665) NOT BY CHOICE
('29', 433, 6, 9, 903679) It was not by choice but by necessity that I undertook to preside at the Punjab Provincial Conference.
('29', 433, 6, 10, 903782) 1 The Punjabis wanted an outsider to preside and if at all possible Maulana Abul Kalam Azad.
('29', 433, 6, 11, 903875) The Maulana Sahib however was unwilling.

('29', 433, 6, 13, 904005) The Maulana’s position was appreciated.
('29', 433, 6, 14, 904045) Pandit Motilalji was then approached.
('29', 433, 6, 15, 904083) He was good enough to say he would preside, if he was not prevented by any untoward event, and if Pandit Motilalji was prevented from presiding, I was to fill in his place.
('29', 433, 6, 16, 904256) Unfortunately the unexpected happened and Pandit Motilalji could not come.
('29', 433, 6, 17, 904331) As the reasons given by him are of public importance, I set them forth in his own language.
('29', 433, 7, 18, 904423) “FED UP”
('29', 433, 8, 19, 904432) In his letter to Lalaji he says:

('29', 435, 4, 12, 909220) THE RESULT
('29', 435, 5, 13, 909231) It is hardly necessary for me to inform the reader that the meeting was arranged for the sole purpose of considering the ways and means of easing the tension between Hindus and Mussalmans and of establishing real peace between the two communities.
('29', 435, 5, 14, 909479) Among Mussalman outsiders, Hakim Sahib Ajmal Khan, the Ali Brothers and Dr. Ansari were present, and among Hindu outsiders Panditji Madan Mohan Malaviya was present.
('29', 435, 5, 15, 909645) The discussion centred on the political causes of the tension.
('29', 435, 5, 16, 909708) For they seemed to be the predominant if not the only causes of tension between the educated classes in the Punjab.
('29', 435, 5, 17, 909824) Lalaji told me with great sorrow that whereas formerly there were cordial social relations between educated Mussalmans and educated Hindus, now there was growing estrangement.
('29', 435, 5, 18, 910000) The meeting therefore discussed the advisability of revising the Lucknow Pact.
('29', 435, 5, 19, 910079) The Punjab Mussalmans hold that we have outgrown the Lucknow Pact, if it was not a blunder in the very inception.
('29', 435, 5, 20, 910193) They claim that whilst the communal feelings run high and mutual distrust exists: 1. There should be communal representation on a population basis at least under a common electorate or separate, if necessary.
('29', 435, 5, 21, 910402) There seemed to me to be general agreement among them that
('29', 436, 0, 1, 910461) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 437
('29', 436, 1, 2, 910509) separate electorate should be resorted to only at the instance of minorities.
('29', 436, 2, 3, 910587) 2. There should be no favoured treatment to any sect, i.e., no sect should be represented above its numerical proportion.
('29', 436, 3, 4, 910709) 3. The same formula should be applied to local bodies as to the legislative.
('29', 436, 4, 5, 910786) 4. On all public services the different communities should be proportionately represented with due regard to efficiency.
('29', 436, 4, 6, 910907) Wherever therefore any community is unrepresented, all future appointments, whether new or to fill up vacancies, should be so made as to regularize the proportionate representation.
('29', 436, 4, 7, 911089) In other words there should be no class favouritism or class preference.
('29', 436, 5, 8, 911162) The Mussalman friends present made it clear that they merely gave their individual opinions.
('29', 436, 5, 9, 911255) They did not bind anybody but themselves and their opinion was subject to revision if any other community claimed special or favoured treatment.
('29', 436, 6, 10, 911400) 5. Any solution must be an all India solution and must be by the consent of all India.
('29', 436, 7, 11, 911487) The Sikh friends contended that their special position and importance in the Punjab required special treatment, i.e., excessive representation if there was any communal representation at all in the Punjab.
('29', 436, 7, 12, 911693) They said that they would be quite satisfied if communal representation was entirely given up and even if not one Sikh found place in the Legislature or elsewhere.
('29', 436, 7, 13, 911857) The Hindu position seemed to be that there should be no communal representation at all, but that if there was to be any, it should be under a joint electorate.
('29', 436, 7, 14, 912017) The Hindu position was not crystallized.
('29', 436, 7, 15, 912058) The Punjabi Hindus seemed to dread, at the back of the Mussalman demand, a sinister design on the part of the Mussalmans.
('29', 436, 7, 16, 912180) In fact there is a vague fear in their minds that if the Mussalmans gain a decisive majority in the administration of the Punjab, the proximity of the warlike Mussalman tribes would constitute a most formidable menace to the Punjab in particular and to India in general.
('29', 436, 7, 17, 912451) Such is, as briefly and as accurately as is possible for me to put, the real position of the respective communities.
('29', 436, 7, 18, 912568) In these circums tances, it was not possible to press the advance to an immediate solution.

('29', 437, 0, 1, 912789) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 437, 1, 2, 912831) an acceptable and national solution of the thorny problem.
('29', 437, 2, 3, 912890) THE CONFERENCE
('29', 437, 3, 4, 912905) There was nothing notable about the Conference save the fact that the delegates both at the Subjects Committee and at the Conference gave me the utmost assistance.
('29', 437, 3, 5, 913069) Even those who disagreed with me extended the greatest for bearance.
('29', 437, 3, 6, 913138) I single out this fact because obedience to the authority of the chair is such an essential factor in the growth of a healthy public life.
('29', 437, 3, 7, 913277) The greatest caution should no doubt be exercised in the choice of a chairman, but when one has been selected he must command implicit courtesy and obedience.
('29', 437, 3, 8, 913436) The only way to deal with a refractory, vascillating or partial chairman is to move, with becoming respect, a vote of no confidence and remove him from the chair.
('29', 437, 3, 9, 913599) In well ordered society the honour is not to the person but to the position.
('29', 437, 3, 10, 913676) The fundamental distinction between personal rule and organized State is that in the latter the honour is rendered to the position which is a creation of the State, i.e., the people; and thus the State goes on, no matter who is called to rule or preside.
('29', 437, 3, 11, 913931) To put it in other words, every person in a well ordered State is fully conscious of both his responsibility and of his rights.
('29', 437, 3, 12, 914059) The stability of a State depends upon the readiness of every citizen to subordinate his rights to those of the rest.
('29', 437, 3, 13, 914176) He knows that the rights follow, as a matter of course, the performance of duty.
('29', 437, 3, 14, 914257) The State is the sum total of the sacrifice on its behalf of its members.
('29', 437, 3, 15, 914331) But whilst I place on record my gratitude to the delegates for their courtesy and attention, I would like to mention that there is still at our meetings an unconscious lack of self restraint.
('29', 437, 3, 16, 914523) It is indispensable for meetings, public or private, that those who attend them do not all talk at once nor whisper to one another, but that they listen to what is being said.
('29', 437, 3, 17, 914699) The whole value of meetings is lost if people are not attentive.
('29', 437, 3, 18, 914764) The reader will recognize the reasonableness as well as the selfishness of these remarks.
('29', 437, 3, 19, 914854) I want to prepare the ground for Belgaum.
('29', 437, 3, 20, 914896) All those who attend the Congress and conferences at Belgaum, please note.
('29', 437, 3, 21, 914971) The conference went through its work in seven hours on Sunday the 7th instant, 8 to II in the morning, and 4 to 8 in the evening.

('29', 437, 3, 24, 915219) The proceedings were started punctually at the appointed times so far as the Conference was concerned.

('29', 442, 3, 9, 925742) LAHORE, December 11, 1924
('29', 442, 4, 10, 925768) Mr. Gandhi, who left Rawalpindi this morning, passed through Lahore this evening by the Bombay Mail for Sabarmati.
('29', 442, 4, 11, 925883) Interviewed by a special representative of The Tribune at the Lahore Railway Station on the Government of India Resolution
('29', 442, 5, 12, 926006) on Kohat affairs, Mr. Gandhi said: In company of Maulanas Shaukat Ali, Zafar Ali and Dr. Kitchlew, I saw almost every one of the refugees in Rawalpindi; I have also seen Rai Bahadur Sardar Makhan Singh.
('29', 442, 5, 13, 926209) I have read the resolution of the Government of India and I have not a shadow of doubt that the resolution is a challenge.
('29', 442, 5, 14, 926332) I have strongly advised them not to accept any terms of settlement without reference to Hindu and Muslim leaders.
('29', 442, 5, 15, 926446) At this stage, I wish to give no opinion as to the truth or otherwise of the several statements made in the resolution.
('29', 442, 5, 16, 926566) Unfortunately, the Mohammedans of Kohat were not represented by any responsible person in Rawalpindi, but it is perfectly clear to me that the Government of India have arrived at conclusions upon a departmental enquiry as to the formation of which these refugees or Mussalmans had no say, nor had the refugees any opportunity given to them of establishing their case.
('29', 442, 5, 17, 926934) From experience one knows how often such enquiries had been misleading and resulted in giving only a one sided version.
('29', 442, 5, 18, 927054) The refugees are deeply grieved over the resolution.
('29', 442, 5, 19, 927107) They had expected that there would be a full, open and independent enquiry at
('29', 443, 0, 1, 927185) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 443, 1, 2, 927227) which both Hindus and Muslims would be able to have their full say.
('29', 443, 1, 3, 927295) That, however, has not happened and from the Viceroy’s reply to Pandit Malaviyaji it would appear that this resolution is the Government of India’s final say and finding in the matter.
('29', 443, 1, 4, 927480) In the circumstances, the refugees, if they are to consult their self respect, could never go to Kohat until there is a real and lasting settlement between themselves and the Mussalmans of Kohat.
('29', 443, 1, 5, 927676) Such a settlement can never be superimposed from outside, and whatever terms either the Hindus or the Mussalmans concerned may be represented as having accepted, I can only regard as having been accepted under direct or indirect coercion.
('29', 443, 1, 6, 927915) I am hoping that the Mussalmans of Kohat will see their way to meet the refugees and invite them to return to Kohat under a promise of friendship and full security.
('29', 443, 1, 7, 928080) I do not wish to pre judge the case.
('29', 443, 1, 8, 928117) I am hoping, and in this I voice the sentiment of my Mussalman colleagues, that the Mussalmans of Kohat will give us an opportunity of coming at a correct decision upon the unfortunate happenings in Kohat; but this much is absolutely clear that the Hindus are today refugees at Rawalpindi and are in fear of their very existence in Kohat, should they return without a full guarantee from the Mussalman residents.
('29', 443, 1, 9, 928530) I count no assurance that might be given by the Government as of consequence, if the Mussalmans are unwilling to receive the Hindus as their friends.
('29', 443, 1, 10, 928680) They are in an overwhelming majority, with Mussalman tribes within a stone’s throw of them, and every Indian, be he Hindu or Mussalman, expects the Mussalmans of Khoat, if they are anxious to have Hindu Muslim unity, to give full assurance to the refugees and take them back to Kohat.
('29', 443, 1, 11, 928965) I would repeat here what I have said to the refugees.
('29', 443, 1, 12, 929019) 1 On their correct conduct depend the future relations between the Hindus and the Mussalmans in the Frontier Province.
('29', 443, 1, 13, 929138) If they refuse to return until the Kohat Muslims have cordially invited them and assured them of full protection, it will be [well] with them.
('29', 443, 1, 14, 929281) I have no doubt that all India will stand by them.
('29', 443, 1, 15, 929332) I have told them also that there should not be the slightest difficulty in their finding suitable occupation in India, should it be impossible for them to return with self respect.
('29', 443, 1, 16, 929513) I have told them, too, as soon as my present engagements are finished, which would be about the 23rd of January, I would be glad to go back to Rawalpindi and remain with them as long as it is necessary, but I have every hope
('29', 443, 2, 17, 929738) 1 Vide” Speech at Rawalpindi”, 9 12 1924.
('29', 444, 0, 1, 929780) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 445
('29', 444, 1, 2, 929828) that long before that time the Mussalmans of Kohat will recognize their obligation towards the refugees and take them back to Kohat.
('29', 444, 1, 3, 929961) Maulana Shaukat Ali is already moving in the matter and is placing himself in touch with the Frontier Mussalmans.
('29', 444, 2, 4, 930075) Asked by the interviewer to state his views about the Hindu Muslim differences in the Punjab or to suggest any remedy for the present strained feelings, Mr. Gandhi said: I think the above statement on the Kohat affair is quite enough.
('29', 444, 2, 5, 930310) There is nothing just now which strikes me [as] of paramount importance.
('29', 444, 2, 6, 930383) I have fully dwelt on this question in my articles in the current issue of Young India 1 and I do not want to add anything more to what I have already written.
('29', 444, 3, 7, 930543) Further questioned as to the meaning and the significance of his announcement at the recent Punjab Provincial Political Conference about his new plan of attaining swaraj, Mr. Gandhi replied: I have not seen the report of my concluding speech at the conference, but I did say that I was doing a great deal of hard thinking and trying to find out whether at least for some of us it was not possible to end this agony.
('29', 444, 3, 8, 930959) What that can be, I am unable to say at the present moment, and everything depends upon how the Congress receives any proposal that I might have to make.
('29', 444, 3, 9, 931113) I am still in a fog and I have grave doubts as to my ability to carry the nation with me.
('29', 444, 3, 10, 931203) Beyond this, I am unable to go at the present moment, but there is no doubt in my mind that anything that I may conceive now, will have so far I am concerned a finality about it.
('29', 444, 4, 11, 931382) Asked about his immediate future programme, Mr. Gandhi said: I reach Sabarmati on Saturday morning.
('29', 444, 4, 12, 931482) I leave Sabarmati on the 18th and reach Belgaum on the 20th and hope to meet all the No changers who come there and all the Pro changers who would come on the 21st.
('29', 444, 4, 13, 931647) I am most anxious to have a full, free and informal discussion with all the leaders as well as the rank and file.
('29', 444, 4, 14, 931761) I am most anxious that anything that is done at the Congress is not accepted mechanically, but that every delegate who assents to the resolutions that will be submitted to the Congress does so with a full conviction and under a full sense of his or her responsibility.
('29', 444, 4, 15, 932030) The success of any programme will depend upon everyone working at it heart and soul.
('29', 444, 4, 16, 932115) The Tribune, 13 12 1924

('29', 445, 1, 2, 932200) 377. FOREWORD TO” LIFE OF SRI RAMAKRISHNA”
('29', 445, 2, 3, 932243) SABARMATI.
('29', 445, 3, 4, 932254) Margsheersh Krishna 1, 1981 [December 2 12, 1924]
('29', 445, 4, 5, 932304) The story of Ramakrishna Paramahansa’s life is a story of religion in practice.
('29', 445, 4, 6, 932384) His life enables us to see God face to face.
('29', 445, 4, 7, 932429) No one can read the story of his life without being convinced that God alone is real and that all else is an illusion.
('29', 445, 4, 8, 932548) Ramakrishna was a living embodiment of godliness.
('29', 445, 4, 9, 932598) His sayings are not those of a mere learned man but they are pages from the Book of Life.
('29', 445, 4, 10, 932688) They are revelations of his own experiences.
('29', 445, 4, 11, 932733) They, therefore, leave on the reader an impression which he cannot resist.
('29', 445, 4, 12, 932808) In this age of scepticism Ramakrishna presents an example of a bright and living faith which gives solace to thousands of men and women who would otherwise have remained without spiritual light.
('29', 445, 4, 13, 933003) Ramakrishna’s life was an object lesson in ahimsa.
('29', 445, 4, 14, 933054) His love knew no limits, geographical or otherwise.
('29', 445, 4, 15, 933106) May his divine love be as inspiration to all who read the following pages.
('29', 445, 5, 16, 933181) M. K. GANDHI
('29', 445, 6, 17, 933194) Life of Sri Ramakrishna
('29', 445, 7, 18, 933218) 378” PATIDARS” AND UNTOUCHABLES
('29', 445, 8, 19, 933250) I still receive complaints from our untouchable brothers against Patidars.
('29', 445, 8, 20, 933325) A brother has sent me cuttings wherein the facts are supported by names and addresses.
('29', 445, 8, 21, 933412) It is alleged that those untouch ables who had given up the job of removing carcasses were beaten up and made to do this work.
('29', 445, 8, 22, 933539) If this is a fact, it would amount to swadeshi Dyerism, and in some respects, even worse than the foreign variety.
('29', 445, 8, 23, 933654) The action of the foreigner had at least a slight excuse in the conduct of the people.
('29', 445, 8, 24, 933741) There is no such excuse here.
('29', 445, 8, 25, 933771) The foreigners are few in number and hence, ordinarily, they have cause for fear.
('29', 445, 8, 26, 933853) In this swadeshi Dyerism, however, the Patidars are greater in number, while the untouchables
('29', 445, 9, 27, 933947) 1 As given in the source; however, Gandhiji reached Sabarmati on December 13; vide” Letter to Mathuradas Trikumji”, 14 12 1924.
('29', 445, 10, 28, 934075) 2 The source, however, mentions” November 12, 1924”.
('29', 446, 0, 1, 934128) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 447
('29', 446, 1, 2, 934176) are fewer and inferior in strength as well as intelligence.
('29', 446, 1, 3, 934236) To use force against them is like bringing out an army against ants.
('29', 446, 1, 4, 934305) Patidars and the other so called upper castes should reflect on their duty.
('29', 446, 1, 5, 934381) No one’s Dyerism will be tolerated for much longer now.
('29', 446, 1, 6, 934437) Truth, justice and non violence alone will prevail.
('29', 446, 1, 7, 934489) Untruth, injustice and violence, even if they are swadeshi, will never prevail.
('29', 446, 1, 8, 934569) Today, we want justice, we wish to rid ourselves of slavery.
('29', 446, 1, 9, 934630) Shall we be blind to our own faults and not get rid of them?
('29', 446, 1, 10, 934691) Reasonable Patidars should stop those who have heaped injustice on untouchables.
('29', 446, 1, 11, 934772) People should realize that we have our obligations towards the untouchable brothers.
('29', 446, 1, 12, 934857) Just as other castes have given up their occupations, just as Brahmins have forsaken teaching and taken up jobs, etc., just as Kshatriyas have willingly accepted slavery, just as tailors have given up their trade and entered other fields, similarly, untouchables too have a right to give up their old occupations.
('29', 446, 1, 13, 935171) Today, the chamar’s vocation has been taken up by others also.
('29', 446, 1, 14, 935234) I see no impurity in carrying carcasses to where they belong.
('29', 446, 1, 15, 935296) However, how could I force others to do that or any other work?
('29', 446, 1, 16, 935360) We cannot obstinately insist that certain communities or persons must do certain tasks.
('29', 446, 1, 17, 935448) As a direct result of this, we should not be ashamed of doing any essential service.
('29', 446, 1, 18, 935533) Moreover, if no one else is obliged to do it, what sin have the poor untouchables committed [to be forced to do it]?
('29', 446, 1, 19, 935650) I remember that the Bhangis in the South were displeased once.
('29', 446, 1, 20, 935713) They stopped doing their work.
('29', 446, 1, 21, 935744) The Brahmins started cleaning their own lavatories, and the Bhangis were discomfited.
('29', 446, 1, 22, 935830) That is the best way of vanquishing others.
('29', 446, 1, 23, 935874) We should silently suffer inconvenience and remove it through self reliance, through forbearance.
('29', 446, 1, 24, 935972) This way lies progress for both classes.
('29', 446, 1, 25, 936013) The other course would definitely lead to the degradation of one and possibly of both.
('29', 446, 1, 26, 936100) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 14 12 1924

('29', 448, 4, 15, 938221) 382. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS ON PUNJAB SPEECHES
('29', 448, 5, 16, 938268) AHMEDABAD December 14, 1924 I have seen a report of one of my speeches in the Punjab, and I have heard more about the reports of my speeches.
('29', 448, 5, 17, 938410) I warned the reporters against reporting me without first showing their reports to me.
('29', 448, 5, 18, 938497) I made what were to me important statements.
('29', 448, 5, 19, 938542) The editors of The Tribune and the Zamindar did me the courtesy of letting me or my secretary revise their reports, but others evidently did not consider it necessary to respond to my request.
('29', 448, 5, 20, 938735) The result is a travesty of what I did say.
('29', 448, 5, 21, 938779) All I can therefore say to the public is:” Don’t you believe a word of what may be reported of me unless the report is authenticated by me.
('29', 448, 5, 22, 938919) For the rest, let the public await my address at Belgaum, which will summarize all I have said in the Punjab and elsewhere.
('29', 448, 5, 23, 939043) I warn them against expecting anything sensational or exciting.
('29', 448, 5, 24, 939107) What I desire above all else is unity and quiet constructive work for one year.
('29', 448, 5, 25, 939187) Then, but not till then, I should promise much excitement for the most ardent spirits, but let me not anticipate.
('29', 448, 5, 26, 939301) New India, 15 12 1924

('29', 452, 12, 19, 944909) 390. NOTES
('29', 452, 13, 20, 944920) IS LALAJI A COWARD?
('29', 452, 14, 21, 944940) I suppose I share the misfortune of many a public speaker in being often mis reported without the reporters ever meaning to mis report me.
('29', 452, 14, 22, 945079) I remember the late Sir Pherozeshah Mehta 3, in 1896, telling me on the occasion of my very first public appearance on an Indian platform, that if I wished to be heard and if I wanted to be
('29', 452, 15, 23, 945269) 1 From the postmark 2 As given in the source 3 1845 1915; prominent Indian Congress leader
('29', 453, 0, 1, 945360) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 453, 1, 2, 945402) correctly reported, I should write out my speech.
('29', 453, 1, 3, 945452) I always thanked him for this wise advice.
('29', 453, 1, 4, 945495) I know that, if I had not followed his instructions for that particular meeting, it would have proved a fiasco.
('29', 453, 1, 5, 945607) But I have had cause to recall the advice of the uncrowned king of the Presidency whenever I have been mis reported.
('29', 453, 1, 6, 945724) Somebody is said to have reported me as having described, at the Khilafat Conference at Amritsar, Lala Lajpat Rai as a coward.
('29', 453, 1, 7, 945851) Whatever Lalaji may be, he is no coward.
('29', 453, 1, 8, 945892) The context of my speech would have showed that I was defending Lalaji against the charge of being inimical to the Mussalmans.
('29', 453, 1, 9, 946019) What I did say at the time was that Lalaji was timid and suspected the motives of Mussalmans but that he was sincerely desirous of Mussalman friendship.

('29', 465, 1, 2, 974418) 397. SPEECH TO NO CHANGERS, BELGAUM
('29', 465, 2, 3, 974454) December 21, 1924
('29', 465, 3, 4, 974472) On Sunday again, there was a conference at which further discussions took place between Gandhiji and the No changers.
('29', 465, 3, 5, 974590) His speech was a very touching and feeling one, and he seemed to have put his whole soul into it.
('29', 465, 3, 6, 974688) He said, he continued to be as firm a No changer now as he ever was and that the Councils were not for him.
('29', 465, 3, 7, 974796) As an alternative to the Councils, he could not think of a more potent programme than that of charkha, Hindu Muslim unity and removal of untouchability being added to it.
('29', 465, 3, 8, 974967) He could imagine a number of things which would be very useful to the country, but they were not indispensable for obtaining swaraj and he, therefore, stated that the charkha propaganda was the one thing that every man, high or low, in the city or village, could carry on singly or with others.
('29', 465, 3, 9, 975262) It, therefore, formed the coping stone of his programme for the year.
('29', 465, 3, 10, 975332) He added that vast amount of charkha work was necessary to effect a complete boycott of foreign cloth within the year and it was absolutely necessary for Congress to adopt the spinning franchise.
('29', 465, 3, 11, 975528) It was also necessary, he said, that all those who accepted the spinning franchise should work out the programme throughout the year in dead earnest and it would break his heart if those who accepted the franchise and voted for it would not carry it throughout the year.
('29', 465, 3, 12, 975799) He concluded by expressing his hope and confidence that if those who voted for the franchise played their part in a full measure, this nation would not be long in responding to it.
('29', 465, 4, 13, 975980) Mahatmaji casually referred to the new plan of giving battle to Government that he had previously referred to in a speech in Punjab.
('29', 465, 4, 14, 976113) He said it is stated that a complete or substantial boycott of foreign cloth was a condition precedent to the precise formulation of that method or plan.
('29', 465, 4, 15, 976267) He exhorted the No changers to concentrate all their energies during the following year on the charkha.
('29', 465, 4, 16, 976371) He was staking everything on the spinning franchise and if he found himself not properly supported by his followers then it would mean breaking of his heart.
('29', 465, 4, 17, 976529) His new plan would be different from that of Bardoli, although his faith in that was yet green.
('29', 465, 4, 18, 976625) He was not going to unfold it to them fully, but if the necessary boycott was effected at the year’s end, his programme could put it into effect irrespective of what was happening in the country.
('29', 465, 4, 19, 976821) But the principal condition precedent to it was boycott of foreign cloth.
('29', 465, 4, 20, 976895) He was sure if they put forth necessary effort, they would be able to boycott cloth of foreign make completely and if that could be done then the time would be for civil disobedience.
('29', 465, 5, 21, 977079) At the end Gandhiji asked that lists should be prepared from among those present, of those who would agree to give the required 24,000 yards of yarn at the year’s end without fail and who would be ready to die for the country, if necessary.

('29', 466, 3, 4, 977470) Mr. Gandhi, in his joint reply, said that he did not deserve the words of praise heaped upon him, for he had done nothing to their city or district.
('29', 466, 3, 5, 977619) He repeated the suggestions he made on similar occasions recently at Bombay, Calcutta and Ahmedabad, and asked them to read and understand them.
('29', 466, 3, 6, 977764) In the present political condition of India, the municipalities of India should take part in the national movement, but not at the sacrifice of their primary duties, cleanliness and sanitation.
('29', 466, 3, 7, 977958) He was not an admirer of Western civilization, but in matters of sanitation, India had to learn a good deal from the West.
('29', 466, 3, 8, 978081) India was essentially an agricultural country, and it ought to have been impossible for plague and other epidemics to spread in our cities, which were small compared to cities in Western countries.
('29', 466, 3, 9, 978279) He felt pained whenever he heard people saying that these epidemics were divine dispensations.
('29', 466, 3, 10, 978374) He was himself a believer in God, but human efforts had considerable scope for alleviating human miseries.
('29', 466, 3, 11, 978481) When we ourselves break God’s or Nature’s laws, it is absurd to attribute these epidemics to God.
('29', 466, 3, 12, 978579) He was glad to note that the relations between Brahmins and non Brahmins, and Hindus and Mussalmans, were cordial, and while advising the audience to continue those relations, asked them to extend their love to the untouchables.

('29', 470, 1, 2, 987256) 402. SPEECH AT SUBJECTS COMMITTEE MEETING, BELGAUM 1
('29', 470, 2, 3, 987309) December 25, 1924
('29', 470, 3, 4, 987327) The following is the full text of the moving speech made by Mahatma Gandhi at the meeting of the Subjects Committee of the All India Congress on Thursday last: Tomorrow we meet sharp at 3 o’clock.
('29', 470, 3, 5, 987524) A few minutes will be spent in musical recitations.
('29', 470, 3, 6, 987576) The chairman of the Reception Committee will not take more than 15 minutes to deliver his speech.
('29', 470, 3, 7, 987674) I do not propose to read my address.
('29', 470, 3, 8, 987711) My speech will be distributed to you this evening.
('29', 470, 3, 9, 987762) You will kindly study that address, for the address will be taken as read.
('29', 470, 3, 10, 987837) I shall make a few simple introductory remarks not covering more than 30 minutes.
('29', 470, 3, 11, 987919) I shall begin in Hindustani and then speak in English.
('29', 470, 3, 12, 987974) On the whole it would not exceed 30 minutes.
('29', 470, 3, 13, 988019) Tomorrow the first resolution that will be moved after the formal reading of the addresses will be that relating to the Calcutta agreement.
('29', 470, 3, 14, 988159) It will be opposed by Maulana Hasrat Mohani.

('29', 476, 8, 9, 1002704) BUSINESS LIKE
('29', 476, 9, 10, 1002718) Mr. S. G. Pujari of Bijapur sends the following business like note on the remark in Young India that opinion was divided as to the want of durability of khaddar:
('29', 476, 10, 11, 1002880) I am an actual worker in khaddar.
('29', 476, 10, 12, 1002914) One hundred and twenty charkhas with thirteen looms are working under me.
('29', 476, 10, 13, 1002988) I turn out three hundred yards of khaddar every week.
('29', 476, 10, 14, 1003042) My experience dates from 21st August 1921. My method is to purchase cotton locally, issue slivers to spinners, stock the yarn of each spinner separate, and to use the yarn of one hand for the whole of the warp of one whole piece.
('29', 476, 10, 15, 1003272) The same process is repeated as regards woof, the latter being of lower count than the former.
('29', 476, 10, 16, 1003367) That makes the cloth uniform and strong and gives longer durability.
('29', 476, 10, 17, 1003436) I can quote dozens of instances of my customers whose dhotis, shirts and coats generally last for one year.
('29', 476, 10, 18, 1003544) The durability of khaddar is chiefly affected by using yarn bought in markets, because
('29', 476, 11, 19, 1003631) it is not always of good cotton,
('29', 476, 12, 20, 1003664) 2. mostly under twisted,
('29', 476, 13, 21, 1003689) 3. inadvertently sorted,
('29', 476, 14, 22, 1003714) 4. loosely woven.
('29', 476, 15, 23, 1003732) If producers of khaddar would but care to avoid these things, there will be less room for complaints as regards durability.
('29', 476, 16, 24, 1003856) 1 From the reference to Belgaum where the Congress session was held on December 26 and 27
('29', 477, 0, 1, 1003946) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 477, 1, 2, 1003988) I publish the note for the guidance of all who are interested in Khaddar manufacture.
('29', 477, 2, 3, 1004074) TWO ADDRESSES
('29', 477, 3, 4, 1004088) The Belgaum District Board and the Belgaum Municipality did me the honour of presenting me addresses which recounted my virtues.
('29', 477, 3, 5, 1004217) I felt that any recital of my virtues as an All India worker was beside the point.
('29', 477, 3, 6, 1004300) A municipal address may be fittingly given only to a person for municipal virtues.
('29', 477, 3, 7, 1004383) But in the special circumstances in which we are placed, the municipalities which are struggling to be free give expression to their freedom by somewhat identifying themselves with public workers, whether they possess municipal merit or not.
('29', 477, 3, 8, 1004625) It is only from that point of view that the presentation of the municipal addresses to public workers may be justified.
('29', 477, 3, 9, 1004745) But the presentation of these addresses gave me an opportunity of paying a tribute to a Western effort in the midst of my opposition to Western civilization in general.
('29', 477, 3, 10, 1004914) 1 The one thing which we can and must learn from the West is the science of municipal sanitation.
('29', 477, 3, 11, 1005012) By instinct and habit we are used to village life, where the need for corporate sanitation is not much felt.
('29', 477, 3, 12, 1005121) But as the Western civilization is materialistic and therefore tends towards the development of the cities to the neglect of villages, the people of the West have evolved a science of corporate sanitation and hygiene from which we have much to learn.
('29', 477, 3, 13, 1005372) Our narrow and tortuous lanes, our congested ill ventilated houses, our criminal neglect of sources of drinking water require remedying.
('29', 477, 3, 14, 1005509) Every municipality can render the greatest service by insisting on people observing the laws of sanitation.
('29', 477, 3, 15, 1005617) It is a superstition to consider that vast sums of money are required for effecting sanitary reform.
('29', 477, 3, 16, 1005718) We must modify Western methods of sanitation to suit our requirements.
('29', 477, 3, 17, 1005789) And as my patriotism is inclusive and admits of no enmity or ill will, I do not hesitate, in spite of my horror of Western materialism, to take from the West what is beneficial for me.
('29', 477, 3, 18, 1005974) And as I know Englishman to be resourceful, I gratefully seek their assistance in such matters.
('29', 477, 3, 19, 1006070) For instance, I owe to Poore my knowledge of the cheapest and the most effective method of disposal of human excreta.
('29', 477, 3, 20, 1006188) He has shown how by our ignorance or prejudice we waste this precious manure.
('29', 477, 3, 21, 1006266) Excreta are not dirt in their proper place and when they are properly handled.
('29', 477, 3, 22, 1006345) Dirt, as the English say, is”matter misplaced”.
('29', 477, 4, 23, 1006393) 1 Vide”Speech in Reply to Welcome Address, Belgaum”, 21 12 1924.
('29', 478, 0, 1, 1006458) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 479
('29', 478, 1, 2, 1006506) INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA The serpentine coil round the Indian settlers of South Africa is daily tightening.
('29', 478, 1, 3, 1006613) Now in Natal they are deprived even of the municipal franchise.
('29', 478, 1, 4, 1006677) This was said to have been protected.
('29', 478, 1, 5, 1006715) When the attempt was made to take away from them the political franchise, the Natal Government declared that they had no design upon the enjoyment by Indians of the municipal franchise.
('29', 478, 1, 6, 1006901) But no promise made to a weak party is sacred in the estimation of modern Govern ments.
('29', 478, 1, 7, 1006989) Each party must be able to defend its rights by its own inherent strength.
('29', 478, 1, 8, 1007064) The Government of India’s vaunted trusteeship fails at the crucial moment.
('29', 478, 1, 9, 1007139) I know that the settlers look to us for help and prote ction.
('29', 478, 1, 10, 1007201) But they should know that they can have little help from India for the present.
('29', 478, 1, 11, 1007281) She herself is engaged in a life and death struggle.
('29', 478, 1, 12, 1007334) Years ago the late Sir Pherozeshah prophesied that India would be of little help to the Indians overseas, so long as she had not acquired the ability to assert herself.
('29', 478, 1, 13, 1007503) The late Pestonji Padsha was even disgusted with me for going to South Africa.
('29', 478, 1, 14, 1007582) He thought, every Indian worker going out of India was so much economic waste.
('29', 478, 1, 15, 1007661) I think his clear brain partially failed Mr. Padsha.
('29', 478, 1, 16, 1007714) My residence in South Africa was not an economic waste of power.
('29', 478, 1, 17, 1007779) But is there not much truth underl ying Mr. Padsha’s burning desire first to secure India’s freedom?
('29', 478, 1, 18, 1007880) Till we have acquired it, we must send our countrymen across the seas such comfort as newspaper and other sympathy can give them.

('29', 486, 1, 32, 1028622) If any body were to say,”Solve this equation, what the Hindus and the Mussalmans should do?” I would say, it is the duty of every Hindu to be partial to the Mussalmans and of every Mussalman to be partial to the Hindus.
('29', 486, 1, 33, 1028842) I find that there is a seer who wants to see God or to meet God in one way and I in another way and, therefore, everything that he does I look askance.

('29', 486, 1, 35, 1029077) I like to ask the Mussalmans to do that—to be partial to the Hindus.

('29', 487, 3, 10, 1029930) 406. PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESS AT BELGAUM CONGRESS 1
('29', 487, 4, 11, 1029978) December 26, 1924
('29', 487, 5, 12, 1029996) FRIENDS, It was after much misgiving that I accepted the burden of the honour you have done me today.
('29', 487, 5, 13, 1030098) The unique honour for this year should have been bestowed upon Shrimati Sarojini Naidu, who did such wonderful work both in Kenya and South Africa.
('29', 487, 5, 14, 1030246) But it was not to be.
('29', 487, 5, 15, 1030268) The developments both internal and external have necessitated my acceptance of the burden.
('29', 487, 5, 16, 1030359) I know that I shall have your support in my attempt to do justice to the high office to which you have called me.
('29', 487, 5, 17, 1030473) At the outset, let me note with respectful feelings the deaths during the year of Bi Amma, Sir Ashutosh Mukherji, Mr. Bhupendra Nath Basu, Dr. Subramania Iyer and Mr. Dalbahadur Giri at home, and of Messrs Rustomjee and P. K. Naidu in South Africa.
('29', 487, 5, 18, 1030722) I tender in your name my respectful condolences to the bereaved families.
('29', 487, 6, 19, 1030796) RETROSPECTIVE
('29', 487, 7, 20, 1030810) From the September of 1920 the Congress has been principally an institution for developing strength from within.
('29', 487, 7, 21, 1030923) It has ceased to function by means of resolutions addressed to the Government for redress of grievances.
('29', 487, 7, 22, 1031028) It did so, because it ceased to believe in the
('29', 487, 8, 23, 1031075) 1 This printed address appears to have been prepared before December 18; vide”Letter to C. F. Andrews”, 18 12 1924.
('29', 488, 0, 1, 1031191) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 489
('29', 488, 1, 2, 1031239) beneficial character of the existing system of government.
('29', 488, 1, 3, 1031298) The breach of faith with the Mussalmans of India was the first rude shock to the people’s faith in the Government.
('29', 488, 1, 4, 1031413) The Rowlatt Act and O’Dwyerism culminating in the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, opened the eyes of the people to the true nature of the system.
('29', 488, 1, 5, 1031554) At the same time it was reali zed that the existence of the system depended upon the co operation, whether conscious or unconscious and whether voluntary or forced, of the people.
('29', 488, 1, 6, 1031734) With the view therefore of mending or ending the system it was decided to try to begin withdrawing voluntary co operation from the top.
('29', 488, 1, 7, 1031870) At the Special Session of the Congress at Calcutta in 1920, the boycott of Government titles, law courts, educational institutions, legislative bodies and foreign cloth was resolved upon.
('29', 488, 1, 8, 1032058) All the boycotts were more or less taken up by the parties concerned.
('29', 488, 1, 9, 1032128) Those who could not or would not, retired from the Congress.
('29', 488, 1, 10, 1032189) I do not propose to trace the chequered career of the non co operation movement.
('29', 488, 1, 11, 1032270) Though not a single boycott was anywhere near completion, every one of them had undoubtedly the effect of diminishing the prestige of the particular institutions boycotted.
('29', 488, 2, 12, 1032443) The most important boycott was the boycott of violence.
('29', 488, 2, 13, 1032499) Whilst it appeared at one time to be entirely successful, it was soon discovered that the non violence was only skin deep.
('29', 488, 2, 14, 1032622) It was the passive non violence of helplessness, not the enlightened non violence of resourcefulness.
('29', 488, 2, 15, 1032724) The result was an eruption of intolerance against those who did not non co operate.
('29', 488, 2, 16, 1032808) This was violence of a subtler type.
('29', 488, 2, 17, 1032845) In spite, however, of this grave defect I make bold to say that the propaganda of non violence checked the outbreak of physical violence which would certainly have broken out, had not non violent non co operation come into being.
('29', 488, 2, 18, 1033075) It is my deliberate conviction that non violent non co operation has given to the people a consciousness of their strength.
('29', 488, 2, 19, 1033199) It has brought to the surface the hidden powers in the people of resistance through suffering.
('29', 488, 2, 20, 1033294) It has caused an awakening among the masses which perhaps no other method could have.
('29', 488, 3, 21, 1033380) Though, therefore, non violent non co operation has not brought us swaraj, though it has brought about certain deplorable results and though the institutions that were sought to be boycotted are still flourishing, in my humble opinion, non violent non co operation as a means of attaining political freedom has come to stay and that even its partial success has brought us nearer swaraj.
('29', 488, 3, 22, 1033768) There is no mistaking the fact that the capacity for suffering for the sake of a
('29', 489, 0, 1, 1033849) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 489, 1, 2, 1033891) cause must advance it.
('29', 489, 3, 3, 1033914) But we are face to face with a situation that compels us to cry halt.
('29', 489, 3, 4, 1033984) For, whilst individuals hold firmly to their belief in non co oper ation, the majority of those who are immediately concer ned have practically lost faith in it, with the exception of boycott of foreign cloth.
('29', 489, 3, 5, 1034194) Scores of lawyers have resumed practice.
('29', 489, 3, 6, 1034235) Some even regret having ever given it up.
('29', 489, 3, 7, 1034277) Many who had given up Councils have returned to them and the number of those who believe in Council entry is on the increase.
('29', 489, 3, 8, 1034403) Hundreds of boys and girls who gave up Government schools and colleges have repented of their action and have returned to them.
('29', 489, 3, 9, 1034531) I hear that Government schools and colleges can hardly cope with the demand for admission.
('29', 489, 3, 10, 1034622) In these circumstan ces, these boycotts cannot be worked as part of the national progra mme, unless the Congress is prepared to do without the classes directly affected.
('29', 489, 3, 11, 1034792) But I hold it to be just as impracticable to keep these classes out of the Congress as it would be now to keep the non co operators out.
('29', 489, 3, 12, 1034929) They must both remain in the Congress, without either party interfering with or hostility criticizing the other.
('29', 489, 3, 13, 1035042) What is applicable to Hindu Muslim unity is, I feel, applicable to the unity among different political groups.
('29', 489, 3, 14, 1035153) We must tolerate each other and trust to time to convert the one or the other to the opposite belief.
('29', 489, 3, 15, 1035255) We must go furt her.
('29', 489, 3, 16, 1035276) We must plead with the Liberals and others who have seceded to rejoin the Congress.
('29', 489, 3, 17, 1035360) If non co operation is suspended, there is no reason why they should keep out.
('29', 489, 3, 18, 1035439) The advance must be from us Congressmen.
('29', 489, 3, 19, 1035480) We must cordially invite them and make it easy for them to come in.
('29', 489, 3, 20, 1035548) You are perhaps now able to see why I entered into the agreement with the Swarajists.
('29', 489, 4, 21, 1035634) FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT
('29', 489, 5, 22, 1035656) You will observe that one boycott has been retained.
('29', 489, 5, 23, 1035709) Out of regard for the sentiment of an English friend the word”boycott” has been changed in the agreement into”refusal to use foreign cloth”.
('29', 489, 5, 24, 1035850) There is no doubt a bad odour about the word”boycott”.
('29', 489, 5, 25, 1035905) It usually implies hatred.
('29', 489, 5, 26, 1035932) So far as I am concerned, I have not intended the word to bear any such meaning.
('29', 489, 5, 27, 1036013) The boycott has reference not to British but to foreign cloth.
('29', 489, 5, 28, 1036076) That boycott is not merely a right but a duty.
('29', 489, 5, 29, 1036123) It is as much a duty as boycott of foreign waters would be if they were
('29', 490, 0, 1, 1036195) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 491
('29', 490, 1, 2, 1036243) imported to substitute the waters of the Indian rivers.
('29', 490, 1, 3, 1036299) This, however, is a digression.
('29', 490, 1, 4, 1036331) What I wanted to say was that the agreement saves and emphasizes the boycott of foreign cloth.
('29', 490, 1, 5, 1036426) For me it is an effective substitute for violent methods.
('29', 490, 1, 6, 1036484) Just as certain acts such as personal abuse, irritating conduct, lying, causing hurt and murder are symbols of violence, similarly courtesy, inoffensive conduct, truthfulness, etc., are symbols of non violence.
('29', 490, 1, 7, 1036695) And so to me is boycott of foreign cloth a symbol of non violence.
('29', 490, 1, 8, 1036762) Revolutionary crime is intended to exert pressure.
('29', 490, 1, 9, 1036813) But it is the insane pressure of anger and ill will.
('29', 490, 1, 10, 1036866) I contend that non violent acts exert pressure far more effective than violent acts, for that pressure comes from goodwill and gentleness.
('29', 490, 1, 11, 1037005) Boycott of foreign cloth exerts such pressure.
('29', 490, 1, 12, 1037052) We import the largest amount of foreign cloth from Lancashire.
('29', 490, 1, 13, 1037115) It is also by far the largest of all our imports, sugar being next.
('29', 490, 1, 14, 1037183) Britain’s chief interest centres round the Lancashire trade with India.
('29', 490, 1, 15, 1037255) It is the one thing more than any other that has ruined the Indian peasant and imposed partial idleness upon him by depriving him of the one supplementary occupation he had.
('29', 490, 1, 16, 1037429) Boycott of foreign cloth is therefore a necessity if he is to live.
('29', 490, 1, 17, 1037497) The plan, therefore, is not merely to induce the peasant to refuse to buy the cheap and nice looking foreign fabric but also by teaching him to utilize his spare hours in carding and spinning cotton and getting it woven by the village weavers, to dress himself in khaddar so woven and thus to save him the cost of buying foreign and, for that matter, even Indian mill made cloth.
('29', 490, 1, 18, 1037877) Thus, boycott of foreign cloth by means of hand spinning and hand weaving, i.e., khaddar, not only saves the peasant’s money, but it enables us workers to render social service of a first class order.
('29', 490, 1, 19, 1038078) It brings us into direct touch with the villagers.
('29', 490, 1, 20, 1038129) It enables us to give them real political education and teach them to become self sustained and self reliant.
('29', 490, 1, 21, 1038239) Organization of khaddar is thus infinitely better than co operative societies or any other form of village organization.
('29', 490, 1, 22, 1038360) It is fraught with the highest political conse quence, because it removes the greatest immoral temptation from Britain’s way.
('29', 490, 1, 23, 1038486) I call the Lancashire trade immoral, because it was raised and is sustained on the ruin of millions of India’s peasants.
('29', 490, 1, 24, 1038607) And as one immorality leads to another, the many proved immoral acts of Britain are traceable to this one immoral traffic.
('29', 490, 1, 25, 1038730) If therefore this one great temptation is removed from Britain’s path by India’s voluntary effort, it would be good for India, good for Britain and, as Britain, is today the predominant world power, good even for
('29', 491, 0, 1, 1038943) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 491, 1, 2, 1038985) humanity.
('29', 491, 1, 3, 1038995) I do not endorse the proposition that supply follows demand.
('29', 491, 1, 4, 1039056) On the contrary, demand is often artificially created by unscrupulous vendors.
('29', 491, 1, 5, 1039135) And if a nation is bound, as I hold it is, like individuals to comply with a code of moral conduct, then it must consider the welfare of those whose wants it seeks to supply.
('29', 491, 1, 6, 1039310) It is wrong and immoral for a nation to supply for instance intoxicating liquor to those who are addicted to drink.
('29', 491, 1, 7, 1039426) What is true of intoxicants is true of grain or cloth, if the discontinuance of their cultivation or manufa cture in the country to which foreign grain or cloth are exported results in enforced idleness or penury.
('29', 491, 1, 8, 1039640) These latter hurt a man’s soul and body just as much as intoxication.
('29', 491, 1, 9, 1039710) Depression is but excitement upside down and hence equally disastrous in its results and often more so because we have not yet learnt to regard as immoral or sinful the depression of idleness or penury.
('29', 491, 2, 10, 1039913) BRITAIN’S DUTY
('29', 491, 3, 11, 1039928) It is then I hold the duty of Great Britain to regulate her exports with due regard to the welfare of India, as it is India’s to regulate her imports with due regard to her own welfare.
('29', 491, 3, 12, 1040114) That economics is untrue which ignores or disregards moral values.
('29', 491, 3, 13, 1040181) The extension of the law of non violence in the domain of economics means nothing less than the introduction of moral values as a factor to be considered in regulating international commerce.
('29', 491, 3, 14, 1040373) And I must confess that my ambition is nothing less than to see international relations placed on a moral basis through India’s efforts.
('29', 491, 3, 15, 1040510) I do not despair of cultivation of limited mass non violence.
('29', 491, 3, 16, 1040572) I refuse to believe that the tendency of human nature is always downward.
('29', 491, 3, 17, 1040646) The fruition of the boycott of foreign cloth through hand spin ning and khaddar is calculated not only to bring about a political result of the first magnitude, it is calculated also to make the poorest of India, whether men or women, conscious of their strength and make them partakers in the struggle for India’s freedom
('29', 491, 4, 18, 1040969) FOREIGN V. BRITISH
('29', 491, 5, 19, 1040988) It is hardly necessary now to demonstrate the futility, not to say the violent nature, of boycott of British cloth or better still British goods as so many patriots have suggested.

('29', 492, 2, 8, 1041853) OBJECTIONS CONSIDERED
('29', 492, 3, 9, 1041875) But, say the critics, the spinning wheel has not taken, it is not exciting enough, it is an occupation only for women, it means a return to the middle ages, it is a vain effort against the majestic march of scientific knowledge for which machinery stands.
('29', 492, 3, 10, 1042131) In my humble opinion India’s need is not excitement but solid work.

('29', 494, 3, 24, 1048631) A Government can give protection against thieves and robbers, but not even a swaraj government will be able to

('29', 495, 2, 16, 1050424) UNTOUCHABILITY
('29', 495, 3, 17, 1050439) Untouchability is another hindrance to swaraj.

('29', 504, 1, 15, 1072908) Whatever may be true of other countries, there is no chance of the cult of violence flourishing in this country.
('29', 504, 1, 16, 1073021) India is admittedly the best repository and exponent of non violence.
('29', 504, 1, 17, 1073091) Will you not better devote your lives, if you sacrifice them in the cause of non violence?” I know, however, that my appeal to the violent revolutionaries will be just as fruitless as any such appeal to the violent and anarchical Government is likely to be.
('29', 504, 1, 18, 1073349) We must therefore find the remedy and demonstrate to both the violent Government and the violent revolutionaries that there is a force that is more effective than their violence.
('29', 504, 2, 19, 1073528) REPRESSION A SYMPTOM
('29', 504, 3, 20, 1073549) I regard this repression as a chronic symptom of a chronic disease.
('29', 504, 3, 21, 1073617) The European dominance and Asiatic subjection is the formulla.
('29', 504, 3, 22, 1073680) Sometimes it is stated still more cryptically as White v.
('29', 504, 3, 23, 1073738) Kipling miscalled the white man’s yoke as the”white man’s burden”.
('29', 504, 3, 24, 1073805) In the Malaya peninsula the colour bar that was thought to
('29', 505, 0, 1, 1073864) 506 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 505, 1, 2, 1073906) be temporary has now or almost become a permanent institution.
('29', 505, 1, 3, 1073969) The Mauritius planter must get Indian labour without let or hindrance.
('29', 505, 1, 4, 1074040) The Kenya Europeans successfully lord it over Indians who have a prior right to be there.
('29', 505, 1, 5, 1074130) The Union of South Africa would today drive out every Indian, if it safely could, in total disregard of past obligations.
('29', 505, 1, 6, 1074252) In all these cases the Government of India and the Imperial Government are not helpless; they are unwilling or not so insistent as they ought to be on the protection of Indian settlers.
('29', 505, 1, 7, 1074438) The Government of India has not shown even the decency to publish the report of its own Commission on Fiji.
('29', 505, 1, 8, 1074546) The attempt to crush the indomitable spirit of the Akalis is a symptom of the same disease.
('29', 505, 1, 9, 1074638) They have poured their blood like water for the sake of a cause they hold as dear as life itself.
('29', 505, 1, 10, 1074736) They may have erred.
('29', 505, 1, 11, 1074757) If they have, it is they who have ‘bled in the process.
('29', 505, 1, 12, 1074813) They have hurt no one else.
('29', 505, 1, 13, 1074841) Nankana Sahib, Guruka Bagh, and Jaito will bear witness to their courage and their mute sufferings and martyrdom.
('29', 505, 1, 14, 1074955) But the Governor of the Punjab is reported to have vowed that he will crush the Akalis.
('29', 505, 1, 15, 1075043) One hears that repression is crushing the Burmese spirit.
('29', 505, 1, 16, 1075101) Egypt fares no better than we do.
('29', 505, 1, 17, 1075135) A mad Egyptian kills a British officer—certainly a detestable crime.
('29', 505, 1, 18, 1075204) The punishment is not only a detestable crime, but it is an outrage upon humanity.
('29', 505, 1, 19, 1075287) Egypt has nearly lost all it got.
('29', 505, 1, 20, 1075321) A whole nation has been mercilessly punished the crime of one man.
('29', 505, 1, 21, 1075388) It may be that the murder had the sympathy of the Egyptians.
('29', 505, 1, 22, 1075449) Would that justify terrorism by a power well able to protect its interests without it?
('29', 505, 1, 23, 1075536) The repression inBengal is therefore not an extraordinary thing.
('29', 505, 1, 24, 1075601) We must treat its periodic eruption in some shape or other, or in some province or other, as our normal condition till we come to our own.
('29', 505, 2, 25, 1075740) NEED FOR SANCTION
('29', 505, 3, 26, 1075758) The Congress, therefore, to be worthy of its trust must devise a sanction to back its demands.
('29', 505, 3, 27, 1075853) Before we can forge the sanction, we Hindus, Mussalmans, Christians, Sikhs, Parsis, etc., must unite and so should Swarajists, No changers, Liberals, Home Rulers, Muslim Leaguers and others.
('29', 505, 3, 28, 1076044) If we can but speak with a united voice and know our own mind, it would be well.
('29', 505, 3, 29, 1076125) If we can develop the power to keep foreign cloth from our land, it would be better.
('29', 505, 3, 30, 1076210) We are ready then for the sanction.
('29', 506, 0, 1, 1076246) VOL. 29 : 16 AUGUST, 1924 26 DECEMBER, 1924 507
('29', 506, 1, 2, 1076294) MY FAITH
('29', 506, 2, 3, 1076303) Let me state my faith; as a Congressman wishing to keep the Congress intact, I advise suspension of non co operation for I see that the nation is not ready for it.
('29', 506, 2, 4, 1076467) But as an individual, I cannot—will not—do so as long as the Government remains what it is.
('29', 506, 2, 5, 1076559) It is not merely a policy with me, it is an article of faith.
('29', 506, 2, 6, 1076621) Non co operation and civil disobedience are but different branches of the same tree called satyagraha.
('29', 506, 2, 7, 1076724) It is my kalpadruma—Jam i Jam —the Universal Provider.
('29', 506, 2, 8, 1076779) Satyagraha is search for Truth ; and God is Truth.
('29', 506, 2, 9, 1076830) Ahimsa or non violence is the light that reveals that Truth to me.
('29', 506, 2, 10, 1076897) Swaraj for me is part of that Truth.
('29', 506, 2, 11, 1076934) This satyagraha did not fail me in South Africa, Kheda or Champaran and in a hosts of other cases I could mention.
('29', 506, 2, 12, 1077049) It excludes all violence or hate.
('29', 506, 2, 13, 1077083) Therefore, I cannot and will not hate Englishmen.
('29', 506, 2, 14, 1077133) Nor will I bear their yoke.
('29', 506, 2, 15, 1077161) I must fight unto death the unholy attempt to impose British methods and British institutions on India.
('29', 506, 2, 16, 1077265) But I combat the attempt with non violence.
('29', 506, 2, 17, 1077309) I believe in the capacity of India to offer non violent battle to the English rulers.
('29', 506, 2, 18, 1077395) The experiment has not failed.
('29', 506, 2, 19, 1077426) It has succeeded, but not to the extent we had hoped and desired.
('29', 506, 2, 20, 1077492) I do not despair.
('29', 506, 2, 21, 1077510) On the contrary I believe that India will come to her own in the near future, and that only through satyagraha.
('29', 506, 2, 22, 1077622) The proposed suspension is part of the experiment.
('29', 506, 2, 23, 1077673) Non co operation need never be resumed if the programme sketched by me can be fulfilled.
('29', 506, 2, 24, 1077762) Non violent non co ope ration in some form or other, whether through the Congress or without it, will be resumed if the programme fails.
('29', 506, 2, 25, 1077899) I have repeatedly stated that satyagraha never fails and that one perfect satyagrahi is enough to vindicate Truth.
('29', 506, 2, 26, 1078014) Let us all strive to be perfect satyagrahis.
('29', 506, 2, 27, 1078059) The striving does not .
('29', 506, 2, 28, 1078083) require any quality unattainable by the lowliest among us.
('29', 506, 2, 29, 1078142) For satyagraha is an attribute of the spirit within.
('29', 506, 2, 30, 1078195) It is latent in everyone of us.
('29', 506, 2, 31, 1078227) Like swaraj it is our birthright.
('29', 506, 2, 32, 1078261) Let us know it.
('29', 506, 3, 33, 1078277) Young India, 26 12 1924

('29', 508, 1, 2, 1080306) 408. RESOLUTION ON CALCUTTA AGREEMENT AND SPINNING FRANCHISE, BELGAUM CONGRESS
('29', 508, 2, 3, 1080385) December 26, 1924
('29', 508, 3, 4, 1080403) (a) (i) The Congress hereby endorses the following agreement between Mahatma Gandhi on the one hand and Deshbandhu C. R. Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru acting on behalf of the Swaraj Party on the other.
('29', 508, 4, 5, 1080604) THE AGREEMENT 1
('29', 508, 5, 6, 1080620) (ii) The Congress hopes that the agreement will result in true unity between the two wings of the Congress and will also enable persons belonging to other political organizations to join the Congress.
('29', 508, 5, 7, 1080821) The Congress congratulates the Swarajists and others arrested under the New Ordinance or Regulation III of 1818 and is of opinion that such arrests are inevitable so long as the people of India have not the capacity for vindicating their status and liberty, and is further of opinion that such capacity can in the present circumstances of the country be developed by achieving the long deferred exclusion of foreign cloth; and therefore as a token of the earnestness and determination of the people to achieve this national purpose, welcomes the introduction of hand spinning as part of the franchise and appeals to every person to avail himself or herself of it and join the Congress.
('29', 508, 5, 8, 1081507) (iii) In view of the foregoing, the Congress expects every Indian, man and woman, to discard all foreign cloth and to use and wear hand spun and hand woven khaddar to the exclusion of all other cloth.
('29', 508, 5, 9, 1081708) With a view to accomplish the said purpose without delay, the Congress expects all Congress members to help the spread of hand spinning and the antecedent processes and the manufacture and sale of khaddar.
('29', 508, 5, 10, 1081914) The Congress appeals to the Princes and the wealthy classes of India and the members of political and other organizations not represented on the Congress, and municipalities, local boards, panchayats and such other institutions, to extend their help to the spread of hand spinning by personal use and otherwise and especially
('29', 508, 6, 11, 1082240) 1 Not reproduced here; for the text of the Agreement, vide”Joint Statement with Swaraj Party Leaders”, 6 11 1924.
('29', 509, 0, 1, 1082354) 510 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('29', 509, 1, 2, 1082396) by giving liberal patronage to the classes of artists, still surviving and capable of working artistic designs in fine khaddar.
('29', 509, 1, 3, 1082524) (v) The Congress appeals to the merchants engaged in the foreign cloth and yarn trade to appreciate the interests of the nation and discontinue their importation of foreign cloth and yarn and help the national cottage industry by dealing in khaddar.
('29', 509, 1, 4, 1082774) (vi) It having come to the notice of the Congress that varieties of cloth are manufactured in mills and on other looms out of mill yarn and sold in the Indian market as khaddar, the Congress appeals to the mill owners and other manufacturers concerned, to discontinue this undesirable practice and further appeals to them to encourage the revival of the ancient cottage industry of India by restricting their operations among those parts of the country that have not yet come under the Congress influence and appeals to them to discontinue the importation of foreign yarn.
('29', 509, 1, 5, 1083347) (vii) The Congress appeals to the heads and leaders of all religious denominations whether Hindu, Muslim or any others to preach to their congregations the message of khaddar and advise them to discontinue the use of foreign cloth.
('29', 509, 1, 6, 1083579) (b) The present Article VII 1 of the Constitution to be repealed and the following to be substituted therefore:
('29', 509, 2, 7, 1083691) (i) Every person not disqualified under article IV 2 shall be entitled to become a member of any primary organizations controlled by the Provincial Congress Committee, provided that no one shall be a member of any Congress Committee or organization who does not wear hand spun and hand woven khaddar at political and Congress functions or while engaged in Congress business and does not make a contribution of 20,000 yards of evenly spun yarn per year of his or her own spinning, or in the case of illness or unwillingness or any such cause, the same quantity of yarn spun by any other person; provided also that no person shall be a member of two parallel Congress organizations at one and the same time.
('29', 509, 2, 8, 1084397) (ii) The year of the membership shall be reckoned from the Ist January to the 31st December.
('29', 509, 2, 9, 1084490) The said subscription shall be payable

('29', 513, 6, 19, 1093295) After examining the hands raised in favour and against the resolution, he said: I declare the resolution carried.
('29', 513, 7, 20, 1093409) The sitting of the Congress was adjourned for the next day at 11 o’clock sharp.
('29', 513, 8, 21, 1093489) Report of the Thirty ninth Indian National Congress, 1924, pp.
